name: Andrew Wirick
bio:
Andrew Wirick is a software architect and long-time front-end software aficionado. He has a passion for focusing on the human challenges of leveraging software; how we prioritize it, design it, develop it, integrate it, and consume it.

Andrew is a Principal Architect helping to change construction management at Buildertrend Inc. He resides in Omaha, Nebraska.
title: Design systems from the other side: understanding the value for non-designer roles.
abstract: On the surface, a "design system" sounds like something great for designers. But what's the value in it for other technical roles? After demystifying the term, we'll dive into the differences in the day-to-day life of the non-designer roles when using a well-implemented design system.
description:
Design systems are something that many design teams are pushing for within software platforms and products. On the surface, the term sounds like something great for designers. But what's the value in it for other technical roles?

After demystifying the term "design system", we'll dive into the differences in day-to-day life with the developer, quality assurance, and product owner roles. I'll discuss some of the responsibilities that non-designer roles typically have as part of a well-implemented design system. If your company's software doesn't yet have an intentional design system, I'll talk through some great starting spots for designers and non-designers alike.

name: Chris DeMars
bio: Chris DeMars is a front end developer first, UX architect always, from Detroit, Michigan now living in Denver, Colorado. For his community contributions, he holds awards as a Microsoft MVP in developer technologies and Google Developer Expert in web technologies. He is also an international speaker and former organizer for Vuetroit and former co-organizer of the Ann Arbor Accessibility Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, recording episodes of his podcast, Tales From The Script, or watching horror movies.
title: Believe in the Power of CSS
abstract: You know that song by Huey Lewis and the News, The Power of Love? "First time you feel it, it might make you sad." Might be how you feel about CSS right? Truth of the matter is that CSS is such a powerful piece of the puzzle and you should really be excited for what's here and what's to come!
description: You know that song by Huey Lewis and the News, The Power of Love? "First time you feel it, it might make you sad." Might be how you feel about CSS right? What about the power of CSS? CSS has received a bad name as of late, but truth of the matter is that CSS is such a powerful piece of the front-end puzzle and you should really be excited for what's already here and what's to come! Who would have thought we could create magazine-style layouts with CSS grid? What about ruleset variable scoping with custom properties(CSS variables)? And last but not least, the pain of centering content horizontally and vertically which is now possible in three lines with flexbox! Let's talk about how awesome CSS is, and how we can restore our faith in one of the best things that makes the web amazing!
notes:
I spoke at 22 events around the world in 2018, ~30 in total, one workshop, not including meetups and this year I will have spoken at 15 events in 2019 ranging from the U.S., Canada, England, Romania, and Bulgaria.

Past Speaking Engagements

https://youtu.be/OxFkS7oOeWc (Rocky Mountain Angular, 1:00 mark)

name: Eleanor Stribling
bio: Eleanor Stribling is a product manager and developer with a passion for using software to help solve difficult human problems. Her interests are around using software and data to help us make better decisions and developing interfaces that make human and computer interaction more intuitive, accessible and conversational. In her ten years in the tech industry, she's had leadership roles in  in both tiny startups and large multinational companies, building software rooted in data applications for the ad tech, energy, and HR analytics. A lifelong learner currently leveraging her background in Python and analytics to become an expert in AI and Natural Language Processing, she is an alumna University of Toronto and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.  Eleanor lives in San Francisco with her amazing family.
title: Think Like a Product Manager: Straightforward frameworks for building great products
abstract: Product management is an integral part of any software development organization.  In this talk, an experienced PM explains how moments of thinking like a PM can help your team function better, avoid building the wrong thing, and creating a stronger connection to your company and customers.
description:
Ever been working on a project without a strong Product Manager (or no Product Manager) and wondered if you're building the right thing? Or considered Product Management as your next career move?

In this talk, you'll learn from an experienced PM about how to apply straightforward product frameworks from the first day you're back at work that will improve your team's output, impact and connection to your company and customers.
notes:
Hi!  Thanks for considering my talk.

I've given a version of this talk once, at DjangoCon US 2019: https://2019.djangocon.us/talks/think-like-a-product-manager-frameworks/

Here are some videos of previous talks to  give you an idea of my style:
* PyCon Canada 2018: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JKIbGQn-hoU
* Codeland 2018: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=de2AQRuqa0w
* PyCon US 2017: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3dDtACSYVx0
* DjangoCon US 2016: https://confreaks.tv/videos/djancoconus2016-sign-me-up-choosing-using-a-registration-package-for-your-django-project

name: Harnoor Minhas
bio:
Harnoor Minhas is a Senior Data Warehouse Engineer, AWS Certified Solution Architect Associate and a Cloud Technology Enthusiast at Quicken Loans, the nation's largest mortgage lender, which is based in Detroit, Michigan. Harnoor has more than 15 years of diverse work experience working in various sectors namely banking, securities, finance, education, tax, regulatory, private, state and federal government.

Harnoor Minhas believes in continuous improvement and his personal mantra is ‘Believe in Yourself. Live and Grow Everyday’. He also loves helping and mentoring people in technology to realize their full potential. Harnoor is deeply interested in keeping up with the latest technology developments in Big Data, Graph Databases, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning, Serverless Computing and their implementation in AWS cloud. Harnoor is also into cryptocurrency and at point was also heating up his basement using his cryptocurrency mining rig, utilizing 16 graphic cards.
title: From Zero to Machine Learning in 60 Minutes
abstract: When was the last time you attended a Machine Learning presentation & walked out saying that was really cool & I got it!? I am going to take you through an exciting journey of ML - after which - I guarantee you that you will be pumped, have clarity and know exactly how you can implement it yourself.
description:
Description
Have you heard of the catchphrases Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning? So is this yet another theoretical and boring lecture on how cool all this is? …Not Really! During this session, I will take you on a journey of learning about Artificial Intelligence, Machine Learning, Reinforcement Machine Learning and AWS (Amazon Web Services) DeepRacer.

 In the end you will walk away with understanding of different types of Machine Learning and how it's implemented in the industry. You will also be able to quickly and easily - build, train and evaluate your own Reinforcement Machine Learning Model using AWS (Amazon Web Services) and simple Python code. You will see your virtual car model learn, adapt and improve – all in real time as it navigates itself around a virtual race track.
notes:
Harnoor Minhas recently presented at the Quicken Loans - all company tech conference, which was met with great feedback. https://sessionize.com/app/speaker/session/136817

Harnoor Minhas is a Senior Data Warehouse Engineer, AWS Certified Solution Architect/Developer Associate and a Cloud Technology Enthusiast at Quicken Loans, the nation's largest mortgage lender, which is based in Detroit, Michigan. Harnoor has more than 15 years of diverse work experience working in various sectors namely banking, securities, finance, education, tax, regulatory, private, state and federal government.

Harnoor Minhas believes in continuous improvement and his personal mantra is ‘Believe in Yourself. Live and Grow Everyday’. He also loves helping and mentoring people in technology to realize their full potential. Harnoor is deeply interested in keeping up with the latest technology developments in Big Data, Graph Databases, Natural Language Processing, Machine Learning, Serverless Computing, MicroServices and their implementation in AWS cloud. Harnoor is also into cryptocurrency and at point was also heating up his basement using his cryptocurrency mining rig, utilizing 16 graphic cards.

name: Nicole Tibaldi
bio: Nicole is an engineering manager at CircleCI. She cares deeply about improving tech hiring, agile processes, and bridging the gaps between product, design, and engineering. Nicole has previously worked for Halifax-based startup Manifold.co, New York travel company Tablet Hotels, and spent a short stint in the consulting space. Prior to her pivot to the tech industry, she earned a Bachelor of Arts in music performance and spent five years working in banking.
title: “Tech hiring is broken” is broken
abstract: Sure, “tech hiring is broken,” but what’s broken, exactly, and how can we fix it? We’ll examine how to best evaluate technical skills, while also addressing topics we don’t discuss often enough, like how to hire diverse candidates and what we should really explore when looking for “culture fit.”
description: Google the phrase “Tech hiring is broken” and you’ll find roughly 21 million results. You’ll walk away from those articles with more questions than answers. Does whiteboarding really evaluate a candidate’s practical skills? How do you respect a candidate’s time? How do you avoid being exclusionary to minority groups? How do you hire junior candidates? How do you _really_ hire for culture fit? I’ve spent significant time shaping the interview process at the companies I’ve worked for, and I have learned some valuable lessons, You’ll learn about crafting an inclusive hiring process, efficiently evaluating technical skills, patterns in candidate submissions, and how your code is a reflection of culture.
notes: As a female in tech with a non-traditional background, I feel I have a unique perspective on tech hiring. I've spent many hours with my team as we've worked to make our hiring practices more inclusive for all cultures, genders, and skill levels. I've also seen countless code submissions and have perspective on how to create a fair assessment, and how to evaluate it fairly. I am passionate about this subject, and have seen positive trends  as a result of the work I've done.

name: Cassandra Faris
bio: Cassandra Faris is passionate about the human side of technology. She is the Community Manager at SaltStack, an event-driven security, cloud, and configuration management software company. Her career has focused on supporting tech professionals through training, community outreach, marketing, hiring, mentoring, and employee engagement. She is an international speaker who specializes in teaching people how to communicate, be more effective team members, and advance their careers.  She President of the Stir Scholarship for high school girls pursuing technology careers and President Emeritus of the DogFoodCon tech conference. She has an MBA in Organizational Leadership. When she's not busy with the tech community, she is an avid tabletop gamer, runner, and soccer fan who travels as much as possible.
title: Get Out of Your Lane!
abstract: We believe staying in our lanes, gaining more years of experience, and learning new tech skills yields automatic career growth. This is a mistake! Continued career growth also requires us to learn business and communications skills. This talk teaches you why these skills matter and how to gain them.
description: In the tech industry, we often think our jobs have narrowly defined skillsets. We believe that staying in our lanes, gaining more years of experience, and learning new technical skills yields automatic career growth. This is a mistake! For continual career growth, we must also venture into the worlds of business and communication. This talk will explain why these worlds matter to your career. You’ll discover how to gain and apply this knowledge through hands-on exercises and discussion. You’ll also learn how leveraging the tech community enhances your business and communication skills alongside your technical skills. This session will leave you challenged to go beyond your job description and drive your career forward.
notes: This talk has been presented at Code PaLOUsa, Kansas City Developer Conference, Momentum Developer Conference, and Music City Tech.

name: Grishma Jena
bio: Grishma Jena is a Data Scientist with the UX Research and Design team at IBM Data & AI in San Francisco. She works across portfolios in conjunction with user research and design teams and uses data to understand users' struggles and opportunities to enhance their experiences. She earned her Masters in Computer Science at University of Pennsylvania. Her research interests are in Machine Learning and Natural Language Processing. She has spoken and facilitated workshops at multiple conferences including PyCon US (largest Python conference in the world) and O’Reilly OSCON. She has also taught Python at the San Francisco Public Library and was a mentor for AI4ALL's AI Project Fellowship Spring 2018 where she guided a group of high school students to use AI for prioritizing 911 EMS calls. In her free time, she writes, cooks and likes conducting workshops and delivering talks. She likes explaining things in an easy-to-understand format, drawing analogies from real-life (eg. using Uncle Scrooge to explain Greedy Algorithms https://medium.com/the-graph/uncle-scrooge-meets-greedy-algorithms-dfc80c33d7ac). https://www.linkedin.com/in/grishmajena/
title: Why Data Science and UX Research should be Best Friends
abstract: Data Science is changing the world and UX research needs to get onboard to better understand business and user needs. This talk uses real-life examples to explain how Data Science can complement UX research and the kind of applications data scientists and UX researchers can collaboratively work on.
description:
Today’s world generates data at unbelievably rapid rates. It is important to leverage the available data to better understand the bigger picture. Data scientists and UX researchers often have the same destination but different routes. This talk gives an overview of how Data Science can complement UX research, including quantitative and qualitative methods. It introduces the Data Science pipeline along with describing useful applications for UX research like identifying users to interview, finding different segments of customers and generating data for usability studies. It highlights interesting instances of how the two fields can help each using real-life examples from Spotify, Airbnb, Tesla, etc.

* Motivation
* Applications of data science
* What questions can data science answer?
* Different sources of data
* Data cleaning and exploration
* Models and algorithms
* Data visualization and storytelling
* Ethical challenges and considerations
* How Data scientists and UX researchers can collaborate
* Additional resources

By the end of this session, audience members will have a better grasp of the capabilities and processes of Data Science. They will be able to identify opportunities where Data Science can support and enhance UX research. They will feel motivated to encourage their UX research and Data Science teams to work closer together to understand business and user needs.
notes: I will be deriving from my experiences working as a data scientist on a UX research team. I am very passionate about introducing new technical concepts to people, especially those about Data Science and Machine Learning. I have previously delivered technical talks and conducted workshops in the community. I always aim to include elements of humor in my talks and use real-world analogies so people can relate better to what I am saying and are able to retain the concepts for longer.

name: Svetlana Kouznetsova
bio: Svetlana Kouznetsova (Sveta) is a NYC-based user experience and accessibility consultant and works with business owners, media producers, corporations, educational institutions, event organizers to make their products, services, interactions user-friendly and accessible to more people. She has a Master of Science degree in Internet Technology, several advanced certifications, and project experience with national and international organizations and educational institutions. Sveta is also a founder of Audio Accessibility and provides consultation and training to businesses about quality communication access to audio, video, events. She is an experienced speaker and author of “Sound Is Not Enough: Captioning as Universal Design”. Sveta's TEDx talk uncovers the benefits of captioning access that increase audience and ROI for businesses. Her personal experience with deafness and communication barriers contributes to her success as a professional consultant and allows clients to have a greater understanding of why accessibility is critical.
title: Accessibility Through Deaf Lens: Coding and Beyond
abstract: Web accessibility is not only about coding or for blind people. As an accessibility consultant who is also deaf, Sveta will explain why accessibility is for everyone and is a responsibility of all team members and share her personal experience and some examples of accessibility issues and solutions.
description: Accessibility is for everyone and is the responsibility of all team members. While a lot of web accessibility guidelines are focused on coding, there are other accessibility components that all team members need to consider in order to improve the overall product or service from the beginning of any project. Sveta will share her personal experience as a deaf person and some examples of accessibility issues and solutions. They may be new to some and sound like common sense to others, but sadly there are many products and services that fail at accessibility. The talk will help developers and their team members better understand why accessibility is not just about coding and why it’s not to be used as an afterthought.
notes: I’m familiar with accessibility not only because I work in the field, but also because I’ve personally experienced accessibility issues as a deaf person and represent the largest and the most ignored minority that makes up over 1 billion people worldwide. In addition to this, I’m also female and foreign-born, so I represent several disadvantaged groups. I’ve given presentations worldwide for over a decade: https://svknyc.com/speaking. Accessibility is one of the areas I speak about in my presentations that audiences often find enlightening. The need for and the importance of accessibility to a  very large segment of the population is often not considered by event organizers and is a large factor in reducing the size of the audience they reach. If you think my unique presentation will be of value to you please let me know - at least 2-3 months in advance.

name: Christiana Unaeze
bio: Christiana Unaeze is a User Experience Designer, Entrepreneur and Visual Design Strategist. She has over a decade of combined experience in visual and user experience design, project management and design consulting. Currently, Christiana is a consultant with a federal agency where she leads and supports design and accessibility efforts on multiple projects. She is on a mission to help design products that are engaging, creative and accessible to all. She is also a runner, an avid reader, a Game of Thrones fan, an aficionado of statement jewelry, and a fervent DIYer.
title: Guidelines on Designing and Testing for Accessibility
abstract: Ensuring great user experience means creating digital products that ANYONE can use. If you are not thinking about accessibility, then you’re not thinking about the full user experience. Accessibility makes it possible for people with disabilities to understand and navigate well designed products.
description: One main goal of great user experience is creating digital products that ANYONE can use. If you are not thinking about accessibility, then you’re not thinking about the full user experience. Ideally, the user experience for everyone should be the same regardless of physical or cognitive limitations. This means addressing user accessibility scenarios from the onset. Accessibility makes it possible for people with disabilities to understand and navigate well designed digital products. However, accessibility is often one of the last things addressed in product and software design. These guidelines will cover some of the major factors to address and test for in order to meet the accessibility standards in the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG).

name: Adrienne Tacke
bio: Adrienne Braganza Tacke is a Filipina software engineer, international speaker, and published author of the book Coding for Kids: Python. She is also a LinkedIn Learning instructor who specializes in Azure and Cloud Development courses. She takes great delight in solving complex problems and building awesome things, particularly with C# and JavaScript. Most of all, she relishes the opportunity to teach anyone about code.
title: Testing the Functional Waters: Functional Programming Principles and Patterns in C#
abstract: Functional programming gives developers many benefits, especially when it comes to data-driven applications. But what if you're not ready to commit to F# or other strictly functional language? Here, we'll explore how to implement functional programming concepts in C# & why they enhance our code!
description:
Originating as a C# developer, the benefits of functional programming always taunted me. Yet, most applications I worked on heavily relied on user interfaces and an otherwise object-oriented architecture, so the decision to move to F# or some other functional programming language didn't make sense. 

Despite this, many principles and patterns from functional programming DID make sense to implement for cleaner and more robust code. Important paradigms like immutability, method chaining, and using expressions over statements were certainly things even C# developers could take advantage of! In this talk, I want to demonstrate how C# developers can implement these beneficial patterns and principles and explore how doing so ultimately results in better code!

name: Fredric Mitchell
bio: Fredric Mitchell is the principal of Bright Plum, Inc., a neighborhood tech consulting shop, and advisor to The Whether, a startup aimed at helping companies recruit diverse entry-level talent. He has a wide variety of experience working in the government, NGO, and education sectors. Fredric has presented at numerous events throughout the United States and Costa Rica and is a regular contributor to open source communities. He has a B.S. in Electrical Engineering from Washington University in St. Louis.
title: How Math, Science, and Star Trek Explain the Value of Team Diversity
abstract:
The greatest asset of open source software is the ability to fork and improve. When it comes to tech culture, are we accepting all pull requests? Can we be better? If so, how? To the science!

This session explores the mathematical algorithms describing the advantage of diverse teams.
description:
The greatest asset of open source software is the ability to fork and improve. When it comes to tech culture, are we accepting all pull requests? Can we be better? 

If so, how? To the science!

This session explores the mathematical algorithms and scientific studies describing the advantage of diverse teams. We’ll dive into existing research and real-world situations that solved complex problems. We’ll also explore a mathematician’s theory that “diversity trumps ability.”

We’ll also explore how Star Trek played a pivotal role in being the allegory for this concept.

Attendees will take away concrete ideas, examples, and processes to, hopefully, increase the output of their team in the long-term.

At the end of this session, attendees will be able to:

- Apply 3 recruitment ideas to increase the divesity of applicants to their organizations
- Identify 3 techniques to foster healthy dialogue about inclusivity and equity within their organization
- Develop a solid defense of why Star Trek: Voyager was the best Star Trek series.
notes:
Speaking experience:

- LISA19: https://www.usenix.org/conference/lisa19/presentation/mitchell
- PEERS 2017: http://peersconf.com/2017/speakers/fredric-mitchell
- Velocity 2015: http://conferences.oreilly.com/velocity/devops-web-performance-ny-2015/public/schedule/detail/44108
- Drupalcon Austin: https://austin2014.drupal.org/session/30-drupal-8-api-functions-you-should-already-know.html
- Twin Cities Drupalcamp: http://2014.tcdrupal.org/node/237

name: Jake Witcher
bio:
Jake Witcher is a software developer and national speaker from Cincinnati, OH. After 15 years in retail merchandising, Jake began learning JavaScript and in ten months switched careers to become a software developer. He has been building custom software for businesses in the greater Cincinnati area as a consultant for Callibrity since April of 2019.

Jake primarily works in C# but is a functional programming enthusiast and enjoys hacking on side projects written in F#. When he’s not learning about composition, combinators, and monads (oh my!) or watching Supernatural for the nth time, Jake is either working on new content for his blog or training to be a ninja with his two children.
title: Refactoring from ‘for each’ to Functional
abstract: When working with data in collections, using a 'for each' loop can be useful for reasoning about a solution. However when the problem grows more complex refactoring from ‘for each’ toward a declarative, functional style using LINQ methods like Select, Where, and Aggregate becomes advantageous.
description: The ‘for each’ loop is a classic C# approach for iterating over a collection to transform, gather, or filter data. And it’s a classic for good reason. When trying to solve a problem, thinking through the solution step by step in a procedural way can be quite useful. However when the problem grows more complex, so can the body of the ‘for each’ loop. It’s at this point it becomes advantageous to move toward a more declarative style of programming. This session provides several examples of how to refactor from a ‘for each’ solution to a functional one using LINQ methods like Select, Where, and Aggregate. Going through the process step by step, you will learn ways to make the end result correct, readable and maintainable.
notes: You can find a list of my 2019 speaking engagements here: https://www.codefornerds.com/speaking-engagements/

name: Fen Slattery
bio:
Fen Slattery is the Accessibility Lead at Clique Studios, where they build beautiful things and work towards a more inclusive digital world. As a web engineer, Fen seamlessly translates the needs of users into digital experiences that minimize barriers to access. As part of their advocacy work, they have spoken across the US to audiences of all skill levels, been featured on many panels about inclusion in the tech industry, and have spread their passion for accessibility in mentorship of web professionals.

They come to the world of development from a psychology and physics background at the Illinois Institute of Technology. Currently, they are a co-organizer for Chicago’s Digital Accessibility and Inclusive Design meetup, one of the largest community accessibility organizations worldwide. In their spare time, Fen can be found writing zines, running roleplaying games, and taking their cat for walks.
title: Digital Accessibility Beyond Legal Compliance
abstract: Roughly 10% of people have a disability that impacts their use of the web, and lawsuits against inaccessible websites are becoming more common. How can we move beyond seeing accessibility as a legal requirement, and to championing inclusion for people with disabilities?
description: Roughly ten percent of people have a disability that directly impacts their use of digital technologies, and lawsuits against inaccessible websites are becoming more and more common. The Americans with Disabilities Act and Section 508 require us to build accessible technology for people with disabilities, but that shouldn't be our primary driver for being inclusive of all users. How can we move beyond seeing accessibility as a legal requirement, and into championing inclusion for people with disabilities? In this talk, I'll discuss additional motivations for building accessible technology and how to help build empathy for the cause of accessibility within your organization.
notes:
I'm a digital accessibility and inclusion expert who works with clients to create accessible websites, educate developers and designers, and remediate websites with issues. As a disabled person, I advocate heavily for listening to people with disabilities about our needs, and moving beyond thinking of accessibility as something we "have to do" and towards an ethical responsibility we should be excited to do. I've given talks across the US to a wide variety of audiences, led workshops, participated on panels, and appeared on podcasts; I'd love to share my knowledge with your audience!

---

An outline for this talk: (Please note that a11y is an abbreviation for accessibility; PwD is an abbreviation for people with disabilities.)

Intro
- what's the point of this talk?
- who am i, and why should you be listening to me?
- who are you? raise your hand if you've heard about a11y before, raise your hand if you've built something with a11y in mind

the basics
- what is a11y
- the basics of legal compliance - the ADA and section 508
- more guidelines outside of the US
- the WCAG

legal compliance
- so many companies ask "are we wcag compliant" or "is the website ada"
- so often, clients are concerned with following the law, doing the bare minimum. and as consultants, we sell ourselves as being able to do the bare minimum, aka compliance
- those of us that work on internal code, we often just care about hitting the WCAG as a testing criteria
- even as individuals, we often sell ourselves to companies we want to work for as "well i know the wcag"
- and this makes sense, when you think about the developer mindset, right? we write a test, we seek to pass it. and the wcag is a testable thing!
- we're motivated by not getting sued, or being legally allowed to launch, if we're a gov't entity

beyond
- WCAG AA is a minimum passing grade. it's like getting a D. good job, i guess?
- it doesn't feel warm and fuzzy to just like, meet minimum requirements to pass a minimum bar
- accessibility is about inclusion. thinking of it from a legal perspective ignores WHY the laws exist!
- history time! let's talk about the rehab act and the ADA, and the people who fought hard for those.
- the WCAG doesn't exist because some benevolent privileged abled people decided to be nice to those of us with disabilities. it exists because we fight for it, because we push for it.

how to build empathy
- DON'T do disability simulations
- hire people with disabilities
- do user interviews with PwD
- do user testing and validation with PwD
- learn about WHY a11y guidelines are the way they are
- follow disability rights activists - i've got twitter and youtube suggestions
- read a book!

but empathy doesn't pay the bills
- it's hard to sell bosses and the business interests on empathy and inclusion. (unless you work somewhere awesome (like i do)). you also need to provide the financial motivations for a11y
- PwD control $$$ of discretionary income
- PwD prefer services that are accessible and will choose those
- not getting sued is a great way to save money!
- it's WAY CHEAPER to bake a11y in than add it later

if not you, who

name: Clifton Simmons II
bio: For over 20 years, Clifton has worked at large ad agencies as a creative supervisor on USAA, Chevy, Coke and McDonald’s accounts. Five years ago, he never considered a career in UX. Yet, it feels like his extensive digital experience has led him to this. Clifton currently mentors students and grads interested in marketing careers and was named an "Unsung Hero of the Internet" at SXSW for his efforts. He also serves on the board of directors of the Insurance Marketing Communication Association.
title: "Du" Good Digitally: Corporate Volunteerism Side Hustles
abstract: Retain top talent and do good in your community by encouraging staff to use their digital superpowers to help area nonprofits. Corporate volunteerism is quickly growing into today’s high-impact training and development programs for many industries, from Allstate to Salesforce.
description:
"Du" Good Digitally: Corporate Volunteerism Side Hustles
====================

Corporate volunteerism is the new employee leadership program
---------------------

Retain top talent and do good in your community by encouraging staff to use their digital superpowers to help area nonprofits. Corporate volunteerism is quickly growing into today’s high-impact training and development programs for many industries, from Allstate to Salesforce. 

### Create some hero workship 

> Corporate volunteerism develops leadership skills, maintains retention, and builds your brand by creating positive impact in the community.
notes:
An Allstate Fellow
====================

I know the benefits of growing by giving
---------------------

UX content strategist Clifton Simmons is a two-time Allstate Fellow. Allstate Fellows is a volunteer program that allows Allstate employees to devote one day per week to work on a three-month project for area non-profit organizations. Most requests are digital needs. Participation this deep is the equivalent of accepting a side-hustle. Only this second job pays you by sharpening your skills and recharging your creative batteries. This talk will present cases on how these programs are essential to employee growth and brand building. As case studies, we'll look at my work with the DuSable Museum of African American History and the Chicago Humanities Festival.

name: PJ Hagerty
bio: Developer, writer, speaker, musician, and founder of DevRelate.io, PJ is known to travel the world speaking about programming and the way people think and interact.  He is also known for wearing hats.
title: Proactive Programming
abstract: The feedback loop is one of the most important parts of programming. We write tests and try to mitigate all possible problems, but until we deploy our code, it's hard to tell what "works" and what doesn't.
description: The feedback loop is one of the most important parts of programming. We write tests and try to mitigate all possible problems, but until we deploy our code, it's hard to tell what "works" and what doesn't. In this talk, we'll discuss methods used to ensure everything works the way it should before deploying to production.

name: PJ Hagerty
bio: Developer, writer, speaker, musician, and founder of DevRelate.io, PJ is known to travel the world speaking about programming and the way people think and interact.  He is also known for wearing hats.
title: A Glimpse into Accessibility
abstract:
When we build applications for the modern world, we think of our users as much as possible. But what about those who are on the fringes, outside of the average.

This talk will take a look at accessibility, how to design applications with users with disabilities in mind.
description:
Accessibility is an issue often overlooked in modern application development. This talk will take a look some hurdles of consideration and remind developers of the importance of focusing on making their applications accessible to anyone.

We want to make a better world, let's look at making it better for everyone.

Note: the first 5 mins of this talk are done in ASL with no speaking or interpreter.
notes: Note: the first 5 mins of this talk are done in ASL with no speaking or interpreter.

name: PJ Hagerty
bio: Developer, writer, speaker, musician, and founder of DevRelate.io, PJ is known to travel the world speaking about programming and the way people think and interact.  He is also known for wearing hats.
title: Good Enough: The Enemy of Innovation
abstract: The building of modern technology, application development, and all that goes along with it is anchored in the idealization of innovation. For years, the web & mobile application development has rooted itself in the idea of pushing things forward, building a better world for the people living in it.
description:
Not too many years ago, the market for technology left the boardrooms of large enterprises companies and entered the consumer market. It’s interesting to consider that such things as smart phones and portable devices, tablets and even laptop computers have only become a major part of life for the general public over the past two decades. At the beginning of the 21st Century, we were at a boom for the use of home computing in industrialized countries. Now, around the world, people have handheld mobile devices in the remotest of regions.

But are we moving in a positive direction? What have been the major technological breakthroughs a person on the street can benefit from? How do the applications we use regularly innovate? Do they at all?

Unfortunately, this doesn’t seem to be the case.

name: Jonathan Turner
bio: Jon graduated from Brigham Young University with a bachelor's and a master's degree in computer science. His thesis was on "cool robot stuff" (more specifically, user interface design combined with interactive machine learning applied to robot control). He has worked as a developer doing data conversion, government management software, and educational software focused on teaching children English. He also taught computer science at Neumont University. He currently works as a software craftsman at Pluralsight, which specializes in online technical training. When not developing professionally, he enjoys working on mobile, game, hardware and other random side projects.
title: TDD - It's About More Than Just the Tests
abstract: How is test drive development different than writing tests before writing your code? What are the steps of TDD? How does TDD influence the production code you write? Come find out the answers to these questions and more in this introduction to TDD.
description:
Test driven development is all the rage. But what is test driven development? It just means that you write your tests before your code, right? Writing the tests first is part of test driven development, but only one part. And some would argue not the most important part.
 
In this session we’ll talk about what test driven development (TDD) actually is and how it differs from other types of testing. We’ll go over the basic mechanics of TDD. Then we’ll write some code using TDD, both to show these mechanics and to illustrate how using TDD can not only add tests but result in better code than we might otherwise end up with.
 
If you’ve never done TDD before or have done a little and would like to learn more, this session is for you.
notes:
In my experience interacting with other developers I've noticed a lot of confusion around the differences between unit tests, test first development and test driven development. The intent of this presentation is to help developers understand the difference between these types of tests, to learn what the basic steps of TDD are and to see these steps demonstrated in a code kata.

I have given this presentation at the Agilel 2018, Utah Python User Group, the Utah .NET User Group and the Utah Software Craftsmanship group and the response was great at all of them.

name: Jonathan Turner
bio: Jon graduated from Brigham Young University with a bachelor's and a master's degree in computer science. His thesis was on "cool robot stuff" (more specifically, user interface design combined with interactive machine learning applied to robot control). He has worked as a developer doing data conversion, government management software, and educational software focused on teaching children English. He also taught computer science at Neumont University. He currently works as a software craftsman at Pluralsight, which specializes in online technical training. When not developing professionally, he enjoys working on mobile, game, hardware and other random side projects.
title: 6+ Years of Pair and Mob Programming - Ask Me Anything
abstract: I have been developing software using pair and mob programming full time for over 6 years. There are a lot of people curious about how this kind of software development works. This is your chance to ask someone who's been doing it for a while!
description:
A lot of people talk about pair programming. Some also talk about mob programming. These two practices can be a great tool in developing software, but I’ve found that not a lot of developers get an opportunity to practice them. Consequently there are a lot of questions and sometimes some misconceptions about them.

I’ve been working in an environment where we use pair and mob programming almost exclusively for over six years. In this session I’ll go over some of  my experiences (good and bad) with pair and mob programming. The rest of the time will be open for you to ask any questions you have about what it’s like to pair and mob programming full time.
notes:
I've been to several presentations and workshops on mob programming in the past. A large portion of the time at those events is spent answering questions about how mob programming actually works. I was thinking it would be useful to give a presentation that is geared towards answering those questions. I even got the opportunity to ask Woody Zuill about the idea and he thought it sounded good!

This would be the first time I would give this presentation. So it could go fantastically well or it could crash and burn horribly. I'm hoping for the former, but plan to prepare for the latter, just in case.

name: Dana Scheider
bio: Dana Scheider is a member of the Cucumber core team. Hailing from Portland, Oregon, she currently lives in Melbourne, Australia, where she works as a Ruby on Rails developer for Envato. She is particularly interested in testing, behaviour-driven development, REST API design, and improving processes within engineering organisations. Dana's extracurricular interests include theoretical mathematics, opera, and shooting pool. An in-demand speaker, notable conference appearances include SwanseaCon, CukeUp! London, Full Stack Toronto, and RubyConf Colombia.
title: The Joy of Docs, or, Technical Writing for Developers and Engineers
abstract: Have you ever struggled to use a tool because the docs were bad? Of course you have! It's not surprising considering engineers are rarely taught the basics of technical writing. This talk will give you some pointers so your users have a better experience.
description: Technical writing is rarely taught in code schools or listed among the qualifications for an engineering job. Yet users rely heavily on documentation to use the tools they need to use. Not only that, decisions about which tool to use often take into account the availability of quality documentation. It's important not to leave the task of writing docs to technical writers who may not fully understand the underlying technology or use cases. This talk will teach you the basics of technical writing--from tutorials and reference guides to pull requests and release notes - so you can increase adoption of your software and keep your users--and your coworkers--happy.
notes:
I'm an engineer who has worked as a writer. I've gotten consistently positive feedback about the docs I write and the PR descriptions I author, so I think I have some knowledge to share on the subject that will be useful to others. While content varies by the amount of time allotted, some of what I might cover includes:

* Considering your users' existing knowledge base, and asking yourself whether there might be users with a different background you haven't considered
* Asking yourself what could go wrong for a user
* Filling in missing context
* Imagining edge cases
* Thinking of what your software CAN'T do, as well as what it can
* Making assumptions explicit
* Writing fundamentals (paragraph structure, use of jargon or specialised language, conventions, etc.)
* Making your writing accessible to less experienced or less technical users
* Planning, outlining, and editing
* Conducting documentation reviews
* The relationship between documentation and inclusivity

This talk will be useful to developers at all levels.

name: Matt Busche
bio: Programmer, speaker, and runner. Web performance enthusiast. Wheel of Fortune expert. @northerniowa alum.
title: Web Performance - Where to start?
abstract: As an industry we've built thousands of websites, but how many of them perform well on slow connections? Let's learn the quickest ways to achieve a more performant website without breaking the bank and keep our business partners happy.
description: As an industry we've built thousands of websites, but how many of them are readily accessible to people without fast computers or 4G internet? In this session we'll learn how we can reduce the weight of our website and make it accessible to everyone. This includes reducing image size, reducing JavaScript, and reducing round trips to a web server. We'll also learn how Progressive Web Application technology can provide a working website even when a network is unavailable.

name: Chris DeMars
bio: Chris DeMars is a front end developer first, UX architect always, from Detroit, Michigan now living in Denver, Colorado. For his community contributions, he holds awards as a Microsoft MVP in developer technologies and Google Developer Expert in web technologies. He is also an international speaker and former organizer for Vuetroit and former co-organizer of the Ann Arbor Accessibility Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, recording episodes of his podcast, Tales From The Script, or watching horror movies.
title: ARIA: A Grande Method Of Accessible Markup
abstract: ARIA, or accessible rich internet applications, are a very powerful set of attributes that define non-semantic content for your users with disabilities.
description: ARIA, or accessible rich internet applications, are a very powerful set of attributes that define non-semantic content for your users with disabilities. In this session, we are going to break down web accessibility at its most granular level before exploring ARIA properties that will help create amazing user experiences, when semantic markup won't cut it. By the end of this talk, you will walk away with the knowledge of introductory ARIA concepts and when to put them into practice
notes:
I spoke at 22 events around the world in 2018, ~30 in total, one workshop, not including meetups and this year I will have spoken at 15 events in 2019 ranging from the U.S., Canada, England, Romania, and Bulgaria.

name: Simon Yost
bio:
I empower teams to close the gap between design and engineering so that digital experiences connect people. While specializing in maximizing the potential of multi-disciplinary teams, I create sustainable, nimble digital experiences and technical solutions.

I have spent 15 years building organizations (startups, nonprofits, and enterprise) in the Midwest region by spearheading digital strategy and content delivery. That includes countless hours coaching professionals and students on building applications, creating digital experiences, and installing systems in their businesses. I currently serve as a technology consultant at Slalom St. Louis.

Outside of work, I am a husband, father, amateur cyclist, and self-professed coffee aficionado. My passions include foster/adopt parenting and Nebraska football.

I write at [UIE.dev](https://medium.com/uie-dev).
title: Adding Design to DevOps
abstract: Once your app and DevOps are humming along, it happens: a new feature request. Starting new features with static design mockups is failing. We need new processes so our teams can interact differently. Join us to explore integrating developers, devOps, and design workflows & what is holding us back.
description:
After the Kubernetes cluster is stood up, Docker containers are deployed, Jenkins jobs (or similar) are pushing code to production, your cloud app is humming along. Then, it happens: a new feature request.

Designers have long handed-off instructions for new features with only an image or two—static pictures that represent how the coded version should appear. That process is failing us. We don’t need to fire everyone and start over, and we need some new systems and structures to help our teams interact differently. 

In this session, we will explore how to integrate developers, devOps, and design workflows and what is holding us back from cross-functional, high performing greatness.
notes:
I had a blast speaking at Connectaha last year and would be honored to return. My mission unifying & aligning teams around the power of technology so that tribes can thrive. This presentation would serve your attendees to that end.

Here is a recent example of my speaking from a DevOps Days event: https://youtu.be/cfmdqlqkxfc

I have spent 15 years building organizations (startups, nonprofits, and enterprise) in the Midwest region by spearheading digital strategy and content delivery. That includes countless hours coaching professionals and students on building applications, creating digital experiences, and installing systems in their businesses. I currently serve as a technology consultant at Slalom St. Louis.

Outside of work, I am a husband, father, amateur cyclist, and self-professed coffee aficionado. My passions include foster/adopt parenting and Nebraska football.

name: Jake Partusch
bio: 👋 My name is Jake, and I love all things JavaScript. I'm the Director of Web and Mobile at Object Partners, where we help our clients to build highly customized web applications. I feel most at home when I'm either learning something new, or teaching others. When I'm not writing code, I love to read, golf, and spend time with my family 👪.
title: Serverless for Frontend Developers
abstract: In this ever-changing, cloud-centric world, the ability to quickly build and deploy an API is an invaluable skill for frontend developers. Serverless strikes the balance between the richness of traditional APIs and approachability for developers that are new to server-side development.
description:
With the exploding popularity of serverless and cloud applications, it is easier than ever to build and deploy a full-stack application. Historically, even writing a backend in a familiar language like JavaScript required extensive knowledge of virtual machines, networking, and containerization. As tools and serverless capabilities have improved, we can stop worrying about the server management, and stick to writing code! 

In this talk, we'll explore the history of server-side development with JavaScript and its evolution into a leading cloud application language. We'll dive into the basics of building a serverless application and write/deploy a live example!
notes:
👋 I'm a a software consultant specializing in frontend development. Over the past two years, I've also been working with AWS and deploying serverless backends for my applications. So, I've developed some great, real-world, experience and would love to share with the community!

- My only technical requirement is decent WiFi 😉

name: Jake Partusch
bio: 👋 My name is Jake, and I love all things JavaScript. I'm the Director of Web and Mobile at Object Partners, where we help our clients to build highly customized web applications. I feel most at home when I'm either learning something new, or teaching others. When I'm not writing code, I love to read, golf, and spend time with my family 👪.
title: JavaScript and Accessibility: Building Thoughtful Interactions
abstract: Modern web applications require many, often complex, user interactions. Using the power of JavaScript, we can and _should_ make these interactions accessible to all users! In this talk, we'll discuss common strategies and pitfalls in building accessible web applications with JavaScript.
description:
Building accessibility into modern web applications is an often-overlooked ethical requirement. _Every_ user should be able to use our applications! With the complexity of the web in 2020, there are more and more potential pitfalls in developing accessible interactions with JavaScript frameworks.

In this talk, we'll walk through common mistakes, discuss repeatable accessibility strategies, and learn how to build accessibility testing into the development process.
notes:
👋 I’m a a software consultant specializing in frontend development. Over the past several months, I’ve also been working with a client to become WCAG AA compliant. So, I’ve developed some great, real-world, experience and would love to share with the community!

My only technical requirement is decent WiFi 😉

name: Jameson McGhee
bio: I’m a Father of 2, a Software QA Engineer, a Co-Organizer of the #KnoxQA meetup group, conference speaker, and a fierce friend. I usually spend my days fathering, QA’ing, co-organizing, conference speaking, or friending fiercely, but when not doing that, I enjoy playing board/tabletop games and pool, building things, or learning something new.
title: "Fear is the mind-killer." -Banishing the Fears of Test Automation
abstract:
One of the main goals for all manual testers is to get into test automation...but getting started can be overwhelming and terrifying. There is so much to learn and few people willing to teach you. 

My presentation is intended to help with getting started down the path to successful test automation.
description:
I started out as a manual tester who had little to no coding knowledge. I didn’t even know that test automation was a thing. Once I became acquainted with the concept, I realized how amazing it would be not spending so much time performing repetitive regression/sanity tests. However, a surprising outcome of becoming acquainted with test automation was that it scared me: There was so much to learn and several hurdles to clear.
 
Maybe you're like me. Maybe you're struggling with figuring out test automation. Maybe it's something you'd love to get into, but you find yourself putting it off because it seems too overwhelming and you’re not sure where to start. In this presentation, I'll take you down my path toward understanding test automation. I will discuss some of the challenges I faced, and share the tools/techniques I found to make some of those challenges easier to overcome. Please join me to hopefully lessen the fear of the unknown involved with getting started with test automation, and help you overcome some of those hurdles to automation success!
notes: I have been working in Quality Assurance for over 6 years and have been actively learning and working toward the goal of successful test automation engineer. This talk will be focused around the things I have learned over the course of that career.

name: Cassandra Faris
bio: Cassandra Faris is passionate about the human side of technology. She is the Community Manager at SaltStack, an event-driven security, cloud, and configuration management software product. Her career has focused on supporting tech professionals through training, community outreach, marketing, hiring, mentoring, and employee engagement. She is an international speaker who specializes in teaching people how to communicate, be more effective team members, and advance their careers.  She President of the Stir Scholarship for high school girls pursuing technology careers and President Emeritus of the DogFoodCon tech conference. She has an MBA in Organizational Leadership. When she's not busy with the tech community, she is an avid tabletop gamer, runner, and soccer fan who travels as much as possible.
title: Purposeful Personal Branding
abstract: If you have an online presence, you have a personal brand. In this talk, you'll learn how to use it to advance your career. Intentional personal branding opens the door to endless opportunities. Come see how to make that happen!
description: If you have an online presence, you have a personal brand. Most of us didn't intend to create a brand when we made our first websites and social media profiles. They were just fun ways to share our lives meet people. Now, they're networking and career growth tools. In this talk, you'll hear about people whose brands helped them become respected developers, managers, and community leaders. You'll learn how to use your online presence to advance your career. You'll also pick up best practices, common mistakes, and tips for balancing professional and personal content. Intentional personal branding opens the door to endless opportunities. Come see how to make that happen!
notes:
This talk has been presented at Cincy.Develop, CodePaLOUsa, Columbus Women in Tech Conference, DevUp, DevTalks Bucharest, Great Lakes .NET Conference, Momentum Developers Conference, Music City Tech, JavaScript & Friends Conference, Path to Agility, and THAT Conference.

It is most effective early in a conference since it provides attendees with practical tips they can apply during the event.

name: Matt Steele
bio: Matt is a front-end dev at Union Pacific Railroad.
title: Automate Everything with GitHub Actions
abstract: GitHub Actions are a new way to respond to anything that occurs on GitHub, and it's pretty amazing. You can use it to automatically run tests when you push new code, or publish to NPM. But this is just the tip of the iceberg, let's automate everything we can (and some things we probably shouldn't).
description: GitHub Actions are a new way to respond to anything that occurs on GitHub, and it's pretty amazing. You can use it to automatically run tests when you push new code, or publish to NPM if all the tests pass. But this is just the tip of the iceberg, let's automate everything we can (and some things we probably shouldn't).
notes: I gave this talk at NebraskaJS earlier this year and folks seemed to have fun!

name: Jeremy Wagner
bio: Jeremy Wagner is a web performance consultant at SiteImprove in Minnesota who writes and speakers frequently on the web and how to make it faster for everyone, everywhere.
title: Make it Boring
abstract: A talk that advocates for rebalancing our overuse of JavaScript against HTML and CSS to make the fast, accessible, and more inclusive. It acknowledges that our goal to make the web better isn't incompatible with the tools we use, and seeks to bridge the divide by offering actionable advice for all.
description:
A good case can be made for why boring is preferable to exciting in many aspects of our lives. Yet, we're reluctant to apply this sentiment to the web. Rather, we're in a relentless pursuit of the exciting in this increasingly JavaScript-centric world of web development. A pursuit that, despite our best efforts, litters the landscape of the web with excruciatingly slow and inaccessible pages. As division brews over the roles of HTML, CSS, and indeed JavaScript itself, we need to ask if it's worth making the web boring again.

But why make the web more boring? Because boring is fast, resilient, fault tolerant, and accessible. Boring is the essence of unobtrusive designs that facilitate interactions rather than hinder them. When we rely wholesale on JavaScript to build for the web, we're inevitably reinventing things—things that can hinder or even fail people in unexpected ways despite our best intentions. In this session, you'll learn why building for the web with a greater emphasis on core technologies is far from boring, but truly rewarding and exciting work that makes the web more inclusive.

name: Burton Smith
bio:
I am a senior software engineer at Bunzl North America where I work with internal business stakeholders and external customers to build digital products and tools.

I am also the creator of the Clarion style framework for design systems - projectclarion.com.

In my free time, I love spending time with my wife and three daughters, practicing martial arts, jamming on my ukulele, and learning new things (usually about software engineering).
title: UX on Training Wheels
abstract: Whether write APIs, design user interfaces, or create content, you are involved in creating a user experience. In this talk we will discuss the fundamentals of what makes a good user experience to help you build better products.
description:
User Experiences (UX) has become on of the most hyped, overused, and misunderstood terms in the community. Because of this, there a re a lot of misconceptions and misinformation floating around about it. There are many articles that claim to have shortcuts or "hacks" to good User Experiences (UX). Others provide overwhelmingly complex solutions. The truth is that UX can often be distilled down to a few key concepts from which your UX processes can be developed. Whether you have a team of 1 or 1,000, everyone should understand the basics of UX.

In this session we will discuss the core concepts of User Experience development and how you can begin applying them to your development process. At the end of it you will have actionable information on developing user-centered products as well as resources on how to further develop your UX skills.

name: Hilary Stohs-Krause
bio:
Hilary Stohs-Krause is a full-stack software developer at [Ten Forward Consulting](http://tenforward.consulting) in Madison, WI. She came to tech by way of childhood website-building (a _"Buffy the Vampire Slayer"_ fansite, to be exact). Before joining Ten Forward, she spent several years as a professional radio journalist in Lincoln, Nebraska, and attended Omaha Code School.

Hilary volunteers regularly with several tech and community organizations, and co-runs [Madison Women in Tech](http://madisonwomen.tech), a local group with more than 1,800 members. She loves board games, garlic-stuffed olives and bourbon barrel-aged stouts. She’ll read any fantasy or sci-fi she can get her hands on.

She tweets puns and intersectional feminism at [@hilarysk](http://twitter.com/hilarysk).
title: Using our powers for good: Tech and social impact
abstract: You are bursting with power to make your world better, in ways that have nothing to do with going in to the office. Learn the why’s, how’s and where’s for being a superhero of social impact in your own backyard - wherever that might be, no matter how busy you are, and no matter your specific skills.
description:
Want to make a difference in your community, but don’t know how, or feel like you don’t have time?

You’re not alone. Luckily, there are a number of ways you can use your tech-industry skills to create positive change in your community - and yourself! (Fun fact: volunteers live longer and make more money than those who don’t volunteer.)

We’ll explore the why’s, how’s, and where’s for sharing our skills, both technical and non-technical. You’ll learn more about the breadth of ways to give back, and hopefully leave feeling empowered to reach out in your own community and start making connections.
notes:
**Pitch**

This talk was born from my experiences as co-founder of "Tech & Social Impact," a locally-oriented community group that brings together nonprofit / social justice organizations and tech folks. That group was itself inspired by my experiences as co-organizer of large, more general tech meetup, whose members consistently asked questions along the lines of: 

- "Where do you like to volunteer?"
- "Have you heard of anyone needing tutors?"
- "I feel like I have skills people need, but don't know how to make it happen."

For younger tech workers, especially, skills-based volunteering is popular: 77% of millennials said they’re more likely to volunteer when they can use their specific skills or expertise to benefit a cause. From mentoring to open source to tutoring to just showing up, there are numerous ways folks with tech or tech-adjacent skills can make a difference in their communities. 

**Format**

Though some of the material is more pertinent to programmers, this talk applies to anyone who works in tech. I start with looking at why tech folks might want to get involved their community (ie: benefits such as business leads, learning new skills, building up your resume, etc.), then I look at the different hows of volunteering (ie: mentoring, speaking, tutoring, coding, etc.)

I conclude with a section about how to find where to volunteer, highlighting various national organizations and nonprofits, and then exploring methods for finding locally-oriented opportunities in attendees' own communities. There's also time for Q&A at the end. Throughout, I include examples from my own life to demonstrate the wide variety of opportunities available, showing that even accounting for attendees' individual time constraints, interests, and abilities, there's something for everyone.

name: Cameron Presley
bio:
Cameron Presley is a Lead Software Engineer for SentryOne (https://www.sentryone.com), a speaker, a Microsoft MVP, Director of Speaker Relations for CodeStock (@CodeStock) and co-organizer of FunctionalKnox (@FunctionalKnox).

Based out of Oak Ridge, Tennesee, Cameron has ten years of experience working with start-ups and large enterprise both publicly and privately held to architect solutions, implement solutions, and training developers to be better today than what they were yesterday!

In his spare time, Cameron can be found hanging out with his family, playing board games, jamming on the bass guitar, and reading books.
title: Establishing a SOLID Foundation - An Introduction to Software Design
abstract: In this presentation, we’re going to examine a set of design principles that yield easy-to-read, decoupled code referred to as SOLID. We'll start by exploring the history of SOLID, the different principles, how to spot issues, and how to resolve them.
description:
Are you tired of opening classes that have hundreds or thousands of lines of code? Do you feel that you spend too much time trying to understand how something (that should be simple) in your application works? Are you frustrated with following spaghetti-like logic through your code’s core?

In this presentation, we’re going to examine a set of design principles that yield easy-to-read, decoupled code referred to as SOLID. To start, we’ll explore the history of SOLID and establish the problems it solves. From there, we’ll dive into the different principles (Single Responsibility, Open/Closed, Liskov Substitution, Interface Segregation, and Dependency Inversion) by defining what each principle means, how to spot violations, and how to resolve them.

Intended for developers wanting to learn more about software design, by the end of the presentation, you should be able to describe what SOLID code is. In addition, you should also be able to spot trouble areas in your codebase and have the tools to undo the damage.
notes:
I've given a version of this talk at a few different conferences (see https://blog.thesoftwarementor.com/speaking-schedule) and the resources for the talk can be found at https://blog.thesoftwarementor.com/presentations/#SOLID.

Here's some of the feedback that I've received for this session in the past:
- https://twitter.com/pcameronpresley/status/1067577821894230017
- Ridiculously smooth and natural speaker, enjoyable to listen to! Very solid knowledge, passion shines through
- I especially appreciate the graphic heavy slides. Too often presenters’ resort to reading from a slide. I also enjoyed the interactive nature of the presentation. 
- This talk was the 6th highest voted session when presented at KCDC 2019
