title: Browser Automation with Python
abstract: This talk will teach you how to use Selenium and Tkinter to build a simple script with an interface to automate tasks on the browser like: extract data, input data and interact with the elements on the website. Afterwards, you should be able to build your own script to automate different tasks.
description:
There are different ways to use and find elements in these tools. We are going to show and explain how they work and how they can be used with different strategies.
 
* This talk assumes you are familiar with basic python syntax. *
 
One of the biggest changes in Selenium recently has been the inclusion of the WebDriver API. This driver gives us the power to automate tasks for the browser natively — just as a user would — allowing us to interact with and extract the elements of the browser. To achieve this goal it is necessary to do a little bit of scraping on the websites, but this is where the fun really begins. I will teach some tricks on how we can complete the same task through different ways, or different tasks through the same way. 
 
With Tkinter, we will learn how to make a simple and easy interface for our python script, making it more dynamic and general so we can use it without changing too much code.
notes:
I consider my passion, software, as something special. Why? Because I don't like to code straight from what it says in the book. I like to analyze and understand every detail so then I know how to expand what I learned to create what I want. 

Browser Automation is a topic that I personally found awesome in every aspect and if we mix it with Python it makes it even more awesome, and some people don't know that we can do Interface on the Python scripts.

In this talk, I won't just teach about these tools but, I will give them the knowledge and show them how they can grab this tool and build whatever they want.

name: Misha Bouzinier
bio: Michael (Misha) Bouzinier is an experienced software developer interested in data modeling, genetics and evolution. Born and educated in Moscow, Russia, Misha spent 10 years supervising projects in educational and biotechnology sectors. Misha went on to manage the GUI development in Parametric Technology Corporation, before joining InterSystems in 2001, where he designed and developed the software that applied various InterSystems technologies to the Lifescience domain. In 2017 he has assumed the role of is the Director of Informatics of Brigham Genomic Medicine (BGM) program. In collaboration with the Sunyaev lab he leads development of computational methods for human Mendelian genetics.
organization: Brigham Genomics Medicine, Division of Genetics, Brigham and Women's Hospital
title: Building a Community for Development of Open Source Genomics Platform
abstract: Genomics is rapidly becoming routine in our everyday life. Processing of genomic data requires more computational resources than any other task which an ordinary person is likely to come across. We are building a community to create the first community-built open-source genomic analysis platform.
description:
Introduction
===========

Whole genome sequencing (WGS) is rapidly becoming routine in clinical practice and in everyday life. Processing and interpretation of genomic data requires more computational power and storage than any other task which an ordinary person is likely to come across in their life. Hence, one can assume, it should lead to a massive software development effort. The fact is that today, most genomics platforms are either proprietary or academically developed and maintained. Being proponents of open source, we have started building a community of clinicians, researchers and professional software developers from different countries and backgrounds to create the first community-built and fully open-source genomic analysis software platform - Forome (as a Forum for Omics).  

Two important goals of Forome Genomics Platform are to support both clinical and research workflows for all flavors of genetic data and to build into the platform integrated development environment for clinical rules, providing the ability to seamlessly transform research workflows into clinical guidelines, thus speeding up the adoption of WGS into clinical practice.

Platform
========

Forome platform consists of the following major modules:

* Upstream pipeline, that ingests data from a sequencing lab and creates the aligned BAM files as well as calls common variants using standard GATK haplotype callers.
* A set of custom rare variant callers identifies extremely rare and unknown variants in a pedigree-aware way. 
* The downstream annotation pipeline injects a wide range of information related to functional analysis, population genetics, clinical knowledge, epigenetics, etc. 
* Anfisa - is a user interface for variant filtration, curation and interpretation

From a technical point of view, Forome Anfisa is based on realization that genetic analysis belongs to the same class of analytical problems as data warehousing and business intelligence, where relatively static data is processed by application of OnLine Analytical Processing (OLAP). Traditional Database Management Systems (DBMS) balance efficient modification of data with fast access, while OLAP tools specifically focus on achieving the maximum performance for data querying and information retrieval. OLAP approach is proven with other verticals like financial analysis, sales forecasting etc., but to the best of our knowledge has never been applied to the big data in genetics. 

An ETL pipeline (known as annotation pipeline to bioinformatics folks) annotates genome of the patient and their family members with the data consolidated from various public and commercial databases (provided the end user has a license to specific data). For every case it creates an OLAP cube that serves as the backend for the analysis. The modular pipeline is designed to easily plug in third-party annotation tools and functional predictors, selected or, even created, by the users. (It makes it easier that the majority of the community tools are command line Linux programs.) A typical case consists of 6 to 7 million of records (called variants), with each record having from 300 to 2000 data entries (annotations).   

From a functional perspective, filtration of variants is executed either by combining conventional conditions based on variant annotations (as in most existing variant filtration tools) or by building a decision tree that classifies the variants into several buckets. A typical decision tree consists of about 15 branching points, each point representing a complex condition on functional, clinical, sequencing quality, call quality and/or population genetics data. A rule represented as a decision tree is transparent and replicatablable, and when expressed in a scripting language can be easily included in any protocol.

Anfisa’s interface is designed for a researcher or clinician to easily view and inspect the variants at each of the branching nodes and review which variants have been put into which bucket. This way a user, who is developing a new rule can easily see their mistakes or inefficiencies and improve and optimize the rule. Application of a rule to a whole genome (about 6 million variants) typically takes about one minute and produces a set of between a couple to a few hundred variants.  The variants that are eventually put in the bucket “for further manual review” then presented to a clinical geneticist for interpretation. Anfisa includes hundreds of data points about each variant as well as links to publicly available databases for information about the variant or gene. Another important feature of Anfisa is that the user, at any time during the analysis, can query to identify any of the millions of variants in a whole genome.

Application
=========

Forome Anfisa is being actively used in three diverse and complementary projects: SEQaBOO (SEQuencing a Baby for an Optimal Outcome), Brigham Genomic Medicine (BGM)/Harvard Undiagnosed Disease Network Clinical Site and research cohort analysis of purpura fulminans (PF) patients.

SEQaBOO is a clinical research project initiated in Boston aimed at integrating high-throughput clinical-grade genomic analysis into routine newborn screening. For SEQaBOO, we have developed a filtration algorithm for the phenotype of congenital deafness. Its application typically selects 10 to 30 variants for further review from a genome. Anfisa has been applied to support a best-practice clinical variant filtration, analysis, and reporting workflow of 40 cases of suspected congenital hearing loss.

BGM uses a phenotype-agnostic approach to analyze rare disease cases refractory to clinical analysis for novel genetic mechanisms of disease. With Forome Anfisa, the search for possible causal variants is performed in two stages. The first stage applies a decision tree to discard variants that are extremely unlikely to be related to the case. The result of this stage is a set of a few hundred variants that are rare, have functional significance (e.g. missense) and fit into one of possible inheritance models. In the second step, we drill down into this set, first by applying predefined filters based on potential inheritance models: autosomal dominant, X-linked and two recessive filters - homozygous recessive and compound heterozygous. If predefined filters yield no obvious result, they can be interactively adjusted for alternative inheritance hypotheses (e.g. imprinted genes) are explored. The compound heterozygous variant caller built into Anfisa allows flexible and interactive combinations of transcript and gene specific annotations into a complex search criteria.

The PF research study uses the cohort analysis capabilities within Forome Anfisa. A population of 481 samples is divided into three cohorts: PF patients, sepsis patients without PF, and control cohort. Filters used are based on a variant being present in specific cohort and combination of its frequencies within the cohorts.

Conclusion
=========

The Forome Genomics Platform is being developed by an international community with contributors coming from the USA, Russia, UK, Austria and Canada. We are always looking for more contributors from other places. 

Scientists and engineers speak different languages, have different mentality and often incompatible work habits. Writing software to provide routine solutions for a problem that just a few years ago nobody knew how to solve adds to the challenges. These problems are especially exacerbated in a distributed team developing a new open source software. 

If you would like to tackle these challenges, if you think that what we are doing is interesting and useful, please join our community and let us continue to work together.

name: Rob Richardson
bio: Rob Richardson is a software craftsman building web properties in ASP.NET and Node, Angular and Vue. He’s a Microsoft MVP, published author, frequent speaker at conferences, user groups, and community events, and a diligent teacher and student of high quality software development. You can find this and other talks on his blog at [https://robrich.org/presentations](https://robrich.org/presentations) and follow him on twitter at [@rob_rich](https://twitter.com/rob_rich).
title: Building stateful workloads in Kubernetes
abstract: It's day 2. Kubernetes is running your sites. Now how do you migrate the data store? Join the code-focused tour through K8s's volume content. We'll craft a strategy to care for your users' data in this new container world. You can power your business on Kubernetes: stateless or stateful.
description: It's day 2. Kubernetes is running. You have your deployments and services set. Now how do you migrate the data store? Let's journey together on this code-focused tour through Persistent Volumes, Persistent Volume Claims, and StatefulSets. We'll craft and launch a strategy to care for your users' data in this new container world. You can power your business on Kubernetes: stateless or stateful.
notes: It's (relatively) easy to build stateless web properties in containers, but it's a much different beast to build data stores in Kubernetes. We'll disambiguate PV, PVC, and Stateful Sets in simple ways so you can get past this next hurdle of K8s knowledge.

name: Rob Richardson
bio: Rob Richardson is a software craftsman building web properties in ASP.NET and Node, Angular and Vue. He’s a Microsoft MVP, published author, frequent speaker at conferences, user groups, and community events, and a diligent teacher and student of high quality software development. You can find this and other talks on his blog at [https://robrich.org/presentations](https://robrich.org/presentations) and follow him on twitter at [@rob_rich](https://twitter.com/rob_rich).
title: Your Technology Your Way: Full-stack Web and Service with .NET and Node
abstract: Do you want to build full-stack with your stack? We'll build a SPA, API, and back-end service with ASP.NET and then again with Node. We'll compare and contrast, and intermix. You can use JavaScript or C# front-to-back for your next project. Use these samples to jump-start your next full-stack site.
description: Do you want to build full-stack with your stack? We'll build an ASP.NET website using Blazor and WebAPI, a back-end service using Service Worker and gRPC. Then we'll build the same website with Node using Express, Vue.js, gRPC, and PM2. Along the way we'll compare and contrast these technologies to empower you to use JavaScript or C# front-to-back for your next project. You'll leave with a functional sample in each, and a methodology to choose your next full-stack site.
notes: We review the code for an app with Blazor, gRPC, and Service Worker built in C#. Then we review an identical app built in Vue.js, Express, gRPC, and PM2. Then we mix-n-match technologies. The a-ha moment comes when attendees realize they can pick the technology that sparks joy -- even if it's different between different parts of the app.

name: Rob Richardson
bio: Rob Richardson is a software craftsman building web properties in ASP.NET and Node, Angular and Vue. He’s a Microsoft MVP, published author, frequent speaker at conferences, user groups, and community events, and a diligent teacher and student of high quality software development. You can find this and other talks on his blog at [https://robrich.org/presentations](https://robrich.org/presentations) and follow him on twitter at [@rob_rich](https://twitter.com/rob_rich).
title: Kubernetes Test Drive
abstract: Are you a Docker aficionado or are you new to the Docker ecosystem? Come see how Kubernetes (K8s) adds a mature solution for containers. We'll look at pods, deployments, and services. You'll leave with a solid understanding of the principles of K8s, and a practical set of skills and examples.
description: Are you a Docker aficionado or are you new to the Docker ecosystem? Come see how Kubernetes (K8s) adds a mature solution for running containers in production and development. We'll start with containers, layer in pods, replica sets, deployments, and services. We'll dig into minikube and kubernetes in docker desktop. You'll leave with a solid understanding of the principles of K8s, and a practical set of skills for driving this container orchestrator throughout the software development lifecycle.
notes: This talk is great for those new to containers and for those looking to move from Docker Swarm or another container orchestrator.

name: Chad Green
bio: Chad Green is a manager, software development, architect, community leader, Microsoft MVP, and most importantly a father and husband.  Chad works as the Director of Software Development fort ScholarRx developing an affordable, lifelong digital-learning platform for medical students and physicians everywhere.  Over his career spanning three decades, Chad has managed groups from 3 to 63 people, worked on projects in a wide range of markets including education, healthcare, military, government, workforce management, financial services, chemical research, and electronic commerce.  Being a big believer in giving back and wanting to ensure that there are cool events for others, Chad founded and chairs the annual Code PaLOUsa conference, organizers the Louisville .NET Meetup user group and the Monthly Tech Leader Coffee and Discussion and has helped other groups like the Louisville Tech Ladies and events like Cincy Deliver.
title: Ch-ch-ch-changes: Tracing Changes in Azure Cosmos DB
abstract: The Azure Cosmos DB change feed listens to an Azure Cosmos container for any changes and then outputs the sorted lists of documents that were changed.  In this session, you learn what the change feed is, how it works, and how you can use it to build more robust applications.
description: David Bowie might not be able to trace how time changes him, but with the Azure Cosmos DB change feed allows us to trace the changes to your data within your Cosmos database.  The Azure Cosmos DB change feed listens to an Azure Cosmos container for any changes and then outputs the sorted lists of documents that were changed.  In this session, you learn what the change feed is, how it works, and how you can use it to build more robust applications.

name: Johnie Karr
bio:
With nearly 12 years of experience, Johnie began his career building custom software for Cox Communications to facilitate communication between engineers and field employees. At Cox, he completed Leadership Academy, an elite year-long training program offered to top employees of the company and received many accolades for his customer service skills. Johnie also spent four years working for the state of Kentucky. He built and supported enterprise software for the Kentucky General Assembly. He also designed and built a universal funding application (UFA) for Kentucky Housing Corporation that gained national recognition from the National Council of State Housing Agencies in 2014, when UFA was nominated for an industry innovation award. At the International Student Exchange Program, Johnie architected and built the back-end tools for the organization’s new platform. At ScholarRx, Johnie works on the back-end and authoring tools that help the future doctors be the best they can be.

Johnie is passionate about new technologies and is particularly interested in building new enterprise and mobile applications to streamline processes. Johnie is a Six Sigma Yellow Belt and holds certifications for customer service, implementing and maintaining a SQL server 2008 database, HIPPA awareness for business associates, and HIPPA security. Johnie has been on his church's IT team since 2012 and has served as treasurer since 2013.
title: So, you want to use Entity Framework, but your DBA says no
abstract: Entity Framework has been through several iterations, yet some teams still resist.  In this talk, I'll emphasize some of the selling points for using EF (or any ORM), and  how developers can still use it in their projects, even when teams still insist on working solely with stored procedures.
description: Entity Framework has many advantages that make developing with data schemas much easier and quicker; but, some organizations, teams, and DBA’s do not want to make the jump from traditional ADO.NET. In this talk, you will learn about the key benefits of using Entity Framework, how it can make database development work easier and quicker, and how you can convince your organization, team, or DBA’s to embrace it. And when outright usage of Entity Framework is still frowned upon, you will learn how you can still use it with stored procedures, views, raw SQL queries, and even Entity Framework Migrations.

name: Sean O'Dell
bio: Sean is a Public Cloud and Developer Advocate at VMware focusing on application development and the intersection of Operations (DevOps) between Enterprise IT and AppDev teams. Sean joined the VMware Cloud Services team in early 2017 during the exploratory phase and subsequent launch of VMware Cloud Services. Sean has been with VMware for over 8 years with a minor detour to a startup; Arkin, for 14 months that was acquired by VMware. Sean spent four and half years focusing on VMware’s Cloud Management solutions during the initial build out of the vRealize Suite. Arkin; now Network Insight, is a SaaS Network Operations management platform focused on AWS, VMware NSX and Datacenter Networking solutions. Prior to joining VMware, Sean was a customer with a focus on Datacenter Security, Compliance and Enterprise Management.
title: Continuous Verification (CV) - The Missing Link to Fully Automating Your Pipeline
abstract: In this session, we will describe a practice; Continuous Verification (CV), that can reduce and potentially eliminate manual post-deployment actions in order to accelerate the pace and reliability of software delivery.
description:
Attendees will learn the reasons for this practice, see examples of operations suited to this approach, and experience a demonstration of a pipeline augmented with Continuous Verification stages.

Examples of Operations
- Policy Checks
- Vulnerability Checks
- Governance Checks
- Performance Checks
notes: Here is a shorter version of this talk that I gave with my boss at Gitlab Commit London.

name: Joe Karlsson
bio:
Joe Karlsson is a software engineer turned Developer Advocate at MongoDB. He comes from the frozen tundra of Minneapolis, Minnesota (and yes, it does get really cold here, and no, not everyone here has the accent from the movie, Fargo 😝). Joe has been primarily a Node and JavaScript engineer. He has been writing, teaching, and talking about code his entire career. Sharing what he knows and continuing to learn about programming is truly the thing he loves doing the most.
 
Joe is the co-creator of open source software, including bechdel.io, a web app that tells you if a movie script passes the Bechdel Test or not. In his free time, he is usually drinking Gin and Tonics, eating at a new restaurant, or tinkering on a new art project or open source project.
title: From SQL to NoSQL: A Gentle Introduction For Developers
abstract:
"I have heard a lot about NoSQL databases, but don't know what they are. What's the difference between NoSQL and SQL?” If you’ve asked these questions, then this is the talk for you.

In this talk, we will discuss the current NoSQL landscape and how you can take advantage of NoSQL databases.
description: When you need to model data, is your first instinct to start breaking it down into rows and columns? Mine used to be too. When you want to develop apps in a modern, agile way, NoSQL databases can be the best option. Come to this talk to learn how to take advantage of all that NoSQL databases have to offer and discover the benefits of changing your mindset from the legacy, tabular way of modeling data. We’ll compare and contrast the terms and concepts in SQL databases and MongoDB, explain the benefits of using MongoDB compared to SQL databases, and walk through data modeling basics so you feel confident as you begin using MongoDB.
notes:
Many devs are aware of NoSQL, but have a hard time retraining their brains when they come from a SQL background. This talk's goal is to help address this common sticking points for those trying to learning NoSQL databases.

Talk  Outline:

* Map terms & concepts from SQL to MongoDB
    * MongoDB stores data in Documents
    * Modelling data in MongoDB v SQL
    * Schemaless database
    * Document -> Row
    * Field -> Column
    * Collection -> Table
    * Database -> Database
    * Index -> Index
    * Embedding -> JOIN
    * $lookup (Aggregation pipeline) -> Left Outer JOIN
    * Multi-record ACID Transaction -> Multi-record ACID Transaction
* Discover the 4 humongous advantages of MongoDB
    * Scale cheaper
    * Program faster
    * Query Faster
    * Pivot Easier
* Change your mindset in 3 key ways
    * Not all documents in a collection need to have the same fields
        * Polymorphic Pattern
        * Outlier Pattern
    * Data that is accessed together should be stored together
    * Stop using transactions regularly
* Recap/Overview/Questions

I am speaking as a representative of MongoDB, but I want to clarify that the outcomes I present in this talk will be fair and balanced. My goal is to help devs understand the current landscape of NoSQL databases in 2019, not sell them MongoDB.

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/)

name: Jake Witcher
bio:
Jake Witcher is a software developer and national speaker from Cincinnati, OH. After 15 years in retail merchandising, Jake began learning JavaScript and in ten months switched careers to become a software developer. He has been building custom software for businesses in the greater Cincinnati area as a consultant for Callibrity since April of 2019.

Jake primarily works in C# but is a functional programming enthusiast and enjoys hacking on side projects written in F#. When he’s not learning about composition, combinators, and monads (oh my!) or watching Supernatural for the nth time, Jake is either working on new content for his blog or training to be a ninja with his two children.
title: Thinking Functionally with F#
abstract: Functional programming (fp) is an effective way to build software however making the mental shift can be difficult. This session introduces the basics of F# and fp by demonstrating how common problems can be solved in a functional way using techniques like piping, composition, and pattern matching.
description: Functional programming is a fun and effective way to build software however making the mental shift can be a challenge. Picking up the syntax of a new language is one thing, but how do you solve problems with immutable data structures and pure functions? This session introduces the basics of F# and functional programming by demonstrating how common problems can be solved in a functional way. Using functional techniques like piping, function composition, and pattern matching you will discover new ways of approaching familiar situations. Learning to think functionally can be a challenge, but it is worth the investment and will prove to be a welcome addition to your toolset as a programmer.
notes: You can find a list of my 2019 speaking engagements here: https://www.codefornerds.com/speaking-engagements/

name: Jeff Strauss
bio:
Jeff is a technical architect, an executive consultant, and an attorney. As a member of the Chief Digital Advisor team at World Wide Technology—and with his unique experiences that combine tech and the law—he maintains a passion for solving problems with inspired solutions, improving life and business through technology.

A dedicated member of the developer community, Jeff travels internationally to speak on both technical and business-oriented topics. He is a Microsoft MVP and serves on the board of directors for the Kansas City Developer Conference.
title: Start Me Up: Configuration and DI in ASP.NET Core
abstract: ASP.NET Core heralded the end of global.asax and web.config, replacing them with a whole new way to wire up and bootstrap our web applications. This session provides a walkthrough of the Startup and Program classes, the host and app builders, configuration, DI, and the HTTP middleware pipeline.
description:
Adoption of ASP.NET Core continues to grow in development shops around the world. The .NET community offers a nice selection of templates for getting a new project moving quickly. On the other hand, more complex applications may require you to go deeper than what comes out of the box. The configuration and dependency injection systems in ASP.NET Core are flexible and powerful, and it is worth understanding the details of how a modern web application on the framework spins up on start.

This session provides a walkthrough of the Startup and Program classes, the host and app builders, configuration, DI, and middleware. Learn how to build your own middleware providers and pipeline. Create custom extension methods to register services with your application quickly and easily. Leverage the power of ASP.NET Core to work best for you and your organization.
notes:
SELECTED PUBLISHED PRESENTATIONS:
http://jeffandjon.com/media (under the "Jeff's Videos" tab)

(This talk has been delivered, most recently in October 2019 at Techorama Netherlands, but it is not currently available in an online video.)

NOTES ON THIS SUBMISSION:
The primary objective in this session is for attendees to come away with an understanding of the ins and outs of how ASP.NET Core applications are wired together. I will talk through the starter template, explaining the pipeline and the IServiceCollection container. The talk will also then examine the configuration providers and the Options pattern, showing how the key-value pairs are aggregated from different sources into a single Configuration collection.

While the talk will not get into the deep details of how to actually build your own middleware from scratch, it will show how to inject external middleware, services, and providers into the application.

Lastly, with the recent release of ASP.NET Core 3.0, some teams may already be starting to migrate/adopt or at least will be investigating an upgrade. Therefore, I will show a handful of the changes that developers should know, with respect specifically to the Startup and Program classes and the deprecation of IWebHost and move to the "Generic" Host, comparing and contrasting against the features of version 2.x.

name: aaron ralls
bio:
Aaron is a Sr. Applications Architect with Accruent focusing on migrating applications to the cloud. Aaron is also the President of the Fort Smith Tech Users Group since April 2018. 

Aaron started as a developer and later served as a Manager of Developers, Business Analysts, Test Analysts, Vendor Managers. During his twenty plus years, Aaron has worked in banking, electric utilities, health care, transportation.

Aaron is an analytical and solution-oriented professional with expertise in guiding teams to improve efficiency by identifying the core issues. 

In his free time, Aaron enjoys music and food festivals, video games, the occasional workout, and spending time with his family.
title: Security Simplified with IdentityServer4
abstract:
OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect and SSO, Oh My! This can be hard to do on your own. 

Are you building your own security into your applications? If you are STOP!

Join me as I walk you through how to use IdentityServer4 to secure your API's, MVC applications, services, and mobile applications.
description:
In this talk, we learn about the security specifications that IdentityServer4 supports, such as OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect. We then cover some best practices for the various type of clients we use in technology solutions. We then learn how to implement and integrate with IdentityServer4 using common clients and API's.

#Intro

* What is OAuth 2.0?
* What is OpenID Connect?
* What is SSO (Single Sign-On & Single Sign-Off)?

#Review of best practices

* Authentication vs. Authorization
* Where do I get the users claims?
* How often should I check for updated Authorization claims?
* What authentication flow is right for my application?

#Demos

Live demonstration of IdentityServer4 providing Authentication for .NET Core 3.0 API. 
We will show how to configure a C# MVC client, an Azure Function, a console process, a JavaScript client, Xamrin Mobile App to access the API.
notes:
I have spent the last three years working with Azure as an Application or Cloud Architect. My recent focus has been on building long-term strategies on how to migrate existing applications to the cloud. In addition, I am a Microsoft Certified Azure Architect.

I started speaking in 2018 at local meetups (Fort Smith, AR; Little Rock, AR; Tulsa, OK) and presented at my first conference Little Rock Tech Fest 2019.

I have done this presentation for Fort Smith Tech Users Group, Little Rock .NET Users Group, and Little Rock Tech Fest 2019.

name: Maciej Treder
bio:
Senior Software Development Engineer at Akamai Technologies. Author of articles about JavaScript, NodeJS, and Angular. Founder of @ng-toolkit opensource project - set of tools for expanding existing Angular applications (https://github.com/maciejtreder/ng-toolkit). Enthusiast of web technologies especially Single Page Apps, Progressive Web Apps, microservices, and Internet of Things. Certified Java Programmer (OCJA & OCJP in Java 7 SE).

title: Asynchronous - Synchronous JavaScript. There and back again.
abstract: Callback… Callback everywhere… Asynchronous JavaScript is a pain. One day promises where introduced, they looked promising. We just moved callbacks to different place. Then ReactiveX came with Observables. But still, at some point you need to subscribe. There is a solution async-await mechanism!
description:
This session covers in-depth the asynchronous code execution and its drawbacks. As a magic solution for the callback hell I propose async-await mechanism (way of executing asynchronous code synchronously), together with best practices and real use cases. I am going to cover how promises differentiate from observables, how and when use async-await with observables.

General points of the presentation:

- Callback example -> callback hell (callback in callback and callback again)
- Promise -> promise hell (.then().then().then() etc. etc.)
- Observable -> ReactiveX library introduction - promises on steroids
- what is async/await
- Why?
- How to use?
- How to use with browser?
- Best practices and performance

name: Allen Wu
bio: Allen is a staff software engineer at Airbnb. He has extensive experience in the software industry and has worked across the tech stack including frontend, backend, and infrastructure, across roles as both an individual contributor and engineering manager, and on product and infrastructure teams. He received his bachelors degree in Computer Science from UCLA and has previously worked at Yahoo and Microsoft. Allen is currently on the Lux Guest Growth team at Airbnb and was the tech lead on a team of 12 engineers working on the Luxury Retreats migration.
title: Airbnb and Luxury Retreats, a post acquisition technical migration
abstract: Airbnb acquired Luxury Retreats in 2017. In 2019 the entirety of the Luxury Retreats business was migrated over to Airbnb's technical stack, all while maintaining business continuity. This talk will share this journey as a case study, covering technical details, challenges, and key takeaways.
description:
In 2019, Airbnb decided to migrate the entirety of the Luxury Retreats business onto the Airbnb technical stack. Post acquisition migrations are an often overlooked but absolutely critical part of acquisitions. In this talk we will go through the journey together, covering technical details, challenges, and key takeaways. The following is an outline of the presentation.


# Outline

### 1.  Why did we decide to migrate as opposed to support two stacks?
*Lessons we learned along the way that you can take away from.*

Post acquisition, Luxury Retreats operated on its own tech stack independently of Airbnb's. We began to notice the following drawbacks:

-   Difficulty of collaboration — different codebases and tools made it difficult for engineering and data science to collaborate across the two stacks
-   Large maintenance cost — maintaining two sets of software on different technical stacks created significant overhead and required two distinct sets of engineers, one for each platform
-   Inability to leverage Airbnb Platform — being on a different stack meant LR would be unable to take advantage of core platform features available on Airbnb (experimentation, internationalization, security/fraud checks, etc)

We decided that migrating over to Airbnb's tech stack would be well worth the investment and lay a strong foundation to future growth.

### 2.  What strategies did we employ to execute the migration?
*The technical complexity here was high and we had to keep the business running throughout the entire process*

Luxury Retreats is a complicated business. Behind the website and app, we also had villa management tools, salesforce instances, calendar and pricing databases, and data reporting pipelines.

The Luxury Retreats migration involved many interdependencies. This played a factor in deciding the sequencing of the various pieces that needed to migrate. In broad terms, we went with the following sequencing.

1.  Read paths
2.  Write paths

Read-only products such as the website and iOS app launched first. By doing this, we were able to keep the source of truth constant. Writes would continue to happen on the legacy side, with changes synced over from LR to Airbnb. Following that, products that impacted the write path, such as host tools to create and modify listings and agent tools to create bookings were launched. These changes would allow us to move the source of truth over to Airbnb’s infrastructure transparently to the clients.

### 3.  How did we leverage Airbnb's infrastructure to rebuild the Luxury Retreats website?
*An architecture deep dive as well as key concerns and challenges that were tackled.*

We rebuilt the entirety of the Luxury Retreats website on Airbnb's infrastructure. We decided to maintain as much design and feature parity as possible to limit the variable effects on business performance. By leveraging Airbnb's infrastructure for traffic, server side react rendering, api gateway, backend services, we were able to rebuild the entire website in a time frame of several months.
![enter image description here](https://i.imgur.com/xy99pxs.png)
Key concerns include handling inconsistencies between search and regions between the two products, and backwards incompatible differences in URL structures for region and villa detail pages.

### 4.  What did the data warehouse migration entail?
*A critical and often overlooked piece of the infrastructure.*

The data warehouse and ETL pipelines between Luxury Retreats and Airbnb were very different. Luxury Retreats used SQL Server and even had an unknown number os Excel sheets configured to have read or write access into the data warehouse.

Additionally, accounting principles and operational terminologies were different. We had to undertake innovative solutions to consolidate differences in revenue tracking.

In order to have a continuous view of the business, we had to move Luxury Retreats' historical data over to Airbnb's data warehouse, which meant mapping and migrating data fields properly.

Before and after of the data warehouse
![enter image description here](https://i.imgur.com/yPiIUvH.png)
### 5.  How did we roll out the new website?
*A technical deep dive on the website rollout and business performance confidence through AB testing.*

With a project of this magnitude with so many moving parts, it’s important to keep in mind that at the end of the day business continuity is critical. Taking the product down or negatively impacting the conversion rate would be disastrous for the business and would go against the goal of migration, which was to lay the foundation and groundwork for future work to grow the business.

It was critical to our success to quantify the guest impact of the migration. Given the seasonality of the business, the most accurate way to do this was by running an AB test of user facing products. This was challenging because it involved testing two entirely different web stacks.

The following steps demonstrate the path towards being fully on Airbnb’s web infrastructure in four phases.

1.  Copy over all DNS records from LR name server to Airbnb’s name server, and update our domain registration to point to the correct server accordingly.  
2.  Update DNS record to point to Akamai, Airbnb’s CDN provider which forwards the request to the load balancer. This step is transparent and gives us a platform upstream for both legacy and Airbnb load balancers where we can deploy business logic.  
3.  Use the CDN to send partial traffic to the Airbnb web stack. This is the phase with live experimentation.  
4.  Update CDN so that 100% of LR web traffic goes to new Airbnb web stack, and deprecate all legacy web components.

The web rollout experiment was subject to a tight timeline. Due to the migration sequencing, the web rollout was first, and any delays would block the rollout of subsequent tracks. The following describes the preparations we made ahead of going live to ensure a smooth rollout.

**Power analysis**

More data means more statistical confidence in results. Relative to Airbnb, Luxury Retreats has a lower booking volume, and has a concept of an inquiry that can mature into a booking. In order to prepare an experimentation plan, we calculated the MDEs (minimum detectable effects) of various metrics under consideration at various P values. That data gave us the ability to make an informed tradeoff between how long to run the experiment and the statistical confidence of changes in the metrics that we were evaluating.

**Target metrics**

As with any experiment, it was important to pre-define what the target metrics were - the primary indicators to consider concluding the experiment and shipping to 100%.

From our power analysis, given the lead time required for an inquiry to turn into a booking, it would not have been feasible to use bookings as a target metric for a short experiment duration.

We sought out a metric that was a leading indicator of bookings that had more reasonable MDEs. We ended up choosing “Contacts” (inquires + online bookings), which had a much more manageable MDE of detecting a 10% change within 2 weeks.

One issue with looking solely at contacts was around the quality of contacts. For example, a product change that introduces confusion may encourage more visitors to inquire, but those incremental inquiries may not lead to additional bookings; this change may actually be bad for the business. In order to address this, we introduced “High Intent Inquiries” as the second target metric that would help us quantify changes to the website. To measure intent, we created an inquiry scoring ML model that took a variety of user signals to generate a quality score. We set a predefined threshold to classify the inquiry as high intent based on signals collected at the time of submission. “High intent inquiries” had a MDE of 15% change within 2 weeks.

Ultimately we decided to use contacts and high intent inquiries as our two target metrics for the web experiment.
Funnel events

We sought to define and implement Google Analytics events for all events in the funnel across both the old and new website. This was important for two reasons:

1.  Events were required in order to build metrics for the experiment
2.  Comprehensive funnel events would allow us to course correct during the experimentation period (there would be no time to add logs and wait several days to collect more data)
    
This was challenging because the product and implementation differed in many areas; we had to use the same funnel but implement the events in a way that was consistent and meaningful.

We also built out an experimentation dashboard on Tableau that utilized the GA events and reported daily on all funnel events so we could closely track and monitor performance.

**Launch plan**

Before starting the experiment, we aligned with all stakeholders on the following plan and launch criteria.

1.  The experiment would last for 2 weeks
2.  As long as the target metrics of Contacts and High Intent Inquiries did not drop more than the predefined threshold, the statistically significantly detectable amount (P=0.05) for that time frame, we could launch to 100% the new website.

**Outcome**

When the experiment was live, we monitored the performance in terms of movements in funnel metrics on a daily basis. We shipped product changes during the experimentation phase based on funnel metrics, so the positive impact was likely to be underrepresented in the final set of cumulative data. We reported on the target metrics, their delta, and their confidence interval using a [one tailed test](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-_and_two-tailed_tests), as lifts in key metrics would not be launch blockers.

The analysis showed fluctuations on contacters, high intent contacts, and low intent contacts within low digit percentage points. Additionally, the one tailed test showed that the lower bound of the 95% confidence interval was within our predefined criteria. We believed this outcome validates our hypothesis that we successfully migrated without any impact to our users, and rolled out to 100% of users.
notes: Allen is a staff software engineer at Airbnb. He has extensive experience in the software industry and has worked across the tech stack including frontend, backend, and infrastructure, across roles as both an individual contributor and engineering manager, and on product and infrastructure teams. He received his bachelors degree in Computer Science from UCLA and has previously worked at Yahoo and Microsoft. Allen is currently on the Lux Guest Growth team at Airbnb and was the tech lead on a team of 12 engineers working on the Luxury Retreats migration.

name: Ramón Guijarro
bio: Ramón is a product-focused web engineer and all-around web lover. He enjoys building user interfaces with JavaScript and React, speaking at conferences, moving fast and learning new things (tech-related or otherwise). He also likes using JavaScript to build stuff beyond the browser and finding out about unexpected uses for the web in general. He cares about community, diversity and inclusion as well. Making up silly personal needs in order to solve them with equally silly code projects is another of his questionable virtues.
title: A love story written in JavaScript
abstract: Dating apps can feel tedious and like a waste of time. Is there a way to skip the grunt work? That's what I asked myself six months ago when I built Swipr, a tool written in JavaScript that does the swiping for you. In this talk we'll see how it works and how to built CLIs with Node along the way.
description: If you've ever used a dating app, you'll probably agree that they can feel tedious and like a waste of time: you go there every day to swipe left or right almost arbitrarily, only based on a few pictures and a scarce bio, and then hope for a match to finally get to chat with someone. Is there a way to skip the grunt work and get to the interesting part? That's what I asked myself six months ago when I built Swipr, a tool written in JavaScript that automates this process. In this talk we'll see how the project came to be, how it evolved to what it is today and all the challenges it faced. We'll also take a look at how it actually works, discussing architectural choices and learning about good tools and practices to write command line apps with Node.js along the way.
notes:
# Tentative talk outline

## The problem with dating apps

### Facts

- Most popular dating apps are about choosing people based on pictures
- Women are much more selective than men in general (*)
- There is usually a limit in the number of likes you can give

### Consequences

- Can feel arbitrary and promote superficiality
- Hurts less good-looking people, especially men (**)
- Pushes you to come back every day

### Workaround: like everybody

- Waste of time. Still requires you to go back to the app everyday.
- Waste of chances. Some of your likes will go to profiles without pictures, or empty descriptions, etc.

### How the tool helps

- Likes or passes on people based on configurable preferences. Eg, min number of pictures, min number of words in bio, like back if you've been liked before.
- Similar to the like everybody strategy, but a bit more selective and automatic (unattended)

(*) The average woman likes 12% of men on Tinder

(**) Men of average attractiveness can expect to be liked by 0.87% of women (1 for every 115), vs 20% for most attractive men

Data from [https://medium.com/@worstonlinedater/tinder-experiments-ii-guys-unless-you-are-really-hot-you-are-probably-better-off-not-wasting-your-2ddf370a6e9a](https://medium.com/@worstonlinedater/tinder-experiments-ii-guys-unless-you-are-really-hot-you-are-probably-better-off-not-wasting-your-2ddf370a6e9a)

## Origins and evolution

- Started as a browser automation script with Puppeteer, to take advantage of Tinder's webapp
- Realized the Tinder API was fairly straightforward by looking at the network requests with browser dev tools and some unofficial documentation online
- Rebuilt it as a command line tool with Node.js
- Could be turned into a website, but for recurring unattended use the server would need to store credentials with all the implications this would have
- Maybe an Electron app that sets up a background process to be run daily would work

## How it works

### Architecture

- Module that deals with API calls with different layers: network requests, authentication and token injection, response parsing and data transformation to domain models, semantic error handling.
- Module for console logging. Abstracts details away ensuring consistent message formatting by exporting semantic functions (eg, printTitle, printLike, printSuccess).
- Module for config storage, including validation.
- Module with misc utility functions.
- Main module that handles UI and user input and coordinates calls to the other ones.

### Tools and libraries
- System access: processes, commands, files
- Prompts and interaction: commander, inquirer, chalk, cli-spinner, gluegun, oclif, node-notifier
- User settings: configstore, dotenv
- Distribution: npm, pkg, update-notifier

Repository for Swipr (working proof of concept): [https://github.com/soyguijarro/swipr](https://github.com/soyguijarro/swipr)

# Speaking experience

[https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro](https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro)

name: Jasper Schulte
bio: Hacker Founder. During the day I'm principal engineer at TripAdvisor, but during the evening I build my own drones and try to do all kind of fun stuff with them.
title: Using JavaScript to hack your vacuum robot and indoor drone to battle each other
abstract: In this talk, I will show how to hack an iRobot Roomba s9+ vacuum robot and a (cheap!) Tello indoor drone to 'battle' each other. After showing how the hacking of both devices is done (so you can repeat it at home) I'll have the flone flying, and the robot driving, on stage for the actual battle.
description: The talk is comprised of three parts. In the first act, I'll show how to hack the vacuum robot and control it, in the second act I'll show how to hack the indoor drone and talk about the intricacies of controlling it in air, and in the third and final act I'll introduce a small battle game written in JavaScript that will use the vacuum robot on the ground and the indoor drone in the air to battle each other. The whole talk is JavaScript-based, so interesting for a lot of people. I'll show how to hack the devices in a very approachable way, so the audience can follow the same steps at home (if they have any one of the devices) and immediately start having fun. I will have the two devices on stage and during the battle, the drone will actually fly (and the robot vacuum drive around).
notes: The drone is not dangerous as it is very low powered and has a protective cage around the propellers. And you'll get back a neatly vacuumed stage ;)

name: William M. Riley
bio: I'm a product engineer who cares about lots of stuff, and has two great dogs 🐕🐕

abstract: At Split Infinities, I built a design system called Stellar in order to help me build wonderful and performant web experiences. Stellar has been a productivity godsend, and in this talk, I'll cover my technical strategy with Stellar.

name: Raounak Sharma
bio:
I love building businesses, and technology is my way of contributing. I have worked with start-ups to MNC's and what really excites me is the ever-changing nature of software due to market trends. Apart from the tech I have played football for clubs, trekking in cape town and a big fan of Marvel (mostly Iron man) and stand-up comedy.

* Last Conference talk [RubyFuza 2019](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=REmCO0_3EZg&list=PLI113oIao_x55gOvfDER9ocuEQD94kjjx&index=15)
title: World of CLI (command line apps) with Ruby
abstract:
Ever wonder how to handle the problem when you need to build a small solution as an add-on to a big project in a short time. Want to see how CLI apps can serve us in this situation? How CLI apps can increase your width of solving engineering problems.

Yes? Cool then, let's dive.
description:
---
## Why this talk? | Relevance

Command line applications are a very fast,  effective and powerful way to do things. And there is a time in every developer's carrier where he/she needs to **automate the things** and even want to change the automation according to the situation. And while doing these task he/she wants to build this thing in a very **short time** because this **thing is a part of a very big project**. Backend developers and system admins are usually experiencing these things more than half a year.

Backend developers also are not very much into the user interface and system admins just hate that. So for them, command line applications are like a big relief.

If you are one of them then I can explain to you how:

* **Why** a CLI app could be the best solution for that problem?
* **When** to actually take this approach?
* The **constraints** we face.
* **How** in **Ruby** we can make them.

And **my experience** of how, when, and why I made them when I faced the same issue I discussed above.
 

---
## Coverage

* **Why this talk? and why me?**: I will show you the importance of command line apps and how we can use them in our applications (maybe like an add-on with Rails).

How they can be used to increase your level as a software developer and land you on a better job.

And most important, *why you should listen to me* when you have such a great line of the speakers? If you don't like it till now, you are free to go. 

> First I want the audience to have an interest in this. After that, I will dive into the topic.

* **Architecture**: First we will look into the architecture of these CLI apps. This would help us understand how efficient they are and what they are capable of. And especially answer the **why** we should use them.

* **Work Flow & Where it fits?**: This section explains the flow of operations when you execute a command. Here we see **when** and **where** they are a good fit to implement. 

* **Creating our own with Ruby**: Yes, what is the importance of above all things, if you don't have your own personal CLI. 

In this, we will see how we can create our own CLI apps with **our favorite language Ruby**.

* **Questions**: Throw as many doubts or question you have for me. I will be more than happy to resolve those, with best of my knowledge.


---
## Timeline
Below is the timeline I have prepared for my talk of about 55 minutes:

* **5 minutes**: Why this talk and why me?
* **10 minutes**: Architecture of CLI apps
* **15 minutes**: When to use them?
* **10 minutes**: Workflow of CLI apps
* **10 minutes**: Making our CLI app in Ruby
* **2 minutes**: Questions 
* **3 minutes**: 'Growing as a software engineer'. This is a thing I want to share with the community. It's about the things we as a software engineer should do in order to grow. I have implemented them in my life and within my college life, I have seen the results. It doesn't matter at what level attendees are in their career, I am sure there are some values in this section they all can have. Just want to share this.

For more discussions catch me up at the conference.

---
## Takeaway

* A feeling of **level up** in their professional career as a software developer, as now they are ready with an idea on how to face an add-on software like problems in the **short span of time**.

* A good basic understanding of CLI apps and how to make them in Ruby.

* A fun session and in an awesome conference.
notes:
## Why me?
I recently got stuck at this point where I need to work on CLI applications in Ruby. After brainstorming with them for several days I decided to go in deep and understand them in order to work properly.

During this period I gain some knowledge which I want to share with Ruby community.

I am not a new bee, and can totally understand the importance, pressure, responsibility of being a speaker. 

In terms of audience satisfaction, you can count on me. And to have a look at my professional background you can check the following details:

* I have worked in 5 companies as a Web developer intern (Using Rails and Angular). And currently working as a co-founding team member in my startup. You can refer to my [linkedin](https://www.linkedin.com/in/raounak-sharma/) for more information.

* I have worked in fields like UI/UX (While making dashboard in Angular-JS), Backend-development (Rails-5), Browser simulation testing (selenium + Watir), making REST-full JSON API in Rails-5

* I am handling staging servers of the company which is on Elastic Beanstalk of AWS.

* Experience Letter of my [UI/UX internship](https://www.dropbox.com/s/q7f9bomwzydv3zi/Aviate_softwares.pdf?dl=0)

* Experience Letter of my [Rails Monolithic app](https://www.dropbox.com/s/uq4ae2zfxi83em0/gyandhan.jpeg?dl=0)

* Experience Letter of my [Rails Rest API](https://photos.app.goo.gl/Qp83ViprnrvIU6mq2)

### Academic
I am a **University Topper** and have studied the core of computing. Subjects include Fundamental of computing, State Machines, Networking, Database Management Systems, Operating Systems, Microprocessors, Artificial intelligence, and all related subjects.

### Hackathons
I have been a part of many **hackathons** including **regional** hackathons of various universities(Hack@DTU, Hack@NSIT and many more) in nearby cities and also **international ones like AngleHack**. One of my driving force to learn new technologies has come from there. Those sleepless nights with code have really pushed me to make the best software possible.

### Mentor
* I mentor at MentorCruise in Ruby and object-oriented programming.
* I was the coach at Rails Girls workshop held in Pune, on 21st January 2018.
* I was a coach of a team (Team Rubies (Atibhi and Prateksha)) in Rails Girls Summer of Code 2018.

### Speaker
* Gave a talk in [Deccan Ruby Conference 2018](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMg17iak2lU)
* Also speaking at [RubyFuza & Friends 2019](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DMg17iak2lU)
* Lightning talk at [RubyConf India 2018](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8MITcQNMD14)
* Also got selected to speak at RubyConf Keya 2018, but couldn't make it due to some financial problems.

name: Sachin Ohri
bio:
Sachin has over 15 years of experience in Software development and around 4 years in Azure. He is currently working as a Lead Solution Architect for Cloud with focus on Microsoft Azure. He has in-depth experience in migrating/managing Cloud based Infra and applications. 

He has experience in various technologies including Microsoft stack, open source front-end stack like Angular. He is also an author of a book "TypeScript 2.x by Example" where he teaches readers TypeScript and Angular by building an application. He has been focussing on Azure for last 4 years with specific focus on helping large enterprise migrate to Azure.
title: Managing Governance, Compliance and Standards for Enterprise using Azure Policies
abstract:
Do you have multiple teams in your Enterprise with large number of subscriptions? 
Do you want to standardize and enforce how resources are configured, how regulatory compliance are managed, cost control, security and design consistency?
If so, then Azure policies is your answer.
description:
Azure Policies help us to be compliant with the corporate standards and service level agreements. Policies help us to setup rules, restrictions, pre and post executions that allow us to keep all our Azure resources compliant with Enterprise security and standards. Polices are easily integrated with your existing ITSM tools like Service Now, JIRA, Azure DevOps
* Do you want to make sure all your resources have some standard tags which help you to manage your cost and budgets?
* Do you want to make sure that no one opens a port for Bitcoin or Ethereum or no VM should have a public IP?
* Do you have some practices which you want to enforce as preventive and some which should be detective or even want to auto-remediate if there is a violation?
* Do you want to have separate standards for different environments like Sandbox, Prod?

Azure Policies does all this. 

In this session we will deep dive into Azure policies, we will look at what Azure Policies can do and how can it help your Enterprise to move to cloud with confidence that the standard security and compliance practices are followed uniformly.
notes:
Microsoft Azure is the leading cloud providers where many large Enterprise are moving their workloads. One of the biggest concerns Enterprise's have is how would their corporate standards, costing, compliance, regulations be managed in Cloud. Azure policies tries to solve all those problems and make the move to cloud more effective.

In this session Sachin brings his learning, his experience in implementing compliance, security and standards in Enterprise based Cloud resources using native Azure services.

title: You call yourself a Senior Developer?
abstract: Once upon a time, Senior developer was the real role-model, a person that everyone looked up to, a developer that you seek for advice and wisdom. Nowadays, seniority is a synonym for large salaries and big egos.
description:
Once upon a time, Senior developer was the real role-model, a person that everyone looked up to, a developer that you seek for advice and wisdom. Nowadays, seniority is a synonym for large salaries and big egos.

Let’s have a trip down the memory lane and drift away from the money-driven mindset. Instead of that, let’s inspire you to be better developers who are fulfilled by knowledge, success, and accomplishments.

name: Ram Dayal Vaishnav
bio: Ram Dayal Vaishnav, Engineering Lead at Arcesium India, is very passionate about Open Source technologies and has been contributing to Mozilla’s projects since 2012. He is also a Mozilla Tech Speaker & a Mozilla Representative. Interested in Future Technologies, he has given talks on VR, WebAssembly & Future Technologies at various international events including FOSSASIA Singapore, MozFest London, JSFoo India and SHA HackerCamp Netherlands.
title: WebAssembly for a faster, secure & more inclusive web ecosystem
abstract: WebAssembly, the new ingredient of the web ecosystem, has got everyone's attention lately. Its because it is fast, secure & most importantly - it is making web more inclusive by inviting & welcoming other language to build the web. Lets hear more about WASM from Ram in this version of GraphQL Asia!
description:
WebAssembly, the new ingredient of the web ecosystem, has got everyone's attention lately. Its because it is fast, secure & most importantly - it is making web more inclusive by inviting and welcoming other language to build the web.
In this talk, Ram will speak about WebAssembly as a tool which was missing in the web's toolbox earlier. You may be already using awesome WebAssembly without even knowing it, so let's know it a little more and learn what's so special about it; why should you know about it (even if you might want to just continue using JS for your web applications) and where all can it be used today? Ram will also show few quick hands-on demo demystifying WebAssembly for you.

name: Ram Dayal Vaishnav
bio: Ram Dayal Vaishnav, Engineering Lead at Arcesium India, is very passionate about Open Source technologies and has been contributing to Mozilla’s projects since 2012. He is also a Mozilla Tech Speaker & a Mozilla Representative. Interested in Future Technologies, he has given talks on VR, WebAssembly & Future Technologies at various international events including FOSSASIA Singapore, MozFest London, JSFoo India and SHA HackerCamp Netherlands.
title: WebXR - Future of building the future
abstract: One of the recent updates in Virtual Reality field is the transition of WebVR into WebXR. In this session Mozilla Tech Speaker Ram will speak about how WebXR is gearing up as one of the key future technologies to build the VR enabled experience of future.
description:
We all have seen that development of Virtual Reality experiences has been doing a major makeover of the computer industry. The Web, being the most open platform, have also adopted itself well and have become a key participant for providing cool Virtual Reality experiences. One of the recent updates in this field is the transition of WebVR into WebXR. 
In this session Mozilla Tech Speaker Ram will speak about how WebXR is gearing up as one of the key future technologies to build the VR enabled experience of future.

name: info@practicalddd.com
bio:
Vijay Nair is currently a Director of Platform Engineering within Oracle’s Financial Services Global Business Unit. 

A DDD and distributed systems enthusiast, he has around 20 years of experience in architecting, building and implementing mission critical applications for the financial services industry around the world.

He is the author of the book "Practical Domain-Driven Design with Enterprise Java". He can be reached via his personal website www.practicalddd.com or via Twitter at @Fusionvj. He also runs a popular Git repository (https://github.com/practicalddd) which showcases practical DDD implementations using popular Java frameworks.
title: Implementing CQRS/Event Sourcing and Event Driven architectures in Java with the Axon framework
abstract:
The open source Axon framework is the leading Java framework for building CQRS/ES and Event Driven Microservices applications.

This session helps developers take the first steps towards utilizing the Axon Framework to build applications based on these patterns
description:
CQRS (Command Query Responsibility Segregation) is a design pattern that originates in DDD (Domain-Driven Design) and emphasizes strictly separating reads from updates in the application model. Event Sourcing is a closely related technique that stores state as a series of events as opposed to only keeping track of the latest data. While these concepts are important on their own right, they are especially important for microservices development.

In this heavily demo driven session we explore CQRS and Event Sourcing in detail using the Axon Java framework. At the end of the session you should have a good idea if CQRS and Event Sourcing are for you and why Axon helps in implementing these concepts.

Attendees get a complete project to kick start their Axon framework discovery and implementation.

name: Santosh Viswanatham
bio: Santosh is an open web philanthropist, Tech Speaker at Mozilla and a Senior Development Engineer at Pramati. He eats Vanilla JS for Breakfast and tweets at @isantoshv. Santosh is a Mozilla Rep and a Participation leader at Mozilla, loves working with a diverse group of people. He has given talks on WebVR, Cross-Platform extensions, Firefox OS in the past. For his contributions to Mozilla, His name is listed in about:credits of every shipped Firefox Browser. When he is not glued to his computer you will find him reading books, watching movies, trying not to cook badly.
title: Cross-browser add-ons with Extensions APIs
abstract: We use Ad-block, Grammarly, Containers, and a lot more other add-ons in our browser every day. How about being on the other side of the table and build one with the javascript we already knew? Let's talk about add-ons, Extension apis and build an add-on of our own with existing AI/ML models.
description:
We use an extensive number of Browser Add-ons every day. Browser add-ons help a user to personalize the browser as per our need and make the most of it. Add-ons extend, enhance and modify the functionality of the browser. How about for once, we look from the other side of the table and build one?
WebExtension APIs made it ridiculously easy for Javascript developers to build browser add-ons which work in almost all major browsers like Chrome, Firefox, Opera, etc. with no or minimal code changes.
In this session, we will be learning how to develop portable cross-browser extensions using Javascript. One can learn how to use features of browser such as Notifications, Tab capture, HTTP request handling, Toolbar buttons in an addon. This talk will also dive into the Architecture of Web Extensions, Followed by a Hands-on demo of Building an extension from scratch using Web Extension APIs.
By the end of the session, You will be able to build compelling add-ons using WebExtension APIs and also relate using existing javascript utility libraries in building WebExtensions.
By this session, I look forward to increasing the circle of browser extension developers so as to make browsers great.
notes: I have been working on WebVR and Browser add-ons from the past two years at a number of Local/International conferences including Voxxed Days, Belgrade and Mozfest, London. This talk on Browser add-ons will enable the developers who already have the knowledge of javascript to build something exciting using WebAPI's and publish them right away on multiple add-on stores. Building add-ons have been really exciting from the past two years after the emerging of cross-platform extension API's.

name: Vilva Athiban P B
bio: Vilva is a Javascript developer and GraphQL enthusiast. He works for Omio. He loves to preach interesting tech topics with humor. He also loves sharing knowledge with the community. He is on a mission to make the browser a better place to visit.
title: Build a GraphQL Client for React Apps from scratch
abstract: GraphQL is gaining popularity and many companies are already using it in production or evaluating to use it. Hence building a GraphQL Client will explain the users about GraphQL and how it works under the hood. This will enable users to get better insights and implement more performant code.
description:
GraphQL is gaining popularity and many companies are already using it in production or evaluating to use it. Hence building a GraphQL Client will explain the users about GraphQL and how it works under the hood. This will enable users to get better insights and implement more performant code for their products. 

This talk will be live coding, wherein, we get to learn the basics of GraphQL and implement them by building a Client. This GraphQL Client can be used with a React application to consume / Query data from a remote GraphQL server.
notes: Having spent more than a year using GraphQL in production and giving many talks in local meetups. I can explain their internals better with some real-time use cases.

name: Kapil Bhosale
bio:
My name is Kapil, I am a co-founder of Dtree Labs LLP, Pune. 

With almost 5 years of software development experience, I started as a technical consultant. I worked mostly on Web app developments with Ruby on Rails. 

My areas of interest include Image processing, distributed and parallel computing as well.

I love sports, trekking, travel, and food. 
Once upon a time, I was a state level boxer, it's a longs story :)
title: Why and How we created an error reporting tool - using Rack Engine and Active Support Instrumentation.
abstract:
Simple, efficient error tracking tool.
It's a Rack-based gem, with small memory footprints & built for performance.
It uses Active Support Instrumentation to capture errors & uses threads to process multiple requests simultaneously.
It's not the tool to speak about, it's the unique way we built it.
description:
#### The problem:

> The applications in finance and healthcare etc domain data privacy are a major concern. 
They also have to comply with **GDPR**, **HIPPA** etc which do not allow them to share data with third-party applications in normal circumstances. So for error tracking, suggested tools like Sentry and Rollbar were not approved.

#### Objective:
> To build an efficient error tracking tool in ruby and display them on UI mounted inside the same application.

#### Solution:
We built a gem named **Specterr** using **instrumentation API**. 

The instrumentation API provided by Active Support allows developers to provide hooks which other developers may hook into. There are several of these within the Rails framework. With this API, developers can choose to be notified when certain events occur inside their application or another piece of Ruby code.

We are leveraging these notifications to track errors. Storing them inside the DB configured by the user, not over the cloud. We are mounting **Rack-based UI** to display errors captured.

Basically, there are two parts of the gem 
 - one which captures the errors and stores it. 
 - Other is a mountable UI to display them. 
 
 We got a chance to explore following components which are generally unexplored by common rails developer: 
- The instrumentation API & Rails **PubSub architecture**
- Gem mounted with the Rack-based engine.
notes:
##### We would like to present following in the context of an open source project we created.
 
- Details of Active Support Instrumentation in Rails.
- Use cases of Active Support Instrumentation - PubSub Architecture
-  Rack engine mounting vs Rails engine mounting  
-  Insights of Rack application  
-  Our Journey of the gem - why we wanted to create it and how we did it. 

link to gem : [https://github.com/dtreelabs/specterr](https://github.com/dtreelabs/specterr)

name: Italo José
bio: Italo José is Microsoft MVP in AI category and works at Nindoo as a deep learning engineer, he's Lead of Developer Circle SP from Facebook in São Paulo. Also is a Self-driving car assistant teacher at FIAP university in the mechatronic course and win (3º) the real self-driving car global hackathon in China by Pix Moving in 2019. He contributes with the community speaking about AI, mentoring communities by the communup.tech project and writing on medium and in the IMaster (IT Forum) as a columnist.
title: RealTime exoskeleton-mapping and body segmentation  on the browser with Tensorflow.js
abstract: In this talk, we will show how we can implement a deep learning model with Tensorflow.js that makes it for us, and the best part, everything running in the browser!
description:
Are you already through in mapping your exoskeleton like Kinect and at the same time segment your body separable like your head, foot, hand and etc just by webcam?
So, in this talk, we will show how we can implement a deep learning model with Tensorflow.js that makes it for us, and the best part, everything running in the browser!
notes: I’m proposing this talk because I see only python developers working with machine learning and deep learning, it’s hard to see the machine learning job’s description asking for JS skills, the companies only ask for python developers because they don’t know that exist Tensorflow for JS and the JS developers don’t try to learn machine learning because they think that’s only for python developer, but it’s wrong! they can do that.

title: Getting the exact point where the people are looking by a picture
abstract: In this lecture, we will learn about "gaze detection", a technique that allows you to know the exact place where the people are looking inside a mono(2D RGB) picture with deep learning and how we can implement the gaze360 paper \0/
description:
Get a picture and try to know where the people are looking with computer vision, APIs, or some other technique ... you don't know how you can do it right? so this talk is for you! 
In this lecture, we will learn about "gaze detection", a technique that allows you to know the exact place where the people are looking inside a mono(2D RGB) picture with deep learning and how we can implement the gaze360 paper \0/
notes: Like my others lectures, I’m proposing this subject to show how the developers can use the deep learning academic state of the art in their projects in an easy way, the gaze360 is a nice example project that allows us to build infinite applications that can’t possible before and at the same time it isn’t hard to implement it.
