title: Consuming Python Tensorflow models in browser
abstract: We will learn how to convert a python Tensorflow model into Tensorflow.js to consume it on the Browser, Electron, React native and don't think about GDPR(General Data Protection Regulation).
description:
#### Let me makes some questions for you...
- Are you can't create train a model because the data is on the client device and the GDPRGeneral Data Protection Regulation) blocks you to use the user data?
- Are you in a React native project and can't use your realtime deep learning project because you can't run python o browser(client-side)?
- Are you in an Electron project and can't use your realtime deep learning project because you can't run python o client-side or can't install a python runtime in the user machine?

So, this talk is for you, we will learn how the Tensorflow.js works, run it on the browser, on React native, how we can train a TensorFlow Python model and convert it to TensorFlow.js and more!
notes: I'm proposing this talk because the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) will block so many companies to work with machine learning, so I want to show how the developer can train or consume models inside the user devices.

name: Bill Dinger
bio:
Bill is a Senior Technical Lead with Americas working on delivering digital solutions to our clients. Over the last 17 years Bill has worked in enterprise IT starting in the trenches on the help desk. After that, Bill spent almost a decade working in infrastructure support focusing in the Microsoft stack. Over the last 5 years Bill has been developing, architecting and leading teams of software developers. During his 16 years Bill has done everything from troubleshoot dial up connections in rural Nebraska to building the digital experiences for some of America's most well known brands.

When not working, Bill will probably be found on his bike exploring gravel roads in his hometown of Lincoln, Nebraska.
title: OWASP Top 10 Vulnerabilities & ASP.NET
abstract: In this talk we'll go over the new 2017 OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities and how they apply to ASP.NET. We'll include a demonstration of each vulnerability, the risk it poses, how to detect the attack, and how to mitigate it.
description: The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) Top 10 list are the most commonly exploited security threats found on the web today. Securing your applications & clients against them will go a long way towards mitigating any security risks and protecting your application from these threats. In this session, we'll go through each of the top 10 vulnerabilities showing you the vulnerability in action, what the impact is going to be, how to detect it and most importantly how to fix the problem. Code samples will be freely available and we'll examine the vulnerability in both MVC/WebApi & Asp.net web forms applications.
notes:
My company writes Asp.NET web applications for clients all across the world, and methods & principles of securing these applications to prevent attacks is a core function of our business. In addition, in recent years I was responsible for a number of PCI DSS level 1 secured web applications, and a few websites which are under attack by state level actors which necessitated learning about OWASP and how to translate these topics to junior and mid level developers on the project, as well as ultimately ensuring none of these attacks were present.

This talk has been given around a half dozen times before times before all across the US and internationally. A video of myself giving this talk at Build Stuff Majorca can be viewed here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j9xM3Za98ak

name: Sai Haridass
bio:
As a CTO of WebMobileZ and Lead Java Developer at various major companies, Sai honed his skills both as a Tech Wizard and as a People Leader.

His commitment to building High-Quality Software at Low Cost, makes him look beyond the Status quo to deliver value to his clients in various engagements.

He enjoys coding and developing software using Full Stack Java Technologies which include Angular 8, React, JavaScript, TypeScript, HTML5, BootStrap, Material Design, Java 11, WebServices, SQL, JPA, Hibernate, OAuth and SpringBoot.

Over his career of more than 10 years, he deployed software to various IaaS and PaaS Layers like AWS and Pivotal Cloud Foundry. At several client projects, he enabled and facilitated CI/CD mechanisms and code quality controls using Jenkins, Pipelines, GitHub, SonarQube and Jacoo.

He spearheaded various projects which had multiple technical challenges with regards to integrating clients projects with Vendor Webservices and offerings. He designed solutions and provided team and stakeholders with a clear road map on project deliverables and successfully delivered complex projects. 

He is a true believer and strict practitioner of Agile methodologies, Pair Programming, Behavior Driven Development, and Test-Driven Development. He loves fixing complex software bugs and refactoring code to use best possible Design Patterns, Algorithms, and Data Structures suitable for the task.
title: Kiss Good Bye to Backend code with AngularFire, NgRx and Firebase for Modern Web Development!
abstract: As a CTO of WebMobileZ.com and a Lead java Developer at Ford Motor Company, Sai Haridass explored various Technologies which he can leverage to roll out applications. He is an expert on AngularMaterial, AngularFire, and Firebase. He currently consults various clients on Google Technologies.
description:
After acquiring Fabric and Crashlytics in 2016 and launching Cloud Firestore in 2017; Firebase has become much stronger than ever and is positioned to become the choice of “Mobile and Web Application Development Platform” for Developers. In this presentation, I will talk about some new and exciting developments in the Firebase, Angular Material, AngularFire, and NgRx. I will demonstrate the following topics through some practical use cases.
1.	Mat-Datepicker and Mat-table – An explanation of how to use the components in your project
2.	Observer pattern using RxJs – A deep dive into Observer Design pattern using RxJs
3.	Cloud-Firestore – A look into Steps needed to setup Cloud FireStore for your project
4.	Authentication – Explore how to Authenticate users simply and securely 
5.	AngularFire – An example of how to using AngularFireStore and AngularFireAuth can reduce application complexity and boost productivity
6.	Hosting – show you how easy it is to move your code to Firebase hosting from CLI
7.	NgRx – Explain how State Management works using an Analogy with American Democracy.
notes: Sai Haridass worked at Ford Motor company and helped the client to rewrite critical applications from Visual Basic and JSF to Angular 4 and beyond. As a team lead he is in charge of researching various pro’s and con’s of multiple technologies and drive the team to the successful completion of the project.

name: Scott Sauber
bio: I'm a software consultant at Lean TECHniques Inc. where I do web development using ASP.NET Core and JavaScript. My second dev passion behind web development is building DevOps pipelines and automating everything automatable. You can find me on Twitter @scottsauber or on my blog at scottsauber.com.
title: Let's Build a Blazor App
abstract: So you've seen the basics of Blazor, the C# WebAssembly SPA framework. In this session, we'll go deeper with forms, validation, authorization, JS interop, dependency injection, state management, creating a component library, and more. Let's go beyond Hello World and build something real.
description: So you've seen the basics of Blazor, the new WebAssembly C# SPA framework from Microsoft. You've seen the counter demos, the ToDo demos, and the weather forecast demos. That's all well and good, but how does Blazor hold up in a real application? In this session, we're going to build a real Blazor application with best practices in mind for forms, validation, authorization, JavaScript interop, dependency injection, state management, creating a common component library, and more. If you're interested in going beyond hello world with Blazor, you won't want to miss this session.
notes: I've spoken at KCDC, NDC Minnesota, and a few local groups about Blazor.  I'm also the author of Blazor Snippets for VS Code: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ScottSauber.blazorsnippets, and in the middle of discussions with Apress for writing a Blazor book.  So I'd love to give another talk about Blazor, and I haven't given this particular one yet.

title: The 2019 State of the NoSQL Union Address
abstract: In this talk, we will discuss the current state of the NoSQL databases as they compare and contrast document databases, key-value databases, column-oriented databases and graph databases with specific use cases and industry examples.
description: Over the last few years we have seen the rise of a new type of databases, known as NoSQL databases, that are challenging the dominance of legacy tabular databases. However, the sheer number of NoSQL databases available can be overwhelming. What are the current contenders? When should they be used, and more importantly, when should they NOT be used? In this talk, we will discuss the current state of the NoSQL databases as they compare and contrast document databases, key-value databases, column-oriented databases and graph databases with specific use cases and industry examples.
notes:
I am speaking as a representative of MongoDB, but I want to clarify that the outcomes I present in this talk will be fair and balanced. My goal is to help devs understand the current landscape of NoSQL databases in 2019, not sell them MongoDB.

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/).

title: Break it Down: An Introduction to Database Partitioning
abstract: Did you know that for large data sets, or apps with very high query throughput, simply replicating data is not enough? This talk cover a broad overview of how partitioning is being done today.
description: Did you know that for large data sets, or apps with very high query throughput, simply replicating data is not enough? For these applications, we must break up the data in partitions (also known as sharding). There are several ways that top companies are achieving this today. In this talk, we will look at different approaches for partitioning large data sets and how indexing affects our partitions. We will also talk about how to rebalance clusters and best practices for routing requests to the correct partitions. Come to this talk if you are interested in getting a broad overview of how partitioning is being done today.
notes:
Presentation Content and Structure Outline:

* Partitioning of Key-Value data
  * Partitioning by range
  * Partitioning by Hash of a key
  * Relieving Hot Spots
* Partitioning Documents
  * Secondary indexes 
  * Partitioning by term
* Rebalancing Partitions
  * Strategies for rebalancing
* Request Routing
    * Parallelizing query execution by partitions
* Summary

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/).

title: A Gentle Introduction to Building Serverless Apps with MongoDB Stitch
abstract: In this session, we will introduce Serverless computing in a friendly and approachable way. We will discuss the pros and cons of using a Serverless platform. We will then build an app together from scratch using MongoDB Stitch.
description:
Do you want to crank out features the business wants, or spend a lot of time writing code and capacity planning for authentication, authorization, and complicated data access? Of course we all know the answer. 

In this session will begin a beginner friendly introduction to Serverless computing. We will then do a quick overview of the MongoDB ecosystem in the 3 major cloud providers for rapid application building. Then we will walk through a guided tutorial of how to use the MongoDB Stitch serverless platform to build your elastically scalable microservices based app within minutes, complete with end-user authentication and access rules, on a fully managed MongoDB cluster in your favorite cloud platform.
notes:
Talk Outline:

* Introduction to Serverless
  * Pros and Cons
  * Why it's popular
* Quick overview of the MongoDB ecosystem in the 3 major cloud providers
* Live coding Serverless App

My blog covering the app being built during this talk can be found here: [https://www.joekarlsson.com/2019/04/a-gentle-introduction-to-setting-up-a-react-and-mongodb-stitch-app-from-scratch-in-10-minutes/](https://www.joekarlsson.com/2019/04/a-gentle-introduction-to-setting-up-a-react-and-mongodb-stitch-app-from-scratch-in-10-minutes/)

You can find the source code for this tutorial here: [https://github.com/JoeKarlsson/mongodb-stitch-todo-tutorial](https://github.com/JoeKarlsson/mongodb-stitch-todo-tutorial)

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/)

title: How Hasura can easily expose your PostgreSQL as GraphQL

name: Chris DeMars
bio: Chris DeMars is a front end developer first, UX architect always, from Detroit, Michigan now living in Denver, Colorado. For his community contributions, he holds awards as a Microsoft MVP in developer technologies and Google Developer Expert in web technologies. He is also an international speaker and former organizer for Vuetroit and former co-organizer of the Ann Arbor Accessibility Group. Chris loves coming up with solutions for enterprise applications, which include modular CSS architectures, performance, and advocating for web accessibility. When he is not working on making the web great and inclusive you can find him writing blog posts, recording episodes of his podcast, Tales From The Script, or watching horror movies.
title: Run to the light Carol Anne: Auditing with Lighthouse
abstract: Have you heard about Lighthouse? Are you afraid to go into the light like Carol Anne in Poltergeist? Don't be afraid because Lighthouse is an awesome tool to achieve your web experience goals.
description: Have you heard about Lighthouse? Are you afraid to go into the light like Carol Anne in Poltergeist? Don't be afraid because Lighthouse is an awesome tool to achieve your web experience goals. You can do a bunch of awesome things in Lighthouse like running SEO audits, front-end performance audits, and my favorite, accessibility audits. This talk will explore reasons that audits and testing are necessary, and walk through different types of audits you can run. The end goal is analyzing the results and taking steps to achieve your web experience goals.
notes:
I spoke at 22 events around the world in 2018, ~30 in total, one workshop, not including meetups and this year I will have spoken at 15 events in 2019 ranging from the U.S., Canada, England, Romania, and Bulgaria.

title: Hacking the Human Perception
abstract: Hacking you say? Yes, I d, but this type of hacking involves how we as developers, create the illusion of fast load times for our Web applications. This talk will focus on ways we can make things appear to be faster than they are and ways to avoid having to play Houdini entirely.
description: Hacking you say? Yes, I do, but this type of hacking has nothing to do with hooking in Matrix style or surfing through The Gibson at Ellingson Mineral Company. Nope, this type of hacking involves how we as developers, create the illusion of fast load times for our Web applications. Performance is gaining much visibility in the industry and catering to the needs of the user, there are many things we can do to facilitate that need. This talk will focus on ways we can make things appear to be faster than they are and ways to avoid having to play Houdini entirely.
notes:

title: Focusing on Focus
abstract: When we think of CSS and Accessibility, what comes to mind? Is :focus given that much thought since browser's style these by default? Often, focus outlines are turned off in CSS to meet non-inclusive design standards, but this causes problems for keyboard users.
description:
When we think of CSS and Accessibility, what comes to mind? Is it adding alt attributes to image tags? How about color contrast? Is :focus given that much thought since browser's style these by default? Often, focus outlines are turned off in CSS to meet non-inclusive design standards, but this causes problems for keyboard users. How can we make the web a more inclusive place while maintaining design intent?.

As we build more and more things on the web, we must do our part in building awesome, accessible user experiences. Except native default browser styling of the :focus pseudo class is rather blah, don't you think? There has to be a better way to add some pizzazz to elements when users navigate without a mouse. In this talk, I will demo numerous ways to provide custom focus styles despite known limitations in the web platform. For users with disabilities, it's imperative that visual design finds a way to meet in the middle.
notes:
I spoke at 22 events around the world in 2018, ~30 in total, one workshop, not including meetups and this year I will have spoken at 15 events in 2019 ranging from the U.S., Canada, England, Romania, and Bulgaria.

bio: Ram,Developer/Individual Contributor with 10 years of Product development Experience. Previously worked for startup companies like  ,CallidusCloud (SAP Company), Konylabs. Loves Automation, Linux, openSource
title: Scriptway  - Version control for your scripts
abstract: Enter Scriptway. In Scriptway, we found a solution that empowers our developers to easily configure a development environment locally that is used for installation/configuration of software on local docker containers and production servers.
description:
Early 2015, we were building a Single sign-on (SSO) solution to vast majority of our customers from scratch. Our previous datacenter deployments used to take roughly 3~4 hours(scripts+manual) on a maintenance window over the weekend.

We had many different pieces of clustered third party software . This includes but is not limited to OpenDJ,OpenAM, Vertica, and Hadoop. All of these pieces of software manage their configuration via some sort of internal database. Not necessarily a SQL database, but a database none the less. We would like to have a uniform mechanism for managing the cluster wide configuration of these various systems that takes care of some of the common problems of the idempotentcy of running a configuration script and additive configurations after a system is already in production so that individual developers no longer need to bear that cognitive load. This will reduce the number of issues that we have during deployments and reduce the amount of time it takes for developers and DevOps to write new configurations. This system should also support the files being used to configure a system being small and modular to enhance readability and maintainability.

Enter Scriptway. In Scriptway, we found a solution that empowers our developers to easily configure a development environment locally that is used for installation/configuration of software on local docker containers and production servers.

Scriptway maintains a schema is agnostic of the system that it is in. It should be the same whether version metadata info is being stored on the local file system, relational database, LDAP, etc. Version metadata is recorded when a script is run. If the version metadata file, table, ldap schema, etc doesn't exist already, it should be created automatically by the this tool.


Session Outline:

In this session, we’ll discuss . We’ll cover:

* A quick history of our deployment challenges and what led us to Scriptway.
* The benefits of our new deployment approach — easy to Setup and minimal investment
* How we combine Scriptway along with Docker, Ansible  and the Jfrog products like Artifactory for more streamlined continuous integration and deployment

name: Miguel Tannous
bio:

title: Threads: Piece of Cake!
abstract: Imagine been able to exercise at work. isn’t it great? Well, this is something you could do with Threads, but instead of yourself is the software that you’re writing. Threads gives you the ability to execute more than one process at the same time. Opening a door to a new world of possibilities.
description:
Avoiding the use of threads is more common than what you would think. This is Because at first sight they look more complex than what they really are, but for your luck Python makes them manageable and very straight forward.

This talk assumes you are familiar with basic python syntax. *
On this talk you will learn how to manage threads set them up to use them strategically to simplify and speed up your program. I will show you all the information that they provide and how they relate to the process of your program, as well as how to create threads and wait for them to finish. I will also show you some common cases like race condition (and how to avoid them) and how to use a ThreadPoolExecutor
notes:
I consider my passion, software, as something special. Why? Because I don’t like to code straight from what it says in the book. I like to analyze and understand every detail so then I know how to expand what I learned to create what I want.

Threads is a topic that I honestly avoid for a long time I preferred to take the long road, simply because at first glance they seemed more complex than they really are. Until one day I decided to face the big boss and the funniest thing is that I found one of the best tools ever.

In this talk, I won’t just teach about these tools but, I will give them the knowledge and show them how they can grab this tool and build whatever they want.

name: Rafał Leszko
bio: Cloud software engineer at Hazelcast, author of the book "Continuous Delivery with Docker and Jenkins", trainer, and conference speaker. He specializes in Java development, Cloud environments, and Continuous Delivery. Former employee in a number of companies and scientific organizations: Google, CERN, AGH University, and more.
title: Where is my cache? Architectural patterns for caching microservices
abstract: Everybody knows that we need a cache, but where exactly to place it? Inside your application or as a layer in front of it? In the era of Cloud and Microservices these questions get even more complicated. In this session, I'll present different architectural patterns for distributed caching.
description:
Everybody knows that we need a cache, but where exactly to place it? Inside your application or as a layer in front of it? In the container or outside the container? In the era of Cloud Native and Microservices these questions get even more complicated. In this session I'll present different architectural patterns for distributed caching: Embedded, Client-Server, (Kubernetes) Sidecar, and Reverse HTTP Proxy Caching.

In this session you'll learn:
- What are the design options for including the caching layer
- How to apply caching layer in Istio (and Service Mesh in general)
- How to use distributed HTTP caching without updating your microservices
- Common pitfalls when setting up caching for your system

name: Rafał Leszko
bio: Cloud software engineer at Hazelcast, author of the book "Continuous Delivery with Docker and Jenkins", trainer, and conference speaker. He specializes in Java development, Cloud environments, and Continuous Delivery. Former employee in a number of companies and scientific organizations: Google, CERN, AGH University, and more.
title: 5 Levels of High Availability: from Multi-instance to Hybrid Cloud
abstract: Does running your application on multiple machines mean it's highly available? Technically yes, but the term HA is already more than that. Take Kubernetes installation, it's not considered HA unless your master nodes are in different availability zones, not only on different machines.
description:
Does running your application on multiple machines mean it's highly available? Technically yes, but the term HA is already more than that. Take Kubernetes installation, if you install it on AWS, it's not considered HA unless your master nodes are in different availability zones, not only on different machines. And actually, there is much more on that topic.

In this session I'll present 5 high availability levels:
1. Multi instance
2. Multi zone
3. Multi region
4. Multi cloud
5. Hybrid cloud

I'll discuss real-life use cases we experienced while developing Hazelcast and present examples of the related technical features you may need: in-memory partition backups, zone aware partition groups, WAN replication.

In this session you'll learn:
- Why Kubernetes can be deployed in multiple zones but never in multiple regions?
- What options you have while designing for high availability (for both Cloud and On-premise infrastructures)?
- What are the trade-offs when choosing between high availability and strict consistency?
- What are the best practices for deploying consistent systems in Hybrid Cloud?

name: Italo José
bio: Italo José is Microsoft MVP in AI category and works at Nindoo as a deep learning engineer, he's Lead of Developer Circle SP from Facebook in São Paulo. Also is a Self-driving car assistant teacher at FIAP university in the mechatronic course and win (3º) the real self-driving car global hackathon in China by Pix Moving in 2019. He contributes with the community speaking about AI, mentoring communities by the communup.tech project and writing on medium and in the IMaster (IT Forum) as a columnist.
title: Improving your training time with a distributed training
abstract: This talk is about how we can distribute in clusters with several workers training at the same time to improve your training time.
description:
**Have you ever asked yourself**: How can I improve my training?
**You probably thought in solutions like**:  I guess I can increase the batch size or use a different optimizer...
This talk is about how we can distribute in clusters with several workers training at the same time to improve your training time \0/
notes: I'm proposing this talk because many of machine learning engineers don't know so much about infrastructure so they try optimize your "one node" algorithm and spent so much time with this to get a minimal result, with parallel distribution, they can optimize the machine learning train process without create a new algorithm.

title: Deep learning easy peasy with javascript
abstract: We will learn how the Tensorflow.js works, run machine learning on the browser, on React native, how we can train a TensorFlow Python model and convert it to TensorFlow.js and more!
description:
## Deep learning easy peasy with javascript

#### Let me makes some questions for you...
- Are you interested in machine learning and deep learning but don't know Python?  
- Are you are a Python developer and can't create a client-side project?
- Are you a React Native developer and can't use the Tensorflow because "it's for python developers"?

So, this talk is for you, we will learn how the Tensorflow.js works, run it on the browser, on React native, how we can train a TensorFlow Python model and convert it to TensorFlow.js and more!
notes: I'm proposing this talk because I see only python developers working with machine learning and deep learning, it's hard to see the machine learning job's description asking for JS skills, the companies only ask for python developers because they don't know that exist Tensorflow for JS and the JS developers don't try to learn machine learning because they think that's only for python developer, but it's wrong! they can do that.

title: Scraping Data from Websites
abstract: In this talk I am going to show you how to scrape data from websites using the module BeautifulSoup. This talk assumes you know some basic python syntax and data modeling tools. After this talk you should be able to parse the data on a website and store whatever you need.
description: There are different ways that we can scrape data from a website, throughout the process we will take care not to overburden the website and not scrape anything forbidden by the web server. We are going to use a public library for python called "Beautiful Soup", this is a really good tool when we want to take some information from a site. With this we also are going to mention how can we store this data into a CSV and Json file.
notes:
I have been working in this topic for a while by now and I found it interesting and fun because is one of the ways that you can actually mix logic and the python script in a way that you can go through a website and find what you want. 

I worked in the project of Code for Orlando "Road Closure", scraping the data into a CSV and Json file for the events, dates and places where the closure will be having on mind that the page is not structure in its best way when is about code. That was what I liked more, it was a really fun challenge to accomplish.

With all that I mention before I can add that I feel really confident with the topic prepared to answer any unexpected question.

name: Jamie Wright
bio: Jamie Wright is a maker of internet things with a love/hate relationship for Redbull™, standing desks, and paintball guns. He has a love only relationship with teaching, learning, and building bots. Jamie runs Tatsu, a software bot that helps teams save time by performing standup meetings over Slack.
title: Introducing Juvet: Building Bots in Elixir
abstract: Designing chatbots will soon be an essential skill that all developers should know. Chat will at the very least an extension of the existing services their apps provide or the sole platform and at the most, the sole way users interact with our applications.
description:
There is another massive shift happening with how we interact with companies through software. Users feel comfortable naturally talking with their applications through chat bots. Chat is the next generation of the user interface.

Companies like Slack, Facebook, WhatsApp, and WeChat have some of the most popular apps in the world and they are all betting on a messaging interface.

Elixir is the perfect language and ecosystem for building bots and for conversational interfaces. In this session, we will see how we can build scalable, realtime web applications (or “bots”) using a new library Juvet and the Slack API. We will see what a good bot architecture looks like and how we can integrate with existing artificial intelligence services to make our bots smarter.
notes:
The theme of the talk is around chatbots, specifically why they are important in software development, what makes a good chatbot in terms of UI considerations, design, and architecture.

For the other half of the talk, I would like to introduce a new OSS project that allows developers to easily build bots in Elixir. We will talk about why we should be building bots in Elixir and reviewing key implementations for connecting your bot, chat, conversations, and natural language processing.

name: Ekansh Gupta
bio:
# Introduce Yourself

I am Ekansh Gupta (@eKuG, the reason behind this username is ‘eku’ is my nickname and ‘G’ is the initial of my surname), currently pursuing **engineering in Electrical branch from Delhi Technological University** (DTU) 2nd year, Delhi. Apart from this, I have various hobbies, for example, I love to swim, in social aspects my love for anime is unparallel and in my professional career I love shaping young minds has been much interest to me. My story starts way back when I started Grade 11, students in India mostly choose what they have to do in life during that year. When I started grade 11, I made my mind pursue engineering with Computer Science but wasn’t able due unforeseeable circumstances and restrictions which hampered my understanding of the syntax and programming languages that were new to me where everyone else was way ahead. Due to the competitive environment in my University, Guidance and mentors were very scarce. This became my motive in building a healthy technical environment.

# Community Definition

Community for me involves an aggregate of diverse minds coming together to share ideas, struggles, and resources in the spirit of collaboration. Community can be formed on the basis of community sentiment. It is extremely essential. It implies ‘a feeling of belonging together.” It is a ‘we-feeling’ among the members of a community. Because of this feeling, humans unleash their most valuable resources: creativity, imagination, and original thinking and makes them capable of thinking about others rather than just take actions out of self-interest. 

With this in mind and some help from my seniors and friends, we were able to establish a student club known as *Android Techies* collecting likeminded people to develop and mentor students who were majorly associated and/or interested in Android. After completing a couple of projects in the industry, we felt that the need of other technical domains  such as ML, iOS, Game Dev, etc were also catching up and was in quite a lot of demand thereby expanding ourselves from Android to Open Source Development in all major programming languages and Competitive Programming rebranding ourselves as *Software Developers – DTU (SD-DTU)* becoming an official society recognised by college administration. 

Having attended various technical conferences, events, and hackathons, our team got exposure to tech environment. We observed that the lack of a developing community has hindered the growth of various students across uncountable universities which paved our path for further expansion of our student-led organisation. SD-DTU was further expanded and renamed to *International Organisation of Software Developers (IOSD)* which we got registered to the Government of India. Due to the lack of guidance in various colleges, IOSD established student chapters at all the major colleges in and around Delhi, NCR. Every college chapter name is prefixed by IOSD. Leading the student chapters are the core team and its chapter head, and every chapter is officially registered and recognized by the university administration of where it has been established as a technical society of the college. For newbie developers, collaborating on open source projects is the fastest way to learn – it’s like labs for tutorials. For senior developers, contributing to and collaborating on open source help sate the desire to build cool things that matter, along with building up bragging rights in the tech community. We at IOSD are completing 4 years together with around 5000+ connected students pan India and I feel very proud to be a part of this wonderful organisation. Having started with 4-6 members, growing to where we are now, giving us all the opportunity to interact with a very vast and diverse crowd and shaped us to embark on any challenge that comes in our way.

# What are your community's shared struggles?
 
IOSD has always been focused to bridge the gap between the less and more privileged people which may include either educational level, monetary level or diversity. Due the lack of proper guidance for projects and collaborative learning, we initiated many special interest groups (SIGs) which can offer these resources in addition to developing skillset for jobs and placements. Our aim is the equip everyone, regardless of their major, with technical skills to increase their job prospects. IOSD’s Core Value include:
* Education
* Perseverance
* Innovation
* Collaboration
* Creativity

# What is the mission of your community?

We at IOSD have always focussed our resources for the upliftment of technical expertise amongst the community. To do so, SIGs are conducted both online and offline to make the students aware of rising technologies and world of Open Source. I have been in this community for about 4 years now and the kind of projects for the upliftment of society are unparalleled. **Projects ranging from those from Delhi and Arunachal Pradesh Police to United Nations, from college websites to full-fledged commercial websites and app deployments**, my journey with IOSD has been that of a pretty exciting yet fulfilling rollercoaster. Apart from Projects, *India’s biggest student run hackathon (HackDTU) was organised by IOSD at our college with the help of 400+ students from all over the country pooling the resources combining a cash prize of over 2.5 Lakhs for the winner. It was by far the epicentre of programming fuelled by coffee and energy drinks promoting the presence of open source as the core of IOSD.*

# What do members look to get from your community?

With over 5000 members in just under 4 years of inception, communication has been very pivotal to our organisation. WhatsApp groups are made every year of graduation wise. Use of Slack and Gitter is very much promoted. But as we all know, how so ever the platform might be advanced, a student always gets inspirations from seniors when talking face to face or over call which is why, we at IOSD are always available to the organisation whatever the time/day it might be. 

# Future-proofing your community

Due to the exponential growth of IOSD over the years, from last year we had decided to set up a base of all operations which can be termed as an HQ for centralised operations from where all major decisions are taken. The office also acts as a place for nurturing all interns who are unable to work from their home or college as a result of any pressure. The control over every student chapter is then decentralised to the core council of that college which is usually handled by the Pre-final years and sophomores. As the year progresses, students are monitored on the basis of their contributions in various domains not only technical development but overall holistic development. The freshers thereafter are given opportunity to take part and control the organisation and the college level. The organisation runs on a model of scalar chain. This way, the existence of monopoly and monotonous behaviour is rarely present and to the surface. 

Although I must tell you that the journey has not been easy. I have had my fair share of setbacks and failures. But in the end, these are the situations which make you stronger and help you succeed.

So, if there is any takeaway from this, it is to do what challenges your mind. Always be open to learn new skills and improve your abilities. This is the one and only way to grow as a person.

I would like to conclude with the wise words of Ralph Waldo Emerson.
 >Always do what you are afraid to do


Microsoft Student Partner | Facilitator at Mozilla | International Organisation of Software Developers | Data Science and Machine Learning Enthusiast
title: Hacking Web Literacy in an Hour (HackLiteracy)
abstract: Algorithms used by various companies to track down user data and give recommendations(Netflix) and advertisements accordingly. The use of cookies and how to implement them in programs will be displayed. Understanding the use of Python for Flask/Django for backend and data representation
description: Web Literacy refers to everyone having the skills to read, write and participate in the digital world. In order for people to understand how to shape the Web – or even how to keep themselves safe online, or make a living with the Internet – there is a growing need to make sure everyone has the skills they need for healthy Internet citizenship. It needs to be realized that people who grew up with access to the Internet don’t automatically develop strong web literacy skills. We should resist the deepening of divides between the few who know how the technology works, and a majority who do not. We need everyone to recognize that Web literacy is more than coding. Web literacy is more than coding. Governments, educators and parents need to be champions for Web literacy and foster creative opportunities for young people to develop these skills. Technology Companies also need Web Literacy to engage with people.
notes:
Basic Algorithms for Machine Learning (10 Mins) 
The use of Cookies and its implementation (10Mins) 
Overview of Recommendation system by large corporations (10 Mins) 
Using Django/Flask for Backend (10Mins) 
How to become a 10x Developer (5 Mins)

I have built a community of more than 5000 students around the globe to learn, develop and collaborate around the idea of software development using Python and other languages. For newbie developers, collaborating on open source projects is the fastest way to learn – it’s like labs for tutorials. For senior developers, contributing to and collaborating on open source help sate the desire to build cool things that matter. 
Being with the students and mentoring them along the way has been my story from the sophomore year of my study in engineering and now I'm here with the support of a large community behind me believing in me.

Apart from this, I am going to give this presentation at the upcoming MozFest'19 in London organized by Mozilla and the links to the talk will be updated as soon as possible.

name: PJ Hagerty
bio: Developer, writer, speaker, musician, and founder of DevRelate.io, PJ is known to travel the world speaking about programming and the way people think and interact.  He is also known for wearing hats.
title: Pop Songs and Programming for Fun and Profit
abstract:
Ever wonder what it takes to live in the world of an open source developer? What if everything you can learn comes from the world of pop songs?

We can learn a lot of from music, but in this talk, let's listen and see how we can be better developers.
description:
The idea here is to convey ideas on how to get into development and stay as a developer using the tunes and titles from popular music. It's a fun talk where learning how to be a better person leads to being a better dev.

Through a series of pop songs we’ll look at what it’s like to:

- Start out on your own as a programmer - not sure where to go or to get involved in open source

- Work on a team dedicated to Open Source in the crazy world of SV/SF

- Open Source at a big blue company, and how large corporations view Open Source

- Sharing your knowledge with the next line of new folks looking to get in on OSS

- Going out on your own - giving a conference talk - being the expert and sharing what you know
notes: This talk requires audio

name: Jake Witcher
bio:
Jake Witcher is a software developer and national speaker from Cincinnati, OH. After 15 years in retail merchandising, Jake began learning JavaScript and in ten months switched careers to become a software developer. He has been building custom software for businesses in the greater Cincinnati area as a consultant for Callibrity since April of 2019.

Jake primarily works in C# but is a functional programming enthusiast and enjoys hacking on side projects written in F#. When he’s not learning about composition, combinators, and monads (oh my!) or watching Supernatural for the nth time, Jake is either working on new content for his blog or training to be a ninja with his two children.
title: Functional Parsing with FParsec
abstract: Parser combinators are an alternate means of parsing data and you can take advantage of this technique in F# with a library called FParsec. Using functional programming techniques like piping and composition, parser combinators allow you to write parsers quickly, easily, and in a readable way.
description: Parsing is a great tool for collecting metadata and automating processes however using regular expressions and tracking string indices to parse the information you need can get complicated. Parser combinators are an alternate means of parsing data and you can take advantage of this technique in F# with a library called FParsec. Using functional programming techniques like piping and composition, parser combinators allow you to write parsers quickly, easily, and in a readable way. This session offers an introduction to both F# and FParsec, along with the functional programming concepts required to get started with parser combinators. Building on this foundation, you will learn how to write a simple programming language parser using FParsec.
notes: You can find a list of my 2019 speaking engagements here: https://www.codefornerds.com/speaking-engagements/ and an introductory post on the subject of parser combinators and FParsec here: https://www.codefornerds.com/better-parsing-with-fsharp-and-fparsec-getting-started/

name: Dana Scheider
bio: Dana Scheider is a member of the Cucumber core team. Hailing from Portland, Oregon, she currently lives in Melbourne, Australia, where she works as a Ruby on Rails developer for Envato. She is particularly interested in testing, behaviour-driven development, REST API design, and improving processes within engineering organisations. Dana's extracurricular interests include theoretical mathematics, opera, and shooting pool. An in-demand speaker, notable conference appearances include SwanseaCon, CukeUp! London, Full Stack Toronto, and RubyConf Colombia.
title: Managing Executive Function Deficits in the Workplace
abstract: Executive function deficits are common, but poorly understood, conditions affecting executive brain function. This talk explains what executive dysfunction is, how it affects individuals and teams, and how to mitigate its effects.
description: Executive function deficits are common among individuals with mental illness and those on the autism spectrum, as well as those who have suffered traumatic brain injuries. Yet even those who suffer from these poorly understood cognitive conditions are often unaware they exist. Consequently, sufferers and those around them often attribute their problems to laziness and other character flaws rather than to a medical condition. In this talk, I explain what executive dysfunction is, how it can affect individuals and teams, and how to help individuals suffering from this type of condition be happier and more productive at work.
notes: I suffered from executive dysfunction for a number of years before learning what it was, and it had a profound impact on me both personally and professionally. After realizing how pervasive these problems were, I did extensive research into their causes, and what factors can exacerbate or mitigate them. As a senior developer, I'm able to apply the things I've learned directly to my life in tech, making them relevant to other developers who experience these disorders, as well as their coworkers and managers who are also affected.

title: Angular Universal - be more SEO/CDN/User friendly with server-side rendering
abstract: Are you ready for production? Are you sure? Is your application prefetchable? Is it readable for search engine robots? Will it fit into CDN? Do you want to make it even faster? Meet the Server-Side Rendering. Learn how to implement it in your application and about best practices.
description:
Most of the Single Page Applications, and Angular is not an exception here, manifest one common problem. They are not SEO/CDN/prefetching friendly. 

Some could ask “Why should I care about that? My application bootstraps in the browser and looks awesome”, and they are right, as long as they are well-known companies who don’t need to position themselves on the market, AND their applications are closed ecosystems. In any other case, SEO and prefetching is a “to be or not to be” of the application. 

Is there a way to move Angular rendering process to the server and deliver richer content to the browser instead of pure index.html with tones of JavaScript? Yes, there is! It is called Angular Universal, and thanks to it, we achieve much faster First Meaningful Paint of our website! However, there are some pitfalls and risks as well...

During this talk I will cover how to implement server-side rendering (an official angular guide; and an alternative way by using schematics from ng-toolkit project); and how to deal with the problem which developers encounter while working with SSR:

- how to execute different code on NodeJS and inside the browser (different global objects available in both environments); with a real-life example: internationalization with ngx-translate (loading translations via HTTP and directly from the file system)
- How to convey to the browser the information that the back-end already did external API calls and there is no need to repeat them.
- How to abandon long-time calls to inefficient endpoints, and avoid delays in the server-side rendering process.

In closing, I will mention an alternative to SSR - prerendering, a process of rendering all subpages at the build time, and compare both techniques.

In this talk I am mentioning my publications about SSR, as a reference:

https://www.twilio.com/blog/encrypting-cookies-angular-universal-node-js
https://www.twilio.com/blog/expedited-two-factor-authentication-angular-twilio-authy
https://www.twilio.com/blog/transfer-files-data-javascript-applications-angular-node-js
https://www.twilio.com/blog/faster-javascript-web-apps-angular-universal-transferstate-api-watchdog
https://www.twilio.com/blog/create-search-engine-friendly-internationalized-web-apps-angular-universal-ngx-translate
https://www.twilio.com/blog/angular-universal-javascript-node-js-aws-lambda

title: WTF is JWT?
abstract: JWT, JWKS, JOSE header etc. etc. etc. Do you feel lost in all of that shortcuts? This session explains in simple way what is JSON Web Token and how you can utilize them in your daily job.
description:
In this talk I am going to cover in-depth JSON Web Tokens. Starting from the private/public key cryptography & signing data, through JSON Web Tokens (header, claims, signature), JSON Web Key Storage. I want also to describe what are the use-cases for JWTs and why are they better than other approaches.


I would be referring to my publications:

https://www.twilio.com/blog/building-javascript-microservices-node-js
notes: This is a very-draft outline of this talk, in case of any questions just ask.

title: Angular & NodeJS - advanced Angular Universal
abstract: With Angular Universal, you can bootstrap application on the server-side and respond to your user with a fully rendered view. Apart from that, you can execute additional logic and work with sensitive data (ie: private keys) on the server-side. Learn how to do that, and about best practices.
description:
In this talk I want to cover advanced usage of Angular Universal. I am going to perform a presentation together with the "live coding" (to be sure, that nothing will fail I am going to use recorded macros). In the presentation part I want to discuss Angular Universal and describe case study: Angular application with public available page, and protected content behind the two-factor authentication. The task which I want to perform is introducing Server-Side rendering to the application, read cookie values on the server-side to decide what content should be rendered for the authenticated user. I am also going to introduce the 'remember me' option and returning user case study, to present how shared code-base (front-end & back-end) can use sensitive data like encryption key and do not compromise them.

Those are main points of the talk:

1. Angular Universal introduction (why? What are benefits?)
2. Case study, overview of the application architecture (public available page, protected pages behind the two-factor authentication)
3. Introducing server-side rendering to the application
4. Reading cookie values (deterring if user is logged in)
5. Performing request for two factor authentication from the back-end (using private key, to authenticate application with the two-factor system)
6. Summarize and overview of what was implemented.

In this talk I am going to mention and use as a resource for further reading following articles:
https://www.twilio.com/blog/encrypting-cookies-angular-universal-node-js
https://www.twilio.com/blog/expedited-two-factor-authentication-angular-twilio-authy

name: Mark Scott
bio: Experienced Senior Software Architect with a demonstrated history of working in the information technology and services industry. Strong software development professional skilled in SDLC, .C#, and ServiceNow.
title: Three Questions Technologists Should Be Asking Themselves
abstract:
Is it scalable?
Is it secure?
Is it maintainable?

These three questions are the most powerful tools technologists and developers can ask themselves. At every stage, for every product, these questions allow you to future proof and mitigate risk.
description:
These three questions are the most powerful tool any developer can wield: 
"Is it scalable?"
"Is it secure?"
"Is it maintainable?"

Every line of code, function, class, script, file, project, UML diagram, database, concept, proposed solution, and architecture should stand up to these these questions. I've shutdown long winded meetings by asking these questions. I've written some of the most beautiful code I'd ever seen, reevaluated, and dumped it. I've even had managers hand me an award for asking these questions and keeping them honest. These questions are immensely valuable! Lets break them down:

Is it Scalable?
---------------------
This is probably the most complicated question of them all. We can't just write one off code. Devs tell ourselves that we will just "come back to that part and refactor when the time comes" but how often to we get that luxury? When we build something and it has an inherit flaw from the beginning, we're setting ourselves up for failure.

This is the place where UI/UX come into play as well. We can't lock the UI because we're waiting on a call to server side. You can manually train 5 users on this interface now, but when it grows to 20, they need to be able to figure it out themselves.

Hard lessons are learned here. Widgets fail here.

A word of caution on this though, oftentimes we end up in a trap of "analysis paralysis". Anything can be scaled infinitely with infinite resources. We might not have those resources (read time, money, patience) to make this fully scalable at the moment. Note these points and communicate! "We don't have X so there is an upper limit of Y". One of two things may happen here; you scare somebody into getting the resources you need or you are told you can come back later.

Is it Secure?
---------------------
![That's not my department](https://media3.giphy.com/media/kqQwLMXzBmmQg/source.gif)

We often don't want to admit it, but security really is our department. We can harden every server, lock access to every database, and make our environment look like Fort Knox but if we write a back door into something or create a huge vulnerability, all of that is for nothing. 

[Take a look at the HITECH act, specifically section 13404c](https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/ocr/privacy/hipaa/understanding/coveredentities/hitechact.pdf).

> c) APPLICATION OF CIVIL AND CRIMINAL PENALTIES.—In the> case of a business associate that violates any provision of subsection> (a) or (b), the provisions of sections 1176 and 1177 of the Social> Security Act (42 U.S.C. 1320d–5, 1320d–6) shall apply to the business associate with respect to such violation in the same manner> as such provisions apply to a person who violates a provision> of part C of title XI of such Act. 

Guess what! We're that "Business Associate" (yes, even as a contractor). That means that as a developer, we can be held _**PERSONALLY RESPONSIBLE**_ in the case of a leak of PII or HIPAA data!

This goes way beyond just HIPAA and PII though. We never store or transmit plain text credentials, we prevent script and SQL injection. We validate data on the client side AND the server side. Libraries from sources we don't know are on the naughty list and we _NEVER_ set them to auto update for the same reason.
The same logic from above applies, you probably are not going to get the time to "fix it later", do it correctly now.

Is it Maintainable?
---------------------
This question is the most easily dismissed. Of course we can maintain it! We wrote it! Can we though? We're rock stars! We are constantly building, fixing and going to meetings. In one week, one month, or one year's time are you going to be able to handle the fly-bys, one off change requests and break-fix this code needs? Now we have to deliver on our current project _AND_ help with the dev effort on our last project. It gets over whelming and leads to a huge amount of burn out.
Maybe we want to import a library we love. But what happens when support for that library goes away or the updates stop coming? Are others on our team going to be able to fix issues when that black box no longer works and nobody can contact the dev?

Yes, yes comments go here too but we can't forget about code readability! It does no good if I hire a junior and it takes them 6 months to a year to get up to speed. We can write dazzling one liner conditionals in Javascript but they are hard to read and understand. Every language has this issue, it's not just Javascript. Avoid the confusion, white space is our friend!

name: Dan Mallott
bio:
Dan Mallott is a Chicago-based consultant for West Monroe Partners in their Technology Practice. His passion is for distributed architecture, designing and building high performing service layers from the API down to the database.

Recent projects have included a new API and UI written in .NET CORE for a large international insurance broker that allows for insurance carriers to easily view upcoming renewing policies and developing a Kafka-based Customer 360-degree View solution for a mid-sized US health insurer.

Past speaking engagements have included NDC Sydney, Cream City Code, Chicago Code Camp, PASS Summit, and numerous SQL Saturdays throughout the US.

In his spare time, he can be found writing his own software instead of using package solutions or on the ice as an ice hockey player and referee.
title: Secure Database Design and Implementation
abstract: When you design and build an application, do you think about security first or is it an afterthought? Design for an application often starts with the database layer. In this talk, you will learn strategies for designing a more secure database.
description:
When you design and build an application, do you think about security first or is it an afterthought? Design for an application often starts with the database layer. In this talk, you will learn strategies for designing a more secure database. 

These strategies include simple design decisions for table, views, stored procedures, and data access roles. You will also learn about basic security features of several popular database platforms, including SQL Server and PostgreSQL and how these features apply in the cloud. Lastly, you will learn tips on how to retrofit security features on existing databases and look at how data access from the application may need to change.

title: Deploying Docker for Database DevOps Dominance
abstract: Your database deployments are still stuck in the proverbial dark ages! Learn how to leverage Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment practices to accelerate feature deployment and catch regression issues up front!
description: Your database deployments are still stuck in the proverbial dark ages! You might have build scripts for your database in source control, but deploying is still an exercise in creating the perfect script, and don't even think about making a data (or data type) change! Learn how to leverage Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment practices to accelerate feature deployment and catch regression issues up front! In this talk, we will learn techniques to utilize Docker for automating your database testing. We will also learn techniques for deploying database changes to development, QA, and (gasp) production, fully integrating your database into your existing DevOps pipeline. Finally, there will be a review of potential pitfalls and where you may want to fall back to old reliable: the hand-built script.

bio: Developer, writer, speaker, musician, and founder of DevRelate.io, PJ is known to travel the world speaking about programming and the way people think and interact.  He is also known for wearing hats.
title: From Turing to Big Data: A Look at Computing and Analytics
abstract: The basis of all DevOps and development starts with our measurements.  We need to understand what role analytics and metrics plays in modern computing.  To find out, we look at where analytics began in the advent of computer science and where we stand today, with an eye toward the future.
description:

The basis of all DevOps and development starts with our measurements.  We need to understand what role analytics and metrics plays in modern computing.  To find out, we look at where analytics began in the advent of computer science and where we stand today, with an eye toward the future.

title: The Future of Work + Play
abstract: It is no longer news that we have heard about the future of work, how about we talk about the future of play too! This talk is to unveil my research work about the correlation between hobbies and software development.
description: This talk is to unveil and explain the relationship between hobbies and work and how they could improve individual productivity. It will also be an avenue to point out to managers, CTOs and founders the importance of allocating time and even financial support via subscription to their teams to get involved in these hobbies because at the end of the day it improves productivity and ROI - it shouldn’t be classified as a waste of time and resources but as an important part of the company.

name: Burton Smith
bio:
I am a senior software engineer at Bunzl North America where I work with internal business stakeholders and external customers to build digital products and tools.

I am also the creator of the Clarion style framework for design systems - projectclarion.com.

In my free time, I love spending time with my wife and three daughters, practicing martial arts, jamming on my ukulele, and learning new things (usually about software engineering).
title: 10 Keys to Making Friends With CSS
abstract: CSS doesn't have to be hard! Most of the issues revolve around a misunderstanding of a few fundamental concepts. During this talk we will discuss 10 simple guidelines that will make a big difference in the way you write CSS.
description:
CSS doesn't suck (or at least it doesn't have to)! Many of the challenges with CSS come from a misunderstanding of how it works. CSS is a powerful tool that can be used to create amazing products.

In this talk, we will discuss 10 key aspects of CSS that will go a long way with making it easier to create well-crafted user interfaces. At the end of this, you will have actionable take-aways on how to write better CSS as well as resources on how to evaluate how you are doing and how to build your skills.

name: info@practicalddd.com
bio: Vijay Nair is currently a Director of Platform Engineering within Oracle’s Financial Services Global Business Unit. A DDD and distributed systems enthusiast, he has around 18 years of experience in architecting, building and implementing mission critical applications for the financial services industry around the world. Hey s the author of the book "Practical Domain-Driven Design with Enterprise Java". He can be reached via his personal website www.practicalddd.com or via Twitter at @Fusionvj
title: Practical Domain-Driven Design using Java Frameworks
abstract: The Practical DDD session aims to simplify the various concepts/principles and patterns of DDD in a manner which is easily consumable, relatable and practical. The session will walkthrough 4 separate DDD implementations using 4 leading Java Frameworks (Spring Boot / MicroProfile / Jakarta EE / Axon)
description:
DDD is quickly becoming the defacto approach for building business applications be it Monoliths / Moduliths or Microservices as it offers a solid, systematic and comprehensive approach to 
software design and development. However, for folks stepping into the new paradigm the concepts/patterns and principles of DDD seem daunting. The Practical DDD session aims to simplify the various concepts/principles and patterns of DDD in a manner which is easily consumable, relateable and practical within the context of an execution platform like Jakarta EE / Spring Boot / MicroProfile and the Axon Framework.

As a developer/architect or technical leader, using the tools/frameworks that you currently use or are familiar with is the fastest way for adopting a new design paradigm.

This session aims to do exactly that. The attendees are first taken through a quick introduction to the major DDD concepts using a reference application (Cargo Tracker). Attendees learn about DDD concepts such as Domain Models/Domain Rules and Domain Supporting Services not just in theory but through references to Cargo Tracker. 

The next part of the session walks through 4 detailed DDD implementations utiling 4 leading Java Frameworks. Each of these implementations map concepts of DDD (e.g. Bounded Contexts/Aggregates) to the corresponding available tools within the specific platform

- The first implementation will be based on a monolithic architecture using Jakarta EE
- The second implementation will be based on a microservices architecture using Eclipse MicroProfile (Project Helidon)
- The third implementation will be based on a microservices architecture using Spring Boot / Spring Cloud and Spring Cloud Streams
- The final implementation will be the most advanced implementation using a CQRS/ES architecture using the Axon framework

At the end of the session, attendees using any one of these platforms get a relatable pathway to the adoption of DDD for their enterprise applications. Attendees get complete working source code for the 4 implementations.
notes: I currently am the Director of Engineering for Oracle's Banking SaaS applications. I am the author of the book Practical Domain-Driven Design using Enterprise Java (https://www.apress.com/us/book/9781484245422). I run the website practicalddd.com which provides multiple implementations of DDD using Java Frameworks and Platforms. My github URL is at https://github.com/practicalddd

name: Burton Smith
bio:
I am a senior software engineer at Bunzl North America where I work with internal business stakeholders and external customers to build digital products and tools.

I am also the creator of the Clarion style framework for design systems - projectclarion.com.

In my free time, I love spending time with my wife and three daughters, practicing martial arts, jamming on my ukulele, and learning new things (usually about software engineering).
title: Say No To Accidental Architecture! Code Your Design Systems Instead
abstract: Take advantage of Design Systems to bring sanity to your projects, make development simpler, and speed up your development cycles.
description:
Are you still rockin' a single "styles.css" file in or project or have styles scattered throughout your project? Do you find yourself fighting to override styles or throw the "!important" property around a lot? Does your project have 20 different kinds of buttons and you don't know why or even where they are all defined? If you answered yes to any of these or just find it difficult to manage and scale the styles for your project, chances are you are a victim of "Accidental Architecture".

In this session, we will discuss how to prevent "Accidental Architecture" from happening and instead discuss the benefits of Design Systems and how they can be leveraged to create meaningful architecture. We will also introduce some tools to assess your current applications as well as a framework and an architecture that is easy to adapt and implement from one project to another.

name: Burton Smith
bio:
I am a senior software engineer at Bunzl North America where I work with internal business stakeholders and external customers to build digital products and tools.
