title: Back to Basics: Approaches to Machine Learning
abstract: Last couple of years have seen an immense growth of Machine Learning in multifarious domains, each one necessitating a different mathematical model, either rule or tree based models, geometric or probabilistic model. This talk reviews them all and helps choose one for an efficient design solution.
description:
In the contemporary world of learning algorithms, along with the aggregate domains plying Machine Learning the complexity of the models itself is swelling. Thus it is important to approach Machine Learning in a conceptual way and in this talk I will present an informal taxonomy of the Machine Learning algorithms, majorly grouped on the different mathematical abstractions. 

I will cover Logical Models with tree based or rule based concepts, Geometric Models including linear and distance based approaches,  and Probabilistic Models. I will go over the fundamentals of each type of model and discuss their positives, limitations and use cases  along-with a very simple hands-on example. The talk will conclude with some pointers on how to explore the data and choose a model to make the learning more efficient.

This talk aims to introduce different categories of Machine Learning models from mathematical point of view and encourage budding ML enthusiasts to reflect on the implications of each corresponding to their domain. By better understanding these types of models attendees will be empowered to design intelligent solutions.


# Outline

## Introduction (2-3 minutes)
- Rise of Machine Learning & Applications: Reason for its bloom & dominance
- Reflecting on the need to classify Machine Learning algorithms

## Taxonomy of Machine Learning Models (15-20 minutes)
- Laying out 3 different categories with their respective subcategories along with mathematical concepts, use cases, real world examples, pros and cons:
- Logical Models: Tree Based or Rule based, Concept Learning, Inductive Learning, etc.
- Geometric Models: Linear Methods like Linear Regression, Kernel Methods like SVM, Distance-based Methods like K-Means, Nearest Neighbor etc.
- Probabilistic Models: Predictive and Generative Methods, Naive Bayes, etc.

## Hands-On Examples (Audience-level and Time-constraint dependent) (10 minutes)
- Task definitions, Dataset identification and exploration
- Reflecting on different approaches to Machine Learning modeling
- Discussing efficiency, usability, simplicity and implementation of the chosen model

## Conclusion and Takeaways (5 minutes)
- Emphasizing on the need of good and reliable mathematical approach
- Pointers on how to select a model based on the application
- Discussing pros and cons of combining, interleaving multiple models
- Some personal anecdotes, recommendations for different use cases as an ML Engineer
notes:
Currently working on real-life problems in the most progressive environment of ML a.k.a social networking (Twitter, Inc.) and sponsored content as a Machine Learning Engineer, having a Masters in Computer Science (with specialization in Machine Learning and Artificial Intelligence) and a ML/DS Pythonista at heart I truly believe that I could bring in all my thoughts and experiences gathered as a part of my work/study and initiate the audience about different kinds of mathematical models that form the foundation of Machine Learning algorithms and can crudely be divided into three different categories. As budding technologists it can help us leverage this knowledge to design efficient yet intelligent solutions. 

I am an avid open source enthusiast with the honor of winning the Red Hat Women in Open Source Award 2017, and an ardent speaker at all kinds of international conferences and local meet-ups speaking on starting up with open source, going beyond coding to get involved in the community and on embracing different styles in Python programming for use cases like Machine Learning, Data Science, Internet of Things, etc. and with my latest talk on Taxonomy of Machine Learning models I would like to dive deep into this domain.

- Previous Keynotes, talks, CodeLabs etc: [https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pWmkyoxqbFTKsSlmRgYlQ_8gUCtnRrGcfYuGqUT1vCs/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1pWmkyoxqbFTKsSlmRgYlQ_8gUCtnRrGcfYuGqUT1vCs/edit?usp=sharing)
- YouTube Videos: [https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaPucMRPgl5aNJJMO3OkfEA/playlists?view_as=subscriber](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCaPucMRPgl5aNJJMO3OkfEA/playlists?view_as=subscriber)

name: Sergey Poliakov
bio: Sergey is a Frontend Developer at Travel Audience in Berlin. He is working with React, GraphQL, TypeScript and styled-components. Although he is only 28, it's already his second career. Before he got a Bachelor and Master Degree in Journalism in Saint-Petersburg and was working for a small travel startup until the fall of the Russian rouble in 2014. It was then when he made his best investment - he learned how to code.
title: Career Decisions: Quit or Get Involved
abstract: The employee perspective on career decisions is currently underrepresented at tech conferences. I hope, that my speech will inspire people to face the management with some uncomfortable questions and our workplaces will become better. I believe in the initiatives "from the bottom".
description:
Should I stay or should I go? You can catch yourself thinking about it after another farewell party, good-bye email, 1:1 with your manager, company update and on many other occasions.

Having experience in different jobs before IT in this talk, I will raise questions of happiness and self-fulfilment at the working space, the possibilities to have open conversations about it with your management and supervisors, how to find the courage to try to change something before handling your resignation and why “just quit” is not always a meaningful statement.
notes:
Video from my previous speaker engagements:

https://youtu.be/VjThOQUome0 - lightning talk “How to Boost Your Career with Personal Projects” https://youtu.be/Zx_0sdr0dCU - webinar “How to Handle Developers Without Tech Degree”

name: Jamie Wright
bio: Jamie Wright is a maker of internet things with a love/hate relationship for Redbull™, standing desks, and paintball guns. He has a love only relationship with teaching, learning, and building bots. Jamie runs Brilliant Fantastic as an independent software developer that helps companies drive their businesses forward through valuable software.
title: Building a Realtime Websocket API
abstract: There are not many examples, posts, or videos out there of people building websocket APIs, let alone in Phoenix. I had to create one from scratch for a real-world application I built. It turned out great and I want to share my experiences.
description:
Sometimes consumers of your APIs require near-realtime communication as regular RESTful HTTP apis are a few milliseconds too slow. These performant and scalable APIs can be made over websocket TCP connections where events are pushed from client and server in near-realtime fashion.

This talk is a story of how I built such an API. We'll look at why this decision to create a websocket API was made and we will take a look at the data that supported this decision. We will take a deep dive into Phoenix websockets, channels, and transports to expose the underlying architecture. Finally, we look at how we tested the API, how we authenticated users over the channels, and how Phoenix helped this all happen with relative ease.
notes:
I think this talk could help developers who are interested in this subject but do not know how to get started. There is not many resources out there for building this and I think realtime APIs are very useful to build.

I am qualified to talk about this because I have built it myself for a real-world application.

name: John Sawers
location: Broadway @ Webster Ave, Chelsea, MA 02150, USA
bio: John and Engineering Manager at Privia Health. He's been programming professionally for two decades, in Perl, Java, PHP and Ruby. In recent years he has also been teaching workshops which help people get deeply in touch with themselves and liberated from past traumas. He has fused his expertise from these disparate areas into a new way of thinking about them both.
title: Hacking Your Emotional API
abstract:
Being a good developer isn't just about slinging code; we're part of a community. Interacting with others in a community means feelings are involved. 

In this talk you’ll learn how emotions are affecting you by modeling them as an API and looking at the code.
description:
Imagine that your brain is wired to an API, and that one of the endpoints triggers you to be absolutely furious when it’s called. All the other emotions have endpoints as well. This is the metaphor that I use to describe how feelings work.

When we think about emotions this way, they become a bit less scary. The metaphor allows us to use technical language to describe experiences which are often misunderstood. 

To explain why it's important to improve our emotional responses I go over research which describes how improperly handling your emotions can have significant impacts things like abstract thinking, short-term memory and executive function. 

Then I present a toolbox full of techniques that you can use develop emotional fluency, and I illustrate a number of those techniques by describing my own emotional challenges as if they were written in code. I describe how I used those skills to “refactor” that code.

This topic is particularly relevant today, as the non-coding aspects of developer life are becoming more important than the coding ones. Thriving in a diverse community requires us to develop our skills in communication, understanding and empathy. I want to share what I've learned about emotions in a way developers can relate to, so they can grasp how feelings impact not only their own quality of work, but their ability to work well with others.
notes: If you read my bio, you'll see that I am in a unique position to make ill-defined and imprecise feelings understandable to a technical audience. I've spent years developing the emotional API idea, and as I've done so I've found more and more research that points to specific measurable impacts on our lives as developers. This has helped me frame the benefits of this emotional work clearly.

name: Johnie Karr
bio:
With nearly 12 years of experience, Johnie began his career building custom software for Cox Communications to facilitate communication between engineers and field employees. At Cox, he completed Leadership Academy, an elite year-long training program offered to top employees of the company and received many accolades for his customer service skills. Johnie also spent four years working for the state of Kentucky. He built and supported enterprise software for the Kentucky General Assembly. He also designed and built a universal funding application (UFA) for Kentucky Housing Corporation that gained national recognition from the National Council of State Housing Agencies in 2014, when UFA was nominated for an industry innovation award. At the International Student Exchange Program, Johnie architected and built the back-end tools for the organization’s new platform. At ScholarRx, Johnie works on the back-end and authoring tools that help the future doctors be the best they can be.

Johnie is passionate about new technologies and is particularly interested in building new enterprise and mobile applications to streamline processes. Johnie is a Six Sigma Yellow Belt and holds certifications for customer service, implementing and maintaining a SQL server 2008 database, HIPPA awareness for business associates, and HIPPA security. Johnie has been on his church's IT team since 2012 and has served as treasurer since 2013.
title: Building a secure user authorization story
abstract: If you have a login button on your website, you need to hear these tips....unless you want to make your customers vulnerable to social engineering attacks and data breaches, then go ahead and skip this talk :-)
description: Every application has a login button. In this session, we'll cover some techniques for handling user authentication in a secure manner, along with covering proper user flow, including user registration, logging in, and password resets. At the end of this session, you'll be armed with the knowledge to feel confident in the security of your authentication story.

name: Johnie Karr
bio:
With nearly 12 years of experience, Johnie began his career building custom software for Cox Communications to facilitate communication between engineers and field employees. At Cox, he completed Leadership Academy, an elite year-long training program offered to top employees of the company and received many accolades for his customer service skills. Johnie also spent four years working for the state of Kentucky. He built and supported enterprise software for the Kentucky General Assembly. He also designed and built a universal funding application (UFA) for Kentucky Housing Corporation that gained national recognition from the National Council of State Housing Agencies in 2014, when UFA was nominated for an industry innovation award. At the International Student Exchange Program, Johnie architected and built the back-end tools for the organization’s new platform. At ScholarRx, Johnie works on the back-end and authoring tools that help the future doctors be the best they can be.

Johnie is passionate about new technologies and is particularly interested in building new enterprise and mobile applications to streamline processes. Johnie is a Six Sigma Yellow Belt and holds certifications for customer service, implementing and maintaining a SQL server 2008 database, HIPPA awareness for business associates, and HIPPA security. Johnie has been on his church's IT team since 2012 and has served as treasurer since 2013.
title: Creating and consuming a private NuGet Repository using Azure DevOps
abstract: Have you ever wanted to create a private reusable library that you could use through NuGet, but no one else in the world could use, or see, or have any knowledge of, because you don't want to share your awesomeness with anyone?  In this talk, I'll show you how to do just that, using Azure DevOps.
description: There are benefits to using NuGet package manager for your libraries. When you have libraries that contain propitiatory code, or are just for your organizations internal use only, you don't want to expose those libraries to the open marketplace. That's where a private repository comes in. During this session, we'll discuss some of the reasons why package managers are a good idea, and we'll demonstrate how to create a private repository in Azure DevOps for your organization, and show how to publish to and consume that repository.

name: Joe Karlsson
bio:
Joe Karlsson is a software engineer turned Developer Advocate at MongoDB. He comes from the frozen tundra of Minneapolis, Minnesota (and yes, it does get really cold here, and no, not everyone here has the accent from the movie, Fargo 😝). Joe has been primarily a Node and JavaScript engineer. He has been writing, teaching, and talking about code his entire career. Sharing what he knows and continuing to learn about programming is truly the thing he loves doing the most.
 
Joe is the co-creator of open source software, including bechdel.io, a web app that tells you if a movie script passes the Bechdel Test or not. In his free time, he is usually drinking Gin and Tonics, eating at a new restaurant, or tinkering on a new art project or open source project.
title: An Introduction To IoT (Internet of Toilets 🚽); Or How I Built an IoT Kitty Litter Box Using JavaScript
abstract: My favorite things in life are cats 🐈, computers 🖥 and crappy ideas 💩, so I decided to combine all three and make an IoT (Internet of Things) litter box. Together, we will go through how I setup my IoT Litter Box from start to finish.
description:
My favorite things in life are cats 🐈, computers 🖥 and crappy ideas 💩, so I decided to combine all three and make an IoT (Internet of Things) litter box using a Raspberry Pi and JavaScript! If you  have ever wanted to get build your own IoT project, but didn’t know how to start, then this is the talk for you. 

Together, we will go through how I setup my IoT Litter Box from start to finish. Including how to setup Node.js on a Raspberry Pi and how to connect sensors to a Raspberry Pi and how to read the sensor inputs with Node.js.
notes:
Talk Outline:

* Introduction/What the heck is IoT?
* Iot Data Cycle
    * Collect data -> Communicate to a server -> Analyze the data -> Act
* IoT and JS - Why/How does that work?
    * Easy to update over a network
    * The internet already speaks JS
    * Tons of exisiting libraries/plugins/APIs
        * Cylon.js & Johnny-Five
    * JS is great at handling event-driven apps
* Project Demo: Internet of Toilets 🚽: IoT Kitty Litter Box
    * Review required materials and why we need them
        * Raspberry Pi
        * Breadboard
        * etc...
    * We will cover the motivation and insights from the project
    * We will focus on the most simple component, the switch
        * What is the GPIO and how do we interact with it?
        * How do we save/anlyze/act on this data?
            * Demo saving the data to MongoDB database
* Future of IoT
    * Smaller and more powerful devices
    * JS with a smaller footprint
    * Better hardware support
    * Batteries will soon be the bottleneck for IoT work
* Recap
* Questions
* End!

Code: [https://github.com/JoeKarlsson/iot-kitty-litter-box](https://github.com/JoeKarlsson/iot-kitty-litter-box)

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/).

name: Naomi Meyer
bio: Naomi works as a Software Development Engineer at Adobe in New York City, where she leads internationalization on her team. Before writing JavaScript full time, Naomi worked as a teacher in local classrooms across Asia and West Africa. She is passionate about developing with diversity, inclusion, and internationalization in mind, and enjoys hiking and riding bikes on the weekends.
title: Emoji Encoding, Unicode, � and Internationalization (I18N)
abstract: Ever wondered how emoji & complex scripting languages are encoded to work correctly for billions of people around the world? Or how new emoji are introduced & approved? Ever seen one of these: □ � special glyph characters & want info on how to avoid them in the future? Then this talk is for you!
description: Have you ever wondered how emoji and complex scripting languages are encoded to work correctly across browsers and devices - for billions of people online around the world? Or how new emoji are introduced and approved? Have you ever seen one of these: □ � □ “special” glyph characters before and want more information on how to avoid them in the future? Let’s talk about internationalization of unicode characters and emojis across the world wide web! We’ll go over best practices, do’s and don’ts, and provide resources to learn more and even where to go if you want to submit a new emoji proposal! :)
notes: I am passionate about internationalization and work at Adobe as a Software Development Engineer and product champion for internationalization on my team. I have learned first hand how to correctly encode Unicode characters and want to share with the JavaScript community. I also love emoji and think the process is fascinating and should be talked about more!

name: Jeff Strauss
bio:
Jeff is a technical architect, an executive consultant, and an attorney. As a member of the Chief Digital Advisor team at World Wide Technology—and with his unique experiences that combine tech and the law—he maintains a passion for solving problems with inspired solutions, improving life and business through technology.

A dedicated member of the developer community, Jeff travels internationally to speak on both technical and business-oriented topics. He is a Microsoft MVP and serves on the board of directors for the Kansas City Developer Conference.
title: Multithreaded JavaScript—Web Workers, Shared Memory, and Atomics
abstract: JavaScript is single-threaded by design. Thankfully, the language has introduced means for handling parallelism over the web. Web Workers, Shared Memory Buffers, and Atomic operations allow long-running code to execute in the background without blocking performance of the main application and UI.
description:
For better or worse, JavaScript is single-threaded by design. For over 50 years Moore’s Law has described persistent exponential growth in computational power, but physical limitations have slowed that trend. Advancement now comes through the use of multiple CPUs and cores. This is fine for languages featuring threads and task-based architectures. But what about JavaScript?

Thankfully, new paradigms handle parallelism over the web. Web Worker constructs allow long-running code to execute in the background without blocking the UI. Shared Memory and Atomic operations allow true sharing of data among worker processes. Learn to leverage these exciting features to responsibly improve the performance and responsiveness of your web applications!
notes:
THIS TALK ONLINE AT:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2w7Ewkpftd4

SELECTED PUBLISHED PRESENTATIONS:
http://jeffandjon.com/media (under the "Jeff's Videos" tab)

NOTES ON THIS SUBMISSION:
I have found that attendees, even at dedicated JavaScript meetups and user groups, are often unaware of JavaScript's capabilities surrounding parallelism and concurrency. While the topic is somewhat advanced, we certainly have all experienced sites that stop responding, with little or no explanation. In situations where heavy client-side mathematical calculation or other long-running processing is required, utilizing Web Workers efficiently can make a huge difference.

Atomics were temporarily disabled in 2018 due to concerns surrounding Spectre and Meltdown vulnerabilities, but the Chrome team took steps that it felt addressed the problem, and other browsers have begun to follow suit.

The goal of this talk will be to introduce relevant features—some of which have been introduced as recently as ES2017—and to help attendees determine when leveraging "multithreaded" JavaScript may be worth the development time and overhead.

name: Ryan Heupler
bio: Hi there! I'm currently an engineer at Guru, as well as mentor/instructor for an online code school called Thinkful. I run my own YouTube channel focused on helping break down programming concepts into simple terms (or at least I try to!). When I'm not working on any of that, I'll sometime stream on Twitch where I do portfolio reviews for people looking for jobs. I'll sometime mess around making music, or hangout at a local coffee shop (trying to find the best coffee in Philadelphia).
title: Refactoring a Class Component: A Gentle Introduction into React Hooks
abstract: In this talk, I’ll demonstrate how we can refactor class components to functional ones using React hooks. This will include states, life-cycle methods and some “gotchas” we should look out for when using hooks. I will also show how we can write our own custom hooks for re-usability.
description: The introduction of Hooks in React has become a very "buzz word" topic in the community, which, ultimately, has lead to some confusion. Some common questions I hear when talking to others are: What are they? How do you use them? Do they replace life-cycle methods and/or class components completely? We will go over all of these together. I'll start with a basic React app using a few stateful, class components using life-cycle methods, custom methods and API interaction. I will then convert the components over to functional ones while integrating several different hooks, without losing any functionality. Finally, we will look into some common "gotchas" that may be confusing for people starting out with hooks. You will come away from this talk with a good foundation for various primitive hooks in React, and you'll understand how they're used and how you can start to write your own custom hooks.
notes:
The requirements to attend this talk are pretty open. I’m structuring in a way where anybody can understand and follow along. Some basic React experience would be nice to have, but familiarity with a component-style architecture is all that’s needed. I've given talks at LibertyJS, Reactadelphia, and Vue Philly.

I’m a full-time engineer at Guru, where I use and learn about React daily. I’m also a part-time mentor for Thinkful where I teach and help people learn different areas of front-end development, such as React. I try to break things down to as simple terms as possible and while interacting with the audience. I have a YouTube channel focused on helping people learning to program. I try to break things down into simple terms with visual examples so this will include a mix of notes and live coding

name: Fred Turkington
bio: Hello, I'm __Fred__. I'm a web developer, project manager, and entrepreneurship enthusiast. I'm the Director of Operations at __Ten Forward Consulting__, where we create custom web and mobile applications that make work easier for employees in large companies. I've spent the better part of a decade fixing broken processes at large businesses through the power of software. I've learned that your technical solution gets you in the door, but your ability to connect with your users and the tools they use to get through their day are the key to your software being meaningfully adopted. I live, run, and hike in Madison, WI, with my partner and our fluffy Newfoundland dog.
title: Processes for a Successful Remote-Friendly & Employee-Oriented Company
abstract: Engineering organizations hire smart, opinionated people with lots of ideas about how processes should work. Hear how our company makes process design inclusive of everyone, and how we've created processes that optimize for work from home/remote and async communication to keep engineers flowing.
description: Engineering organizations hire smart, opinionated people, which means that all their staff have ideas about how processes should work. Hear about how our company makes process design inclusive of everyone, and how we've created processes that optimize for work from home/remote and async communication to keep engineers flowing.

name: Fred Turkington
bio: Hello, I'm __Fred__. I'm a web developer, project manager, and entrepreneurship enthusiast. I'm the Director of Operations at __Ten Forward Consulting__, where we create custom web and mobile applications that make work easier for employees in large companies. I've spent the better part of a decade fixing broken processes at large businesses through the power of software. I've learned that your technical solution gets you in the door, but your ability to connect with your users and the tools they use to get through their day are the key to your software being meaningfully adopted. I live, run, and hike in Madison, WI, with my partner and our fluffy Newfoundland dog.
title: Persuasion: Getting Your Tech Widely Adopted
abstract: Brilliant developers, project managers, and IT professionals build tools perfectly suited to their users. So why don't those users use them? In this talk, you'll learn new ways to frame your discussion of your technology to make your users excited about the tool you've built to help them.
description: It's frustrating when you've poured your creative energy into a tool that solves a problem for your users, but they don't buy in . You _know_ your users - they turn to you for help with their information problems, and you have the analytical skill to find solutions for them. So why is it so hard to get them on board with a new piece of software or hardware? As a developer, I found that subtly changing the way I talked about the exact same software led to way more progress with my users. Learn ways to get stakeholder buy-in using lessons in persuasion from entrepreneurship.
notes:
The best way I've found to give this talk is with __audience participation__; the first part of the talk is a rousing, fun audience participation activity of about 20 minutes where members of the audience try to persuade others on a fictional product, and the rest is a presentation on persuasive techniques for technical people.

I most recently gave this talk at Chippewa Valley Code Conference in Eau Claire.

name: Fred Turkington
bio: Hello, I'm __Fred__. I'm a web developer, project manager, and entrepreneurship enthusiast. I'm the Director of Operations at __Ten Forward Consulting__, where we create custom web and mobile applications that make work easier for employees in large companies. I've spent the better part of a decade fixing broken processes at large businesses through the power of software. I've learned that your technical solution gets you in the door, but your ability to connect with your users and the tools they use to get through their day are the key to your software being meaningfully adopted. I live, run, and hike in Madison, WI, with my partner and our fluffy Newfoundland dog.
title: The Old Hotness: M, NoSQL, and Why You Should Learn a Really Old Language
abstract: The M language/database was created in the '60s for working with healthcare data. It was one of the first NoSQL databases using technology familiar to any modern MongoDB user. We'll see the benefits of using a 45-year-old language, and the architecture patterns that prove new isn't always better.
description: The M language/database was created in the 1960s for interacting with healthcare data. It was one of the first NoSQL databases, designed around space-efficient sparse trees for storage. Though M is much-maligned in the press, we'll discuss how its concepts of hot NoSQL databases were in use 40 years ago, and the benefits of using a language from a time when cramming your program into available memory was a core programmer skill.

name: Dana Scheider
bio: Dana Scheider is a member of the Cucumber core team. Hailing from Portland, Oregon, she currently lives in Melbourne, Australia, where she works as a Ruby on Rails developer for Envato. She is particularly interested in testing, behaviour-driven development, REST API design, and improving processes within engineering organisations. Dana's extracurricular interests include theoretical mathematics, opera, and shooting pool. An in-demand speaker, notable conference appearances include SwanseaCon, CukeUp! London, Full Stack Toronto, and RubyConf Colombia.
title: A Beginner's Guide to Open Source
abstract: Making your first open source contributions can be daunting. This talk demystifies how open-source projects work and how you can get involved with the projects you love.
description: Many developers aspire to make open-source contributions, but it can be daunting to familiarize yourself with a new project and figure out the best way to get involved. This talk, by a core Cucumber maintainer, provides a detailed explanation of how open-source projects are run, how to get your first contributions accepted, and how to avoid common pitfalls many beginning contributors run into.
notes: I'm a good person to speak on this subject because I'm a member of the Cucumber core team (who worked her way up from community contributor). I've also contributed to a number of other open source projects to a lesser extent.

name: Jonathan Turner
bio: Jon graduated from Brigham Young University with a bachelor's and a master's degree in computer science. His thesis was on "cool robot stuff" (more specifically, user interface design combined with interactive machine learning applied to robot control). He has worked as a developer doing data conversion, government management software, and educational software focused on teaching children English. He also taught computer science at Neumont University. He currently works as a software craftsman at Pluralsight, which specializes in online technical training. When not developing professionally, he enjoys working on mobile, game, hardware and other random side projects.
title: What I Learned About Software Development from Origami
abstract:
At first glance origami and software development appear to have very little in common. Is there anything that can be learned by comparing the two?

In this session we’ll talk about some of the things about software development that can be learned from origami. And we'll fold some origami together!
description:
Origami is the art of paper folding. Software development is the process of putting together instructions for a computer in order to get the computer to perform some desired operation. At first glance origami and software development appear to have very little in common. One is very physical in nature. The other is almost completely digital. Is there anything that can be learned by comparing the two?

In this session we’ll talk about some of the parallels we can draw between origami and software development and some of the things about software development that can be learned from origami. This presentation is from a technical perspective, but anyone involved in the software development process can benefit. If you’re a fan of origami in the shape of unicorns, dragons, dinosaurs or popular Star Wars characters you should probably attend this session. Origami paper will be provided, and no previous origami experience is required.
notes:
This is a presentation on software craftsmanship, disguised as a presentation about software development and origami. Origami and software development are obviously very different, but at least one very strong parallel exists between them: what work we do is important, but also how we do it.

There is no code in this presentation (my preferred type of presentation usually involves some form of live coding), but the parallels between software development and origami come from a very technical perspective. This presentation has TONs of pictures of origami (all models folded by me and pictures taken by me). I also have attendees fold an origami model interactively as part of the presentation. It's a fun presentation that's lighter than some more technical talks, but also provides some deep thoughts for attendees to ponder.

I have given this presentation at Agile 2019, OpenWest 2019 and Utah Big Mountain Data & Dev. It seemed to be very well received every time I've given it.

name: aaron ralls
bio:
Aaron is a Sr. Applications Architect with Accruent focusing on migrating applications to the cloud. Aaron is also the President of the Fort Smith Tech Users Group since April 2018. 

Aaron started as a developer and later served as a Manager of Developers, Business Analysts, Test Analysts, Vendor Managers. During his twenty plus years, Aaron has worked in banking, electric utilities, health care, transportation.

Aaron is an analytical and solution-oriented professional with expertise in guiding teams to improve efficiency by identifying the core issues. 

In his free time, Aaron enjoys music and food festivals, video games, the occasional workout, and spending time with his family.
title: Azure Security Tips for Demoware
abstract:
You've read a blog post or Microsoft documentation on how to run your project in Azure.

You are about to publish your application to the public. STOP!

In this demo, we review Azure Security tips for a typical web application that uses IaaS, PaaS, and FaaS [serverless] resources.
description:
#Intro

As technologists, we have to often move fast and learn fast to get our jobs done. We search out content that gets us started. We confirm the basic functionality and look to move on to the next item. While blogs and Microsoft documentation is great it is ultimately demoware. Demoware is not production ready! In this talk, we cover how to improve the security for common Azure resources.

I will review a typical demoware website application that uses Azure SQL. I will show the components and functionality of the solution.
Then I will secure the solution with an overview of the security recommendations.

#Azure RBAC

* How this impacts Azure Resource Group organization

#Security for IaaS

* Azure Virtual Machines
* VNET's
* Azure Storage

#Security for PaaS

* Azure SQL
* Azure Web Apps

#Security for FaaS 

* Azure Functions
* Azure Logic Apps
notes:
I have spent the last three years working with Azure as an Application or Cloud Architect. My recent focus has been on building long-term strategies on how to migrate existing applications to the cloud. In addition, I am a Microsoft Certified Azure Architect.

I started speaking in 2018 at local meetups (Fort Smith, AR; Little Rock, AR; Tulsa, OK) and presented at my first conference Little Rock Tech Fest 2019.

name: Jennifer Blatz
bio:
Jen Blatz is a Lead User Experience Designer and Researcher with expertise that lends itself to any industry. Jen's path to UX started in journalism and graphic design where she learned the importance of aesthetics, organization, and catering content for the consumer. She has worked in a number of fields including finance, cloud storage, security and pet health. Jen is now at Fidelity Investments focusing on improving enterprise tools used by employees.
Jen loves being active in the UX community to learn and grow while helping others do the same. She is the co-founder of the UX Research and Strategy group, and of IXDA (Interaction Design Association) Dallas. She is the organizer of WIAD (World Information Architecture Day) DFW in 2019 and 2020, and speaker for several local meetups and international conferences like Big Design and Concentric Conference. When not immersed in UX activities and speaking at local meetups, conferences and classes, Jen loves traveling, wine tasting, cooking and spending time with her husband and two doggos, Sadie and Ricky.

title: The Art of Interviewing Users: When you don’t have UX resources and you need insights fast
abstract: When UX and Research are not available, sometimes you have to get the user’s feedback yourself. This talk will give technologists the confidence to ask the right questions of their users, what to do with that information, and how to implement the feedback in to actionable results, without bias.
description:
Showing up to an interview is only one small component of a successful interview. This talk will show you how to plan your research study, establish goals, create your discussion guide, determine the best questions to ask to gather the right information, establish rapport with your participant, and execute the interview. Creating templates for different types of interviews and users can help streamline your process and set you up for success. I will give you tips on a few crucial interview techniques and best practices like how to stay grounded as the apprentice and bring participants out of the weeds and back on track. With a little preparation and planning in advance, your user interview can be used to gather critical information for better designs. 

Outline
●	What is the user interview method?
●	Why is it fabulous?
●	When it might not work
●	Types of formats/scenarios/environments
●	How to prepare for user interviews
●	Being aware of cognitive biases
●	Writing the discussion guide: content, components and formats
●	Conducting interviews in person
●	Conducting interviews via video or phone
●	Techniques and tips on how to:
o	Build the rapport
o	Keep them in line
o	Get out of the weeds
o	Give participants confidence and feel comfortable
o	Note-taking and research study preparation
o	Debriefing with note-takers
o	Additional information to capture
notes:
Attendees will learn all the things they need to prepare for a user interview like how to write a discussion guide, how to keep participants on the right path and how to glide through that interview without a hitch. Or at least if there are hitches, how to get things back on track. 

As a user experience researcher, I have conducted hundreds of user interviews, from in person to remote and have learned a lot of tips to prepare for success. Through the struggles and lessons I have learned along the way, I have developed a set of best practices. I now share this wisdom with members of my team and will share it with attendees of the conference. 

As a lead UX Designer with extensive researcher chops, I can easily translate research practices so that a technologist can understand the value of this method. My hope is to help those who are in a jam by teaching them how to conduct interviews and research properly. Having great interview skills is key to successful research that leads to valuable insights. This can help any person build empathy for the user, and create better designs, based on a solid foundation of research, not guesses.

title: Stop the Dark Patterns! Prevent Cognitive Biases From Creeping in to Design and Development
abstract: Cognitive bias affects all of us – even developers. This talk will help technologists, many who work with UX, see the signs of cognitive biases. The take away is to combat the behaviors and help everyone prevent biases from creeping in to their design work and that of others around you.
description:
Generally, people go into tests with good intentions of gathering accurate, pristine information, so how does all this bias creep in? It’s pretty common to have several psychological biases working against you that can cloud your design and user research. This talk will focus on surfacing some of the darkest types of bias and how to prevent and combat them. Also, learn how to use some of those cognitive biases for good in your designs. No dark patterns here folks.

Outline
●	Opening hook story
●	Agenda
o	What is cognitive bias?
o	What are the signs?
o	How do you fight it?
o	How do we use it to our advantage?
●	Define
●	Why it matters
●	Types of bias
o	Self/You
▪	Blind spot bias
▪	Experimenter’s bias
▪	Observer-expectancy effect
o	Self vs others
▪	Social comparison bias
o	Aligning with me/my beliefs
▪	Semmelweis effect
▪	Not Invented Here bias
o	Creating relationships/togetherness/on others
▪	Courtesy bias/Bandwagon effect/Group Think
o	Recent/long ago
▪	Baader-Meinhoff
▪	Peak-end rule
●	Use in your design for good
o	Baader-Meinhoff
o	Ikea
o	Humor effect
o	Bizarreness effect
o	Default effect
●	It’s a wrap – summary of talk and take-aways
notes:
Attendees will learn several important terms and practical tips about cognitive bias. This will increase their awareness of cognitive biases, help them to understand how to apply them in positive ways in their design work and give them tangible ways to apply the concepts that they learn. It will also help them in future research efforts to prevent “leading the witness” and conduct or observe bias-free research studies.

As a user researcher and designer, I have seen first-hand how these biases can creep in to design and research. I have seen designers bias participants by their reactions (observer-expectancy bias). I have seen how I have loaded questions with my own personal (blind spot) bias. By talking about real-world and personal examples, I can help others understand how we all have biases and what we can do, as designers and technologists, to prevent them from making their way in to our projects.

I gave this talk to attendees of Big Design in Dallas in September, 2019. I know that this topic resonates strongly with the UX and design community.

title: How Enterprise Software Can be Saved by UX Research and Service Design
abstract: Through UX research, we have the chance to improve bad enterprise software. I will talk about how to take research to new heights, by applying mixed methods and by modifying the Service Design Blueprint, to suite alternative research needs and how this can make any project infinitely better.
description:
Enterprise software is often terrible. Through UX research methods, we have the chance to improve it. In this talk, I show how to apply mixed methods to inform UX design on software and services that are not consumer-facing, rather used internally by companies and employees. I will talk about how to take research to new heights, by modifying the traditional Service Design Blueprint, to suite alternative research needs and how this can make any project infinitely better.

Many of us have worked on some pretty poorly designed enterprise software. As UX professionals, we must fight for those who suffer through that experience for hours on end at work. I am going to share a case study where I applied user research methods and Service Design principles to improve the report-making process. My quest for a better customer report goes through a variety of research methods to uncover gaps and opportunities. Going from low-fidelity analysis to improvement recommendations, I show people how they can think outside of the box of a traditional Service Design Blueprint to make any project profoundly better. Using mixed methods in creative ways can be applied to projects outside of the consumer-facing UX world. 

Outline
●	Definition/overview of Enterprise software
●	Definition/overview of Service Design
●	Discuss problem to be solved: Reports for Customers
●	Research plan of attack
o	Discuss the mixed research methods used to break down problem, surface opportunities and make recommendations for improvements
●	Deeper discussion of how Service Design Blueprint was applied to this process/journey
●	Moving Service Design Blueprint from low res to high res/digital deliverable
●	Recommendations and next steps
●	Benefits of Service Design Blueprint and research process
●	Project wins and benefits
●	Explain how these methods can work for you
notes:
Internal enterprise systems and software are often easy opportunities for improvement (what we call ‘low hanging fruit’). I want attendees to be aware of just how rewarding this career opportunity can be. Also, attendees will learn how the foundations of a Service Design Blueprint and other mixed research methods, can be applied to improve the customer or employee experience. By creatively adjusting a traditional research framework, I will show the audience how making a few adjustments to the traditional swim lanes, they can make powerful Service Design Blueprints that are specifically catered to the problem they are trying to solve. 

I have several years of experience working on Enterprise software, ranging from working on software and apps for animal hospitals, financial companies, security companies and more. I understand the dire state of these systems and the need for upgrading. Plus, I have experience in mapping out a company’s system or process by using methods like a Service Design Blueprint. This method is greatly organic, and I want attendees to take away this broadened perspective so that they can apply this modified Service Design Blueprint to their projects.

title: What the “F” is UX and how does it fit in to the agile world?
abstract: When the Agile Manifesto was written, UX was not a part of that world. What do we do with these folks? How do they fit in to our sprints? How do we work with them? This talk will introduce technologists to the principles and aspects of UX that they always want to know, but were afraid to ask.
description:
There is a lot of confusion about UX. What is it? What’s the difference between UX and UI? How do UX folks relate to and work with developers?
And this is just the tip of the iceberg. When the Agile Manifesto was written, UX was not a part of that world. So this brings up even more questions:
How is UX supposed to fit in to our company’s agile model?
Should UX be part of our agile ceremonies and sprints? How is this all supposed to work. This talk will clarify the mustery of what User Experience is and how to incorporate it in to agile and sprints. 

Outline
•	Define UX
o	What UX is and is not
o	The benefits of UX
o	Demystifying the UX and user-centered design process
o	What a UX designer actually does
o	Value of user research
o	How UX can make a developer’s life easier
•	UX in Agile
o	Agile Manifesto’s principles and how they relate to UX 
o	Planning ahead
o	Timeline and sprints
o	Working on the team, we’re not a “developer”
o	Collaboration in person and remotely
o	Don’t throw it over the wall
notes: As a UX Designer and Researcher, I have worked, and often struggled, to understand my role on the scrum team. Moreover, the scrum team did not know what to do with me! Now I have a better understanding of my role on the development team. And no, it is not as another developer. When research and design is conducted by UX in advance of working sprints, UX can save developers time, mistakes and guess work. With this talk I hope to show the value of UX working ahead to make sure that developers are working on the right problems. By basing product design and development on a strong foundation of research, UX is the perfect partner to aid developers when the time comes to work on stories and epics.

name: Paul McConnell
bio: Paul is a software developer with 25 years experience building applications. Over the last five years he has been focused on web development with JavaScript, React, and Node. He lives in St. Louis, the headquarters of World Wide Technology. When he isn't coding he's probably either reading a novel or watching Blues hockey.
title: Think Thunks
abstract: Redux is missing a crucial feature; dispatching actions that involve side-effects like API calls. The Redux-Thunk package adds the ability to handle state changes that depend on async functions instead of only primitive actions. Learn to use Thunks to power up state management in your React apps.
description: Redux is one of the go-to tools for managing state in React applications. Frequently we depend on asynchronous behavior like fetching data from an API to update state. Unfortunately, out of the box, Redux can only handle synchronous state changes. The Redux-Thunk package provides the missing link needed to dispatch functions as actions so you can involve asynchronous effects in state changes. We will briefly review the standard actions provided by Redux. Then we will move on to understand how Thunks let us build action flows with promise based asynchronous calls. Finally, we will apply the concepts to create a React app using Thunks to manage loading and displaying data from an external API with loading spinners and error-handling.

name: Adrienne Tacke
bio: Adrienne Braganza Tacke is a Filipina software engineer, international speaker, and published author of the book Coding for Kids: Python. She is also a LinkedIn Learning instructor who specializes in Azure and Cloud Development courses. She takes great delight in solving complex problems and building awesome things, particularly with C# and JavaScript. Most of all, she relishes the opportunity to teach anyone about code.
title: Azure Automation: The Good Parts
abstract: Deploy several times a day. Trigger automatic builds upon the push of a commit.  Release to multiple environments with varying conditions. Sound complicated? Luckily, it's not! I'll discuss which steps are vital to automate in your dev workflow and how doing so can erase "Release Days" for good!
description:
In this talk, I'll explain which steps in a development workflow are key to configure and/or automate in order to help your team deploy faster and more reliably!

My talk's rough outline is as follows:

- Intro to the "Old" way at my company
- Promise of the "Better" way at my company
- Key #1 Benefits of having branch policies and pull request policies
   - What can happen when these aren't in place
   - Quick Demo of how to create a branch policy (in Azure DevOps)
   - Quick Demo of how to create a pull request policy (in Azure DevOps)
- Key #2 Benefits of configuring automated build and release pipelines
  - Comparison of manual vs automated builds
  - Quick Demo of how to trigger an automated build upon pushed commit (in Azure DevOps)
  - Comparison of manual vs automated releases
  - Quick Demo of how to trigger an automated release (in Azure DevOps)
- The Big Picture: How these different parts work together 
  - Benefits of a fully cohesive pipeline
  - Developer advantages to having this in place

When appropriate, I'll also be sharing  the lessons learned from implementing these strategies for my team's workflow!

Whether starting from scratch or wanting to migrate existing projects to an automated workflow, this talk will leave the audience and their team members equipped with the best practices to create, build, and deploy apps with automated ease.
notes:
Hello! 

I wanted to thank you for reaching out to me after my first talk (ever!) Delicious JavaScript: Delectable Explanations of the Power of JS at NEJS Conf to invite me to speak at your conference! I look forward to your feedback and hope I get the chance to go back to Nebraska!

name: Alison Hawke
bio: I'm the director of quality advocacy for World Wide Technology, serving a team of over forty testers in five cities. My goal is to write code that breaks code to make a better product for the user. I train technical testers who can help a team release awesome products that make client's lives better. I've been in QA since 2005 and I love getting into the code to test more thoroughly. I've written test code in Java, C#, JavaScript, and Elixir. Outside work, I'm a black belt in Chinese Kenpo and have fun sparring every week. I also knit a lot of hats. Originally from England.
title: Leadering for introverts
abstract: How to lead a team of 40+ people when you don't have the mental energy to do people stuff.
description:
Hello, my name is Alison and I'm an introvert. Groups of strangers make me nervous, parties exhaust me, and I'm scared of talking in public. Also, I lead a team of over 40 people. This is how I do it and maintain my sanity. 

Being an introvert doesn't mean you're shy, anti-social, or awkward, but it does mean that dealing with people takes more energy from you than it gives. You have to figure out where your limit is, and what you do to recover. I'll go through some of the tactics I've used that work for me, and some that didn't work. One change I made was making a scarf while doing end-of-year compensation reviews, and I'll explain why.
notes: When you score introversion on a scale of 1 to 10, I'm a 15. Somehow I ended up leading a large team with local and geographically dispersed people. I have 10 direct reports and I'm responsible for the other 30+ in my practice. As a metrics and experiments person, I've done a lot of trial and error to tweak my process and make things better.

bio: I'm the director of quality advocacy for World Wide Technology, serving a team of over forty testers in five cities. title: Before, during, after burnout
abstract: Burnout sucks, leading while you're burned out sucks more. This is about recognizing when things are going wrong, fixing them when it's bad, and how to avoid getting into this pit in the first place. Don't burnout; stop, drop, and roll!
description:
Burnout looks a lot like depression, my companion since childhood. It took me a while to recognize it, and I'm still figuring out how to deal with it. It's a lot like what we're trained to do when on fire: Stop, Drop, and Roll. 

*Stop* what you're doing because it's hurting you. Figure out what's going on. Take a vacation day to decompress, or a half day. Stop and collect your thoughts in a safe space
*Drop* the things you can delegate, or are unnecessary. This doesn't have to be permanent
*Roll* into a better situation by renegotiating what you're responsible for, and talking to your team leaders and managers. Also, how to get help for the longer term.
notes: I've been working through burnout for the last two years, and I've had to come up with strategies to keep going. I would like to keep others from going through that ordeal, and share both what's helped and what has made things worse.

title: Power-leveling the padawans
abstract: Leaders have a responsibility to find and train new leaders. This talk is about how to power-level those potential leaders without turning them into a clone army.
description: I spent five years mentoring someone one to one every week. Now he's my co-director, helping me lead a practice of software testers across the country. Our check-ins have covered everything from how his project is going, to mind-controlling fungi, to testing strategy, and where to find the best tea in town. From our first meeting, he was my science experiment: If I gave him everything I'd learned in ten years of testing, where would he end up in a year? Or in five years?
