title: Code, eat, move, rest, repeat
abstract: As developers, we want to do more and improve our productivity in and out of work. But at the same time we neglect our body, which is key to a better mind and our overall well-being. Let's debunk myths around food and exercise and learn what we really need to do to start becoming our best selves.
description: As developers, we have a tendency to try to do more, in and out of the office: stay more focused, deliver better code, learn more things, work on more side projects. This not only leads to frustration and burnout sometimes, but can also make us push basic good habits aside and neglect our bodies; something that a lot of programmers tend to do anyway. But how do we find the time and energy for all that if we're already busy and tired? Can we really be more productive and improve our well-being at the same time? In this talk we'll take a look at the basic pillars for a better body and mind: diet, movement and rest. We'll debunk some long-standing myths, learn the actual facts and provide actionable tips along the way, so you can finally start becoming the best version of yourself.
notes:
# Tentative outline

## Why

- We deem our mind important but sometimes neglect our body. This is a huge mistake since body and mind are completely interdependent.
- Diet, movement and rest have a deep impact on mental health, mood, stress levels, ability to concentrate and think more clearly.
- Moving more actually gives us more energy. It's a counterintuitive virtuous circle.
- We can be more productive in our professional and personal lives. Achieving more is not about putting more time in, but using it better (better quality, less quantity).

## Eat

- The old food pyramid has been proven wrong.
  - However the food industry keeps pushing it (low fat products).
  - A better eating guide: Harvard's Healthy Eating Plate (https://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/healthy-eating-plate/)
  - Having a "varied diet" doesn't mean eating everything. Flat out ignore most of what you find in the supermarket (processed foods).
- Calories are hard to track and a terrible measure of healthiness anyway.
  - Metabolic impact of food changes depending on the matrix (eg, free sugars vs sugar mixed with fiber in fruit).
  - Comparisons based on calories are absurd: diet coke has zero calories, nuts have a lot.
  - Focus on ingredients and amount of processing.
  - Non-processed foods fill you up way more. It's difficult to go overboard with them, but very easy with processed foods.
- Going the extra mile: reduce the feeding window
  - Intermittent fasting
  - Controlling your appetite: actual hunger vs wanting to eat

## Move

- Do not sit for long
  - Pomodoro technique: work for 30-40 min, rest for 5 min
  - Active rest: light movement during resting periods
  - Try standing desks if possible
- Lead an active life
  - Every little things adds up, take every opportunity to move
  - Climb up stairs, walk to places if they're not too far
- Do regular training
  - Consider high intensity interval training (HIIT) routines to start. Low barrier of entry: very short, can be done at home.
  - Do not neglect strength training. It's proven to be as important as cardio for your overall health.
  
## Rest

- Use natural light in the morning: be outside or close to a window
- Avoid too much artificial light in the evening: use warm lights and night mode in devices
- Keep your room dark and cool for better sleep
- Have an early dinner and don't drink caffeine late in the evening
- The most effective yet neglected thing by far: simply get enough sleep

## Others

- Impact of social life
- Free time management
- Habit building

title: You might not need JavaScript classes
abstract: Classes in JavaScript are problematic in a few important ways that many people are still not aware of, and they don't really have much advantages over alternative patterns based on just functions. Let's show the audience how to simplify their codebases by taking advantage of function composition!
description: More than three years later, the introduction of classes to the ECMAScript standard is still a controversial topic. Brought over from popular classical object-oriented languages, they've not only been argued an unnecessary feature for JavaScript, but their usage can become actually harmful very easily. In this talk we'll take a look at the potential issues and pitfalls of using classes, like the need for context binding of methods, and suggest alternative patterns that are conceptually simpler, easier to work with, safer to use, more idiomatic, require less code and are actually more powerful.
notes:
# Materials

- Video of short 15 min version from YGLF Lithuania 2019: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xwpJygokUfQ](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xwpJygokUfQ)
- Slides: [https://slides.com/soyguijarro/javascript-classes](https://slides.com/soyguijarro/javascript-classes)

# Tentative outline

## Why we got classes

- Improvement over prototype in terms of syntax.
- Familiar for people new to JavaScript coming from other languages: classes are a very common concept.

## Issues and pitfalls

- False expectations. Classes don't work like in other languages. Prototypes under the hood which are dynamic, not static.
- Lack of features. No private members, static members, decorators... There are proposals but not part of the standard yet.
- Context binding. Handling `this` is confusing and error prone in classes when async code is involved. Binding ties in with false expectations again, plus performance implications.
- Harder to optimize. Classes don't minify very well and are generally harder to deal with for tools.
- Broader disadvantages of inheritance model (vs composition)

## Alternative patterns

- Classic patterns based on prototypes (constructor functions or `Object.create`) share similar issues.
- The alternative is to use simple functions. We can do things equivalent to OOP features typically implemented with classes: inheritance, encapsulation, polymorphism, plus design patterns like singletons.
- Factory functions and modules provide instance creation with encapsulation via closures, without having to worry about `this`.
- Static type checking as an extra to enforce additional constraints (interfaces). Structural vs nominal typing.

## Recent case studies

- Hooks API introduced into React that matches class componentes functionality
- Class API proposal for Vue dropped in favor of composition functions

## Conclusions

- Adjust your expectations: classes in JavaScript do not work as in other languages
- Watch out for issues with context and `this`: remember to bind methods when dealing with async code
- Consider using functions: closures are powerful and feel natural to the language (valid reasons not to: specific performance scenarios with tons of instances, or framework forces you to use classes)

# Speaking experience

[https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro](https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro)

title: Redux is dead, long live Redux!
abstract: Writing Redux-like code with useReducer and the Context API actually makes you appreciate the architectural design and concepts behind Redux, which are definitely here to stay. This talk will happily embark on that exploration while ultimately questioning its real value beyond the educational side.
description: Redux is arguably the de-facto standard for global state management in the React ecosystem. Yet despite its huge popularity, it's often accused of being too cumbersome, requiring developers to write a lot of boilerplate code and constantly switch between many files. Tools like Redux Starter Kit aim to improve the situation, but some people still feel Redux is too much for their projects. However rolling our own state manager is out of the question. Or is it? In this talk we'll see how to take advantage of the new useReducer hook and the official Context API to build custom Redux-like solutions, so we can simplify it in whatever ways we want or take different approaches that better suit our project. The experience will actually help us understand Redux better and appreciate the good things about it.
notes:
# Materials

- Video from RuhrJS 2019: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQYbbZF4EZI](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SQYbbZF4EZI)
- Slides: [https://slides.com/soyguijarro/redux-is-dead](https://slides.com/soyguijarro/redux-is-dead)

# Talk outline

## Why people want Redux dead

- Cumbersome store configuration
- Mandatory actions introduce too much indirection for not-so-big projects and are repetitive to write
- Reducers can also be very repetitive to write and dealing with immutability is hard
- React Redux doesn't have the nicest API to connect components 

## Let's roll our own Redux killer

- Hooks (useReducer) + Context API
- Naive store implementation with a single top-level context: performance implications and architectural design issues
- Better implementation with multiple contexts: better performance and encapsulation
- A custom implementation allows different levels of complexity: you can have centralized actions or not, need to connect components or expose directly via context, etc

## Are we sure about killing Redux?

- We lose a huge ecosystem: Redux DevTools, middleware, other utils
- Redux Started Kit helps reducing boilerplate and dealing with immutability (uses Immer under the hood)
- Hooks in React Redux provide a nicer API to access store state and dispatch actions from components

## Final conclusions

- We don't need to choose: contexts for simple local UI state only used in a subtree, Redux for truly global state and normalized data
- Consider what we lose: ecosystem, documentation
- Take your context into account: tech stack, codebase, contributors, expertise, portability
- Redux is more than a library: its architectural principles still stand even if you don't use it

# Speaking experience

[https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro](https://speakerdex.co/soyguijarro)

name: Arthur Doler
bio: Arthur (or Art, take your pick) has been a software engineer for 16 years and has worked on things as exciting as analysis software for casinos and things as boring as banking websites. He is an advocate for talking openly about psychology and mental health in the technical world, and he spends a lot of time thinking about how we program and why we program, and about the tools, structures, cultures, and mental processes that help and hinder us from our ultimate goal of writing amazing things. His hair is brown and his thorax is a shiny blue color.
title: Let’s Talk About Mental Health
abstract: Mental health is an important and often overlooked facet of workplace life. This talk doesn't just cover the common mental health challenges - it uses experiential (as opposed to clinical) language to allow people to talk to each other about their mental state in an HR-approved manner.
description:
It’s a great time to be in technology. And yet despite the improvement in our tools, we somehow don’t spend time talking about how to maintain our most important tool - the one between our ears. Your mental health is arguably the single most important factor in your ability to perform well, avoid burnout, and build resiliency, but we shroud the topic in secrecy, stigma, and co-opted clinical language that makes us think we know what's going on. We often don't even speak of what we feel to family and friends until we're facing a crisis.

We need to change all of that. You don't have to stay in the dark, and you *don't* have to suffer alone. In this talk we’ll start with some basics about mental health, then cover the most common mental health challenges facing developers, and then learn about some techniques to supercharge your brain by improving your mental hygiene (whether you have a psychological disorder or not). Most importantly, you’ll learn how to have a conversation with your coworkers (and other people in your life) about supporting each other and finding your best selves.
notes: I am not a psychologist, but psychology, neuroscience, and information about why we think and work the way we do is fascinating to me, and my passion has become trying to take social psychology findings and translating those back into mindsets and processes to help us and our organizations function better. Mental health is an important and often overlooked facet of workplace life. This talk doesn’t just cover the common mental health challenges - it uses experiential (as opposed to clinical) language to allow people to talk to each other about their mental state in an HR-approved manner.

name: Devlin Duldulao
bio: Devlin Duldulao is a Microsoft MVP, an Auth0 Ambassador, a trainer, an international conference speaker, and a senior consultant at Inmeta. He loves going to universities and user groups to share his expertise.
title: The Quasar you haven't seen before
abstract: In this demo, I'll show you how to build an awesome app from scratch and use it as desktop apps, mobile apps, and a web app with authentication in less than 30 minutes.
description: Quasar is a one-stop solution Vuejs framework that allows you to create a Vue.js app with one source code and deploy it to the web as a SPA, a PWA, SSR, iOS, Android app, desktop app for Linux, Mac, Windows, and get the latest and greatest best practice out of the box.
notes: I've been doing corporate workshops, and conferences and user groups speaking for more than 2 years now. I'm also a Microsoft Certified Trainer.

name: Antonio Peric-Mazar
bio:
Antonio Perić-Mažar is CEO at Locastic digital agency, based in beautiful Croatian city called Split. Their main focus is to build complex mobile and web platforms for different clients that range from startups to enterprise companies from all over the globe.

He is a proud backend developer that moved into a managerial role after founding Locastic in 2011, since, in a very short period of time the team has grown and they became very popular in the development world.

He is quite a proactive guy - as he is one of the founders of the largest regional Blockchain Conference, he is hosting a free monthly Meetup event in Split, also recently he fell in love with Esports as he owns the best Croatian Counter-Strike team.

During the last few years Antonio also focused on sharing his business and development knowledge with Startups and other Entrepreneurs and he spoke on many conferences including:

title: The UI is the THE application
abstract: Do you know how many designers and developers still think that UX is a myth? You would be amazed! But, let’s not dwell, we can change their mind instead.
description:
Do you know how many designers and developers still think that UX is a myth? You would be amazed! But, let’s not dwell, we can change their mind instead.
We live in a digital world where everyone can offer a certain type of service, but there’s that small gap that shows the disparity between good and bad delivery. Your app is a collection of tiny details, and if your main goal is to have satisfied users - you’ll be interested to hear why UI/UX is the foundation of your application success.

name: Devlin Duldulao
bio: Devlin Duldulao is a Microsoft MVP, an Auth0 Ambassador, a trainer, an international conference speaker, and a senior consultant at Inmeta. He loves going to universities and user groups to share his expertise.
title: CORS Tutorial: A Guide to Cross-Origin Resource Sharing
abstract: Learn all about Cross-Origin Resource Sharing, how it protects you, and how to enable CORS in your applications. We'll take a look at CORS, the circumstances under which it is needed, the benefits it provides, and how to configure a Node + Express application to support CORS.
description: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) is a mechanism that allows a web page to make an AJAX call using XMLHttpRequest (XHR) to a domain that is different from the one from where the script was loaded. Such "cross-domain" requests would otherwise be forbidden by web browsers, per the same origin security policy. CORS defines a standardized way in which the browser and the server can interact to determine whether or not to allow the cross-origin request.
notes: I've been doing corporate workshops, and conferences and user groups speaking for more than 2 years now. I'm also a Microsoft Certified Trainer.

He is a proud backend developer that moved into a managerial role after founding Locastic in 2011, since, in a very short period of time the team has grown and they became very popular in the development world.

He is quite a proactive guy - as he is one of the founders of the largest regional Blockchain Conference, he is hosting a free monthly Meetup event in Split, also recently he fell in love with Esports as he owns the best Croatian Counter-Strike team.

title: Are you failing at being agile?
abstract: In these past few years, agile methods became a vital part in the software development process, but are they really applicable for all types of projects and team sizes?
description:
In these past few years, agile methods became a vital part in the software development process, but are they really applicable for all types of projects and team sizes?

A while ago, our company changed the way we approach project development because the team noticed that standard SCRUM-ish methods aren't fully compatible for us, so we developed our own, modified version of agile. In this talk, I will showcase how powerful this approach is and how you can use it to find problems, and eventually resolve them.

name: Devlin Duldulao
bio: Devlin Duldulao is a Microsoft MVP, an Auth0 Ambassador, a trainer, an international conference speaker, and a senior consultant at Inmeta. He loves going to universities and user groups to share his expertise.
title: Introduction to PASETO (platform-agnostic security tokens)
abstract: JSON Web Tokens (JWTs) have become ubiquitous in the web authentication landscape over the last four years. In this talk, I'll introduce you to their successor: PASETO tokens (platform agnostic security tokens).
description: Unlike JSON Web Tokens (JWT), which gives developers more than enough rope with which to hang themselves, Paseto only allows secure operations. JWT gives you "algorithm agility", Paseto gives you "versioned protocols". It's incredibly unlikely that you'll be able to use Paseto in an insecure way.
notes: I've been doing corporate workshops, and conferences and user groups speaking for more than 2 years now. I'm also a Microsoft Certified Trainer.

name: Scott McAllister
bio: Scott McAllister is a Developer Advocate for PagerDuty. He has been building web applications in several industries for over a decade. Now he's helping others learn about a wide range of web technologies. When he's not coding, writing or speaking he enjoys long walks with his wife, skipping rocks with his kids, and is happy whenever Real Salt Lake can manage a win.
title: Make Your JavaScript Functionally Tasty with Currying
abstract: Currying is a technique that has been part of mathematical functions for centuries, and is key component of functional programming. In this session we'll take what you know about functional JavaScript programming and pivot a bit to learn about the currying technique.
description: Currying is a technique that has been part of mathematical functions for centuries, and is key component of functional programming. While currying is heavily used in functional languages like Haskell, it's not as prevalent in JavaScript. In this session we'll take what you know about functional JavaScript programming and pivot a bit to learn about the currying technique, how to use it in your code and, most importantly, why!

name: Scott McAllister
bio: Scott McAllister is a Developer Advocate for PagerDuty. He has been building web applications in several industries for over a decade. Now he's helping others learn about a wide range of web technologies. When he's not coding, writing or speaking he enjoys long walks with his wife, skipping rocks with his kids, and is happy whenever Real Salt Lake can manage a win.
title: Client-side OAuth with PKCE
abstract: OAuth has been around a while, but usually has required a back-end server to keep a client secret, well, secret. Managing secrets can be a very hard problem to solve. Until now! Proof Key for Code Exchange, or PKCE, allows OAuth flows to be accomplished entirely in the client--and still be secure.
description: The OAuth standard has been around for a while, but traditionally it has required a back-end server to hold a client secret, well, secret. Managing secrets can be a very hard problem to solve. Until now! By supporting Proof Key for Code Exchange, or PKCE, OAuth flows can now be accomplished entirely in the client--and still be secure. In this talk we begin the standard three-legged flow and then introduce PKCE. By the time you leave, you will understand how to implement it in your client applications and the benefits for doing so.

name: Cameron Hall
bio: Cameron uses his experience in app and analytics strategy for healthcare, finance, government, and logistics apps with a focus on emerging technologies to deliver on customer-centric product development. As a strategist, he focuses in on finding the core of an app, and building and growing the app experience to scale and mature with its user base through methods like design sprints to find the core features, analytics and insight-driven iterations to grow the app with intention, and constant feedback seeking opportunities to deliver on user and business goals. As a technologist, he works to understand the tools available and the best uses of each one, building out small projects to fully understand the components. Cameron builds on a foundation in communications technology from Randolph College and management of information technology from University of Virginia.
title: Make Your Strategy Not Suck: Crafting the Pillars of a Direction that Resonates
abstract: People, process, product, and persistence. If the org doesn't know why they're doing what they're doing and for who, then the second the going gets tough the questions rise. We'll give you the same framework we use to define and evangelize a product that you can use to promote your strategy broadly.
description: When we create and define a product for organizations, it involves months of focus group testing, interviews, ideation, testing, and validation before writing a single line of code. Our approach targets specific insights and drives to essential outcomes, and yields sustainable features and measurable KPIs. This same approach can be used for outlining the strategy of your organization for others, and will give you tangible ways to measure its success.
notes: We've run this process for organizations as large as WestRock, Capital One, and American Express and as small as startups ideating and scaling. Our process was nominated for an award at the RVA Tech conference, and we regularly evangelize parts of our process at conferences around the world (we're coming to Brazil in December!). We strive to propose bulletproof solutions that seem like complete no-brainers in the way that we pair research with customer-centric design, and this applies to organization strategy incredibly well. We're happy to share specific examples over email.

name: Kenny Chan
bio: Kenny is currently working at Shopify on the Marketing Properties team. He has a background in user-centric design and engineering, solving problems with a user-first approach. His work focuses on merchant-facing properties — regarding working with many disciplines within the organization including SEO, content strategy, design, data, and growth teams. In the past year, some of the projects that I have championed includes Shopify LA, Shopify Academy, and internationalization across the Shopify properties.
title: A Multidisciplinary Approach to Accessibility
abstract: Accessibility isn't just in development or in design. It's a multidisciplinary field that literally spans almost any job within an organization. By empowering every individual on a team with the correct knowledge and resources, we can work together to create accessible webpages.
description: Accessibility isn't just in development or in design. It's a multidisciplinary field that literally spans almost any job within an organization. By empowering every individual on a team with the correct knowledge and resources, we can work together to create accessible webpages, while ensuring that no discipline loses out on their opportunity to deliver top-notch work. Building a great product requires every single component performing at 100%. This talk will go through how everyone on the team will contribute to meeting accessibility requirements, regardless of their role. We will walk through best practices from all disciplines (especially developers) on how we can keep accessibility top-of-mind.

name: Joe Karlsson
bio:
Joe Karlsson is a software engineer and Developer Advocate at MongoDB. He comes from the frozen tundra known as Minneapolis, Minnesota (and yes, it does get really cold here, and no, not everyone here has the accent from the movie, Fargo 😝). He has been primarily a Node and JavaScript engineer, but he also really enjoy the "math-y" parts about coding. He has been writing, teaching, and talking about code his entire career.

He is the co-creator of open source software, including bechdel.io which tells you if a movie script passes the Bechdel Test or not. In his free time, he is usually drinking Gin and Tonics, eating at a new restaurant, or working on an art project (his medium is a 3D printer and an Arduino).

title: Building Your First GraphQL Client in JS
abstract: GraphQL is the future of API. Together we will start with the basics and the philosophy behind GraphQL. By the end, you will leave with a working GraphQL server while we explore real world patterns.
description:
RESTful APIs have been around for a while now, but they are flawed. Things like non-standard CRUD operations, response validation, error handling, in-memory state management, etc. just get really hard. In this talk, you will learn how GraphQL - a standard that unifies server and client communication - comes to save the day, and why the tooling around it is a game-changer.

We will answer the following questions. What is the philosophy behind GraphQL? How do you architect a scalable schema? How can GraphQL boost productivity? How can you avoid common pitfalls?

We will then get a GraphQL server up and running while focusing on exploring real-world patterns for architecting our schema. We will discuss and implement practical steps to improve query performance, error handling and caching.
notes:
As an Engineer/JavaScript Instructor I have been personally using and teaching GraphQL daily for several years and have seen first hand the benefits and drawbacks of using this tool.

This talk has been presented at:

Praire Dev Con 2018 – Regina, Saskatchewan Canada
MidwestJS 2018 – Minneapolis, Minnesota
MXNow 2018 - Monterrey, Mexico

I will demo a full stack GraphQL build using MongoDB as the data layer.

You can check out the code here: https://github.com/JoeKarlsson/graphql-workshop

Slides: speakerdeck.com/joekarlsson/building-a-graphql-client-in-javascript

You can view a complete list of my past and upcoming talks with video on my website [joekarlsson.com/speaking](https://www.joekarlsson.com/speaking/).
